results.project_title: Mechanisms of trans-synaptic pathological tau spreading in the human brain
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 In Alzheimer’s disease (AD), predictable spreading of tau pathology between functionally connected
brain regions correlates well with progressive cognitive impairment, thus constituting a likely effective
treatment target. The proposed study will evaluate the molecular mechanisms of pathological tau spreading
within the framework of trans-synaptic tau spreading. Specifically, the results of this investigation will
contribute to the fundamental knowledge about the molecular mediators of tau oligomer binding in human
synapses, thus providing novel and translationally relevant avenues for future AD research.

results.project_title: Project 1: Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Treated in Health Systems
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 1 - Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Treated in Health
Systems
Vertically integrated health systems (i.e., organizations that own and operate both hospitals and
medical practices) deliver an increasing proportion of cancer care, but the impact of such integration on
patients with cancer remains unclear. This research, together with the other Projects that will use data
from Project 1, will seek to characterize how vertical integration relates (if at all) to forms of integration
that might have more direct benefits for patient care. By studying care integration in systems caring for
patients with cancer, the proposed research will help policymakers and cancer care leaders and
clinicians to identify and facilitate care integration that leads to higher quality, more efficient care for
patients with cancer.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Project 3: Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Receiving Post-Acute Care and Hospice
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 3 – Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Receiving Post-
Acute Care and Hospice
There has been substantial consolidation in post-acute care (i.e. skilled nursing facilities, inpatient
rehabilitation facilities, and home health) and hospice settings, but the impact of such structural
integration on patients with cancer remains unclear. This research, together with the other Projects will
seek to characterize how structural integration relates (if at all) to other forms of integration that might
have more direct benefits for patient care. By studying care integration for patients with cancer treated
in post-acute care and hospice settings, the proposed research will help clinicians, cancer care leaders,
and policymakers to identify and facilitate more meaningful care integration that leads to higher quality
and more equitable care for patients with cancer.

results.project_title: Statistical Methods and Data Core
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE: Statistical Methods and Data Core
The. Statistical Core will complement and support the aims of the Projects by providing data management
expertise and coordination, coordinating analytic tasks and providing statistical expertise, and developing and
applying novel methods for network analyses of health care delivery. The Program Project’s results will inform
health care provider organizations and policymakers about the relationship of multiple forms of integration to
care for patients with cancer.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Project 4: Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Using Specialty Pharmacies
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 4 - Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Using Specialty
Pharmacies
This Project will examine the extent to which pharmacy services are integrated into practices (in the presence
and absence of structural integration) and the role of specialty pharmacies in working with oncologists and
patients to ensure that patients can access, initiate, and adhere to prescribed oral anticancer medications and
supportive care medications. The findings will inform specialty pharmacy leaders, oncology practice leaders,
and policy makers about strategies to facilitate care integration to improve care delivery for patients with
cancer who may benefit from oral anticancer and supportive care medications.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Administrative Core
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE: Administrative Core
The Administrative Core will oversee and support the achievement of this Program Project, which seeks to
examine care integration across four different types of settings and assess how care integration is associated
with better care and outcomes for patients with cancer. The Administrative Core will provide oversight and
administrative support and will lead activities related to dissemination of study results to the public, the broader
research community, and key stakeholders, including patients, clinicians and clinician leaders, payers, and
policymakers.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Project 2: Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Treated in Independent Practices
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE: Project 2 – Care Integration for Patients with Cancer Treated in Independent
Practices
To achieve the best possible outcomes for the large number of cancer patients treated in independent
oncology practices, medical oncologists and practice staff must coordinate and integrate care with other
clinicians and across a wide range of organizational boundaries and settings and over time. This project will
generate new knowledge about the current state of care integration for cancer patients and about how cancer
care can be better integrated to improve care for diverse sets of patients. The findings will inform practice
leaders and policymakers about changes in organizations, markets, and policies to facilitate care integration
that leads to higher quality and more efficient care for patients with cancer.

results.project_title: Generation of highly differentiated NK cells to synergize with broadly neutralizing antibodies to establish viral control in absence of ART
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
We are proposing comprehensive, mechanistically focused, and highly synergistic studies that will determine
the factors promoting in vivo the development and maintenance of terminally-differentiated natural killer (NK)
cells with enhanced antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity. Furthermore, we will investigate how those
factors can be synergistically harnessed with IL-21 and bNAbs treatments to enhance viral control of simian
immunodeficiency virus in the absence of antiretroviral therapy.

results.project_title: Flavivirus and Alphavirus ReVAMPP (FLARE)
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative. Our ReVAMMP Center (Flavivirus and Alphavirus ReVAMPP, FLARE)
addresses the hypothesis that innovative approaches to antigen and vaccine design and
monoclonal antibody screening will promote the development of platform technologies that can
rapidly generate countermeasures against current and future flavivirus and alphavirus threats.
With our allied industry partners, we will develop and optimize protein nanoparticle, virion-
based, and mRNA vaccines, and mAb-based treatments to respond to emerging flaviviruses
and alphaviruses with pandemic potential using a pathogen prototype, modular approach.

results.project_title: The epigenetic basis of socioeconomic determinants of cardiometabolic health in American Indians
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
American Indians are disproportionately affected by cardiometabolic diseases, and these disparities may be
due, in part, to socioeconomic inequities that burden American Indian communities. An understanding of the
biological mechanisms that may be involved in the socioeconomic determinants of cardiometabolic health will
be instrumental to abrogating cardiometabolic disease disparities in American Indians; thus, this proposal will
provide a comprehensive examination of feasible epigenetic mechanisms that may underlie the effects of
socioeconomic adversity on cardiometabolic disease risk in American Indians. Findings from this study will
improve our understanding into the importance that socioeconomic determinants have on cardiometabolic
health in American Indians with relevance to other susceptible populations, and it will provide compelling
evidence that will be instrumental towards developing preventative strategies and precision medicine
approaches to addressing socioeconomic inequities and cardiometabolic disease disparities.

results.project_title: Project 1 Melnick
results.phr_text:
PROJECT 1: NARRATIVE
This proposal explores how somatic mutations in chromatin modifier genes synergize to alter the epigenetic and
3D genomic landscapes of B-cells to drive formation of profoundly immune-evasive lymphomas. Specifically,
the investigators will identify the basic mechanism through which the common CREBBP and KMT2D enhancer
regulatory proteins synergize to drive lymphomagenesis and engage in aberrant cross-talk with T-cell
subpopulations. Based on their mechanistic discoveries they will develop novel therapeutic regimens aimed at
restoring the functionality of the immune system and making these tumors vulnerable to immune eradication.

results.project_title: Project 2 Josefowicz
results.phr_text:
PROJECT 2: NARRATIVE
In lymphoma signals that rapidly transmit information from the extracellular environment to alter gene expression
and cell programming are aberrantly active resulting in a persistent growth and differentiation program. We study
these signals and their function in lymphoma with the hypothesis that aggressive and difficult to treat lymphoma
are highly dependent on them.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: IMPACT-MH: Clinical and behavioral fingerprints of psychopathology
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Despite significant advances in research and clinical care for mental illness, prediction of clinical course at the individual
level remains elusive, in part due to a dearth of longitudinal data collected using assessments sensitive to individual
change over time. Using a combination of ‘traditional’ clinical information (e.g., health records, standardized
assessments) and more novel computational data (e.g., behavioral tasks with demonstrated sensitivity to latent
constructs and to within-person change), this IMPACT-MH project will collect longitudinal data from a cohort of 2400
individuals, highly enriched for psychopathology across multiple diagnostic categories. These data will be used to
conduct person-centered analyses focused on (i) individual-level prediction of outcomes; (ii) characterization of diverse
clinical trajectories; and (iii) data-driven analyses to identify subgroups (aka, ‘biotypes’) that predict differences in
outcomes at 2 years.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

results.project_title: Structural and Functional Studies on the Glucosyltransferases of the Dental Caries Pathogen Streptococcus mutans
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Beginning with the eruption of baby teeth, dental caries affects humans of all races, ages, and sexes. The
proposed studies will elucidate the novel catalytic mechanism(s) of glucosyltransferases by which the dental
caries etiological agent Streptococcus mutans (SM) synthesizes insoluble (a-1,3-linked) and soluble (a-1,6-
linked) glucans. The results will define novel enzymatic mechanism(s) and lead to the development of new
inhibitors to prevent SM’s acid generation, which initiates enamel erosion and dental caries.

full_study_section.name: Psychosocial Development, Risk and Prevention Study Section[PDRP]

results.project_title: Effects of enriched parent-infant interaction on health in early life
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This research will test the efficacy of enrichment interventions focused on parent-infant interactions via singing,
music-listening, and book-reading, for improving parent and infant health. Primary outcomes of interest include
improvements to infant and parent mood, infant sleep quality, infant ability to recover from distress, and parent
well-being. The interventions are low-cost and low-effort for parents, so may have outsized impacts, especially
in underprivileged families and first-time parents.

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

full_study_section.name: Clinical, Treatment and Health Services Research Study Section[AA-3]

results.project_title: Ketone supplementation as an intervention to alleviate alcohol withdrawal and improve brain energetics in Alcohol Use Disorder
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The proposed research study aims to identify whether a daily ketone supplement (KS) reduces the need for
benzodiazepine medication to treat withdrawal and improves brain ketone and GABA metabolism in individuals
with alcohol use disorder (AUD) during inpatient detoxification. The proposed study will generate fundamental
knowledge on the potentially beneficial effects of a novel treatment for AUD and its underlying neural
mechanisms. As a treatment for AUD, KS may offer a unique option: a dietary supplement whose use could
obviate potentially dependence-producing benzodiazepine medication or augment its beneficial effects.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Stem-like T cells as bioindicators and orchestrators of the disease process in MS and animal models
results.phr_text:
Stem-like T cells are proposed to orchestrate autoimmune responses, but little is known
about the role of CD4+ encephalitogenic stem-like T cells. We have designed new ways
to identify and characterize these cells using state-of-the-art transcriptomic signatures
based on multiple genes rather than relying on the conventional single-gene approach.
These new analytical tools will help develop these stem-like CD4+ T cells as novel
bioindicators of MS, and the outcome of these studies will have both scientific and
translational impact.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

results.project_title: Investigating the Role of Macrophages in Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction
results.phr_text:
Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) accounts for roughly half the cases of heart failure in the
United States. HFpEF is a complex syndrome that presents with diastolic dysfunction, and is associated with
comorbidities like obesity, hypertension, diabetes and metabolic syndrome. The underlying pathophysiology of
HFpEF is not well understood, all clinical trials in HFpEF have failed to show any benefit on clinical parameters
thus far. Understanding the role of inflammation on the onset and progression of HFpEF pathophysiology will
significantly improve our knowledge and potentially identify novel therapeutic targets.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Molecular and Cellular Biology of Virus Infection Study Section[MCV]

results.project_title: Determining the role of AnnexinA2 in HIV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 assembly
results.phr_text:
Human Immunodeficiency Virus Type 1 (HIV-1) and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus Type 2
(SARS-CoV-2) remain significant public health concerns. Assembly of HIV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 virus particles
occurs within cholesterol-rich membrane microdomains, or lipid rafts. This study will determine how the lipid-
raft scaffold protein AnnexinA2 recruits both HIV-1 Nef and SARS-CoV-2 Spike to sites of viral assembly,
which may inform the development of novel antiviral therapies.

full_study_section.name: Integrative and Clinical Endocrinology and Reproduction Study Section[ICER]

results.project_title: Genetic Causes of Endocrine Hypertension in Black Americans
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Dysregulated aldosterone production from one or both adrenal glands (primary aldosteronism, PA) is the most
common cause of endocrine hypertension, accounting for 5-10% of hypertension and 14-20% of resistant
hypertension. Research focused on defining the genetic causes of PA in Black Americans is limited despite their high
prevalence of hypertension, and the higher susceptibility to hyperaldosteronism and cardiovascular mortality. The
central goals of this proposal are to define the spectrum of adrenal aldosterone-driver somatic mutations in Black
American PA patients and identify targeted therapeutics that block mutation-driven aldosterone production in
endocrine hypertension.

full_study_section.name: Modeling and Analysis of Biological Systems Study Section[MABS]

results.project_title: Modeling of cell-specific LRP1 signaling in acute myocardial infarction
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE Modeling of cell-specific LRP1 signaling in acute myocardial infarction
The American Heart Association estimates that every 42 seconds an American will have an acute myocardial
infarction (AMI), and despite the improvement in treatment and prognosis, a significant number of patients
continue to die and AMI survivors remain at high risk of developing heart failure (HF).
Low-density lipoprotein receptor related protein-1 (LRP1) is a membrane receptor known as a scavenger for the
serine protease inhibitors (SERPINs) that also possesses anti-inflammatory and pro-survival signals in cultures
cardiomyocytes and proliferative signals in fibroblasts. We propose that using modeling to define the differential
signaling pathways of LRP1 in cardiomyocytes and cardiac fibroblasts may open the way to novel therapeutic
strategies targeting LRP1 in AMI, heart failure, and other related diseases.

full_study_section.name: Social Sciences and Population Studies B Study Section[SSPB]

results.project_title: Experimental Study of a Model to Support Research Evidence Use for Protecting Children
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
If science is to inform effective child protection policy and ultimately improve public health, the field needs an
effective strategy for directly supporting policymakers’ use of research evidence, yet our field lacks an evidence-
based model designed for this purpose. Accordingly, we propose a state-level randomized controlled trial (N =
30 states) of a formal, theory-based approach for appropriately supporting policymakers’ use of scientific
evidence--known as the Research-to-Policy Collaboration (RPC) Model. This work has the potential to reduce
population-level child maltreatment and protect children by improving the use of scientific information in
policymaking, thus increasing the availability of evidence-based prevention programs and policies.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: mRNA lipid nanoparticles for pre-eclampsia
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Pre-eclampsia is an obstetric condition that affects 5–8% of all pregnancies and is a leading cause of maternal
mortality worldwide. Currently, no curative treatment options for pre-eclampsia exist. The goal of the proposed
work is to develop a targeted, placenta-tropic lipid nanoparticle (LNP) platform for the delivery of therapeutic pro-
angiogenic mRNA cargo to the placenta to treat pre-eclampsia during pregnancy.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

results.project_title: Investigating the oral microbiome in hematopoietic cell transplants
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Oral mucositis and bloodstream infections remain as a serious complication in hematopoietic cell transplant
(HCT) recipients. The focus of this project is to understand the oral microbial community changes during the
development and progression of OM and BSI in HCT recipients, and to define the bloodstream microbial profile
in this cohort to determine if the oral cavity is the likely source of bloodstream infections. The results of these
studies will inform future preventive and therapeutic strategies to reduce OM and BSI burden in this high-risk
patient population.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Engaging Mental Health Services for Preschoolers at Risk
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Low income, ethno-racial minoritized children exhibit higher rates of persistent mental health disorders and are
at greater risk for lags in identification and treatment creating a mental health equity concern for the most
vulnerable. Our team developed and tested an ethno-racially matched, peer-based family navigator program
for Head Start preschoolers with developmental concern bringing about increased caregiver engagement in
child services. The current proposal is an adapted family navigation program for caregivers of young children
at risk for mental health conditions to increase engagement in services and improve child mental health
outcomes.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

full_study_section.name: Oral, Dental and Craniofacial Sciences Study Section[ODCS]

results.project_title: Multi-functional 3D Printed Dental Implants for Preventing Peri-implantitis
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
This research will develop a unique multi-functional 3D printed dental implant that will effectively minimize peri-
implantitis, i.e., dental implant-related infection incidences for patients needing artificial tooth/teeth. This unique
infection-resistant and bioactive dental implant can also be tailored according to patient defects. They will
relieve patients from the baleful aftermaths of infections, such as surgical pain, repeated clinic visits for
treatment, prolonged recovery time, reliability on antibiotics, and added therapy costs.

organization.org_name: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics of Mechanistically Aware Phage Cocktails
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE: Cocktails of individually efficacious phages have been proposed as a strategy to create
clinically viable phage therapeutics with sufficient spectrum of activity to combat highly resistant Pseudomonas
aeruginosa. As such, this project will generate a highly optimized N-phage cocktail using a hybrid machine
learning-pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic paradigm to strategically select N-phage components, dose, and
administration schedule to maximize the killing of multi- and extensively-drug resistant Pseudomonas
aeruginosa. This project will leverage phage whole-body distribution from our murine pneumonia model to
establish a human, physiologically based pharmacokinetic model, which will allow detailed assessment of
expected human exposures to phage and describe key aspects of target-mediated phage distribution.

organization.org_name: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Analytics and Statistics for Population Research Panel B Study Section[ASPB]

results.project_title: Development and Psychometric Evaluation of Gastrointestinal Symptom Measures in Autistic Children and Adults
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms are common and disabling among autistic children and adults, yet there are
important limitations to existing measures of GI symptoms for this population. The proposed research will focus
on the development, refinement, and psychometric evaluation of four versions (self-report and parent-report
versions of pediatric and adult measures) of a novel questionnaire, the Autism Gastrointestinal and Related
Behaviors Inventory (GIRBI). These measures will help promote rigorous epidemiology of gastrointestinal
dysfunction, timely screening and diagnosis of GI conditions in research and clinical situations, assessment of
safety and effectiveness of clinical trial interventions, and ultimately, health and well-being of autistic children
and adults.

results.project_title: State social policy interventions for maternal health
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The proposed project will contribute fundamental knowledge about how state-level social policies that provide
economic resources and supports for low-income and other socially disadvantaged groups of U.S. women
during the childbearing years can intervene upon public health priority maternal mental health outcomes and
disparities. Findings will cue policy makers to action and inform cross-sector “women’s health in all policies”
approaches to reduce poverty, maternal morbidity and mortality, and promote maternal health equity across
the reproductive life course and for generations of families.

full_study_section.name: Population and Public Health Approaches to HIV/AIDS Study Section[PPAH]

results.project_title: Exploring sustained implementation and fidelity of an evidence-based HIV prevention program
results.phr_text:
PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENT
The Bahamas has responded to its formerly high rates of HIV infections with a broad and aggressive HIV/AIDS
prevention program including children in the school system. We have worked with them to develop and test the
effectiveness of one such HIV prevention program (FOYC+CImPACT) among grade six students. The grade
six program was shown to be very effective through a study that followed the students for three years after they
had received the training. Therefore, the Ministry of Education (MOE) of The Bahamas decided to mandate the
use of FOYC+CImPACT throughout all government grade six classes in The Bahamas. Over the past decade,
the research team partnered with the Bahamian Ministries of Education and Health to utilize two national
implementation programs to study teachers’ fidelity of implementation and theory-driven implementation
strategies to increase teachers’ continued implementation of evidence-based interventions. Our decade-long
nationwide implementation research provides a unique opportunity to investigate the trajectories and
determinants of sustainability for HIV behavioral interventions. This study will provide valuable information to
all countries and communities struggling to prevent their youth from becoming infected with HIV and doing so
in a manner the country/community can afford to sustain. This information will also answer questions about
maintaining the effectiveness over time of other prevention programs that are incorporated into school
curricula.

results.project_title: Core 1: Lymphoma models
results.phr_text:
CORE 1 LYMPHOMA MODEL SYSTEMS: NARRATIVE
The preclinical models and therapeutics core (LMSC) scope is relevant to public health because it provides an
effective strategy for developing cancer models for comprehensive tumor profiling. These resources will enable
project leaders to define selected lesions' pathogenetic role and identify their relevance in mouse and human
tissue samples using engineered mouse models and PDX and PDO models. The construction of innovative
platforms will provide new tools to cross-validate experimental findings, dissect the molecular culprits, and
discover novel therapeutic avenues. The proposed research is relevant to the NCI’s mission to conduct and
fund research in cancer.

results.project_title: Identifying multilevel facilitators of care outcomes among Positive Deviants to design an intervention for Black sexual minority men living with HIV
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
 The proposed study offers a multi-modal approach to identify necessary intervention components to
improve HIV care outcomes by studying how durably virally suppressed Black sexual minority men overcome
racism, intersectional stigma, and other barriers. Guided by Positive Deviance, we will study faciliators of viral
suppression among Black sexual minority men living with HIV in Prince George’s County, MD and Shelby
County, TN and use data visualization to identify actionable mechanisms for behavioral and/or multilevel
intervention(s). Findings have crucial implications for designing high-impact interventions by elucidating
existing strategies from successful community members that could be scaled for others.

full_study_section.name: Clinical Neuroimmunology and Brain Tumors Study Section[CNBT]

results.project_title: Addressing tumor heterogeneity in pediatric gliomas with precision adoptive T cell therapy
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Despite a multi-modal standard of care treatment approach including radiation therapy,
chemotherapy, and surgical resection, the outcome remains poor for pediatric high-grade gliomas
necessitating the development of new therapies. We have previously established an FDA IND-
approved personalized adoptive cellular therapy (ACT) platform utilizing total tumor RNA-pulsed
dendritic cells (DCs) to expand polyclonal tumor-specific T cells for the treatment of invasive and
refractory brain cancers. In this proposal, we will explore a superior approach utilizing the
identification and selective amplification of patients’ tumor-specific antigens and uniquely
identifying, sorting, and expanding responding tumor-specific T cells for use in ACT to improve
the eradication of invasive HGG before pursuing an early phase human clinical trial.

results.project_title: Evolution of heat tolerance and drug resistance in Cryptococcus
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Many pathogens live in the environment prior to encountering a mammalian host. As a result, human
interactions with the environment can alter the population of pathogens we are likely to encounter and thus
with which we are infected. This proposal aims to understand how heat tolerance and drug resistance are
controlled by genetic variation at two different time scales (across a genus and within a species) of
opportunistic environmental fungal pathogens in order to better predict how pathogens are likely to be altered
by human activities.

results.project_title: A Triad Approach Towards Improved Diagnostics for Maternal and Congenital Syphilis
results.phr_text:
Project narrative
In consultation with end users, we will develop a first-in-class, inexpensive, rapid, and reliable point-of-care
nucleic acid diagnostic to enable accessible and rapid testing for congenital syphilis. To enable development of
modern diagnostics for maternal syphilis, we will evaluate detectability of syphilis pathogen DNA and syphilis
associated microbiome changes in maternal vaginal swabs. The proposed project will make a significant impact
on congenital syphilis prevention because our team has in-depth expertise, validated diagnostic assay and
device technologies, public health nexus with sexual health care, industry partnerships for commercialization,
and the commitment to make healthcare universally accessible.

results.project_title: Modulating growth, progression and metastasis in breast cancer by inhibiting MDA-9
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Our preliminary results demonstrate that targeting MDA-9 using the pharmacological inhibitor PDZ1i
sensitizes metastatic breast tumor cells to conventional therapeutics. This proposal intends to
characterize the mechanism by which PDZ1i, administered in a nanoformulation (PDZ1i-Nano),
controls TNBC progression (growth and cellular dissemination) and sensitizes breast cancer cells to
the toxic effects of chemotherapies and determine if these responses are enhanced further in terms of
preventing metastasis when PDZ1i is used in combination with standard of care chemotherapies.

results.project_title: Brainstem glial senescence and dysfunction in obesity-induced hypertension
results.phr_text:
The economic and social impact of obesity has reached an all-time high of almost 1.4 trillion dollars in 2018, of
which 40% is attributed to cardiovascular diseases. The current proposal will address a novel central
mechanism that could be pharmacologically targeted for reducing or preventing the heightened risk for
cardiovascular diseases in obese individuals.

results.project_title: Machine learning-enabled design of prototype pathogen vaccines and antibodies
results.phr_text:
We propose a highly coordinated and synergistic Center that will develop end-to-end approaches and
generalizable methods for designing potently protective vaccines against paramyxoviruses and bunyaviruses.
Our Center brings together groups with world-leading expertise in computational protein design,
structure-based vaccine design, mRNA vaccines, structural biology, viral entry, viral diversity and evolution,
animal model development, high biosafety-level containment virology, vaccinology, and vaccine process
development and technology transfer. Our Center will generate new knowledge, tools, and generalizable
vaccine design approaches that will significantly advance vaccine development for pandemic preparedness
generally, and will have a direct impact on public health through the development of antibody and vaccine
candidates for several paramyxoviruses and bunyaviruses.

results.project_title: Conte Center: Understanding Latent Cause Inference in Health and Illness
results.phr_text:
A variety of mental health conditions can be considered disorders of generalization, e.g., overgeneralization in
anxiety and compulsion, and undergeneralization in schizophrenia. Latent cause inference is a fundamental
cognitive process that lies at the heart of how we set generalization boundaries in perception, learning and
decision making. We propose a comprehensive characterization of individual differences in latent cause
inference and their relationship to self-reported symptom dimensions and clinical categories, as well as their
underlying neural circuitry, proposing latent cause inference as a new RDoC dimension.

results.project_title: Epigenetic basis and therapeutic targeting of the unique lymphoma immunological niche
results.phr_text:
OVERALL: NARRATIVE
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is an aggressive and clinically heterogeneous malignancy derived
from germinal center (GC) B-cells. The central hypothesis of this P01 program is that different scenarios of
aberrant GC immune synapse signaling to chromatin is the primary driver of these diverse DLBCL phenotypes
and explains the divide between GCB and ABC DLBCLs. The various projects will synergistically probe this
question from different perspectives, using innovative and cutting-edge technologies developed by the
scientific cores, expecting to yield fundamental new insights into DLBCL pathogenesis and precision therapies.

organization.org_name: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Project 4 Green-Davis
results.phr_text:
PROJECT 4: NARRATIVE
The activated B-cell-like subtype of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (ABC-DLBCL) is driven by chronic active B-
cell receptor (BCR) signaling and constitutive NFκB activity. Here we aim to characterize the role of BCR and
NFκB signaling in molding the epigenetic landscape of ABC DLBCL through transcription factors that recruit the
histone acetyltransferase CREBBP. We will investigate the role of CREBBP in maintaining the expression of
BCR and NFκB signaling genes, which may establish selective CREBBP inhibition as an attractive therapeutic
strategy in ABC DLBCL.

results.project_title: 3D In vivo dosimetry for FLASH proton therapy
results.phr_text:
The field of FLASH radiotherapy has experienced wide interest and growth and could be a critical area of
development for better normal tissue sparing in radiotherapy. The Overall Objective of this application is to use
protoacoustic/ultrasound imaging to precisely guide FLASH proton therapy which will greatly facilitate the

results.project_title: Integrative Analysis and Visualization Platform for Cancer Regulatory Genomics
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Our project focuses on developing a comprehensive platform to analyze and visualize cancer-specific
regulatory genomics and chromatin structure, utilizing extensive genomic data from sources like TCGA,
TARGET, and ICGC. This initiative includes creating a regulatory-element–target-gene atlas, identifying and
predicting the effects of genetic aberrations on regulatory elements, and building an integrated, user-friendly
web platform for data visualization and outreach within the scientific community.

results.project_title: Structural consequences of PKC-dependent phosphorylation of Kv7.2
results.phr_text:
Narrative
 M-channels play a critical role for preventing neuronal excitability disease such as seizures. The details are
unclear regarding how M channel activity is regulated. The proposed study aims to provide a detailed
description of how M channels are regulated, which is expected improve therapies for excitability diseases.

results.project_title: PRomoting Excellence through Pain and Addiction Research Enhancement (PREPARE)
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
At present there is an enormous need for new safe and efficacious treatments designed to relieve the burden of
chronic pain and substance use disorders (SUD). However, there is a deficit of scientists trained to conduct
clinical research investigating pain and SUD that can move the fields forward. In order to address this gap, we
propose the Promoting Excellence through Pain and Addiction Research Enhancement (PREPARE) Program
with the long-term goal of creating the next generation of investigators who will advance science through cutting
edge clinical research that helps relieve pain and ameliorate SUD.

full_study_section.name: Organization and Delivery of Health Services Study Section[ODHS]

results.project_title: School-Located Vaccination to Reduce Inequities in Vaccination Uptake Among Historically Excluded Populations in Colorado
results.phr_text:
This study will examine the impact of school-located vaccination (SLV) on routine, influenza, and
COVID-19 vaccination rates among school-aged children and adolescents in Colorado from 2018-2024,
overall and among health disparity populations. We will use propensity score matching in extended Cox
models to assess the causal impact of three SLV models: school-based health centers (SBHCs), school-
located vaccination clinics (SLVCs) independent of an SBHC, and SLVCs run by an SBHC, on students’
vaccination likelihood; simulate potential local- and state-level impacts of SLVCs on routine, influenza,
and COVID-19 vaccine coverage among all students in Colorado and members of health disparity
populations; and use the Consolidated Framework for Implementation Research and a modified positive
deviance approach to examine contextual factors influencing recent implementation and success of the
three models of SLV. Study findings will be immediately actionable for implementers and policymakers in
Colorado and across the country as they work to address vaccination inequities exacerbated by the
COVID-19 pandemic and prepare for future public health emergencies.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Identifying and overcoming mechanisms of resistance to effectively target the TBL1/β-catenin signaling axis for high-risk osteosarcoma
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Osteosarcoma is a extremely aggressive bone tumor with a high propensity to metastasize, which is associated
with an extremely poor prognosis and thus in dire need of more effective targeted therapies. However, with the
incorporation of novel mono-therapeutic agents directed at targeting relapsed and metastatic disease, there is a
high propensity for the development of resistance. Thus, the identification of molecular mechanisms of resistance
and rational, synergistic combination therapies is particularly relevant to the NIH’s mission toward the
identification of novel therapeutic interventions that can be implemented to prevent and treat this highly
aggressive pediatric cancer.

full_study_section.name: Oral, Dental and Craniofacial Sciences Study Section[ODCS]

results.project_title: Decoding the glycome of oral Treponema denticola
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
As an important oral pathogen, the oral bacterium Treponema denticola is not only associated with oral infections
(e.g., periodontitis, necrotic root canals and endodontic infections) but also implicated in several systemic
illnesses such as Alzheimer’s disease and oral squamous cell carcinoma. However, little is known about its
virulence determinants that are associated with those diseases. Therefore, identification of virulence factors and
understanding their roles in the pathogenicity of T. denticola will ultimately lead to a new modality to prevent and
treat periodontitis and probably other diseases as well.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Developing liquid biopsy tests for malignant effusions using artificial intelligence-assisted, morphology-based isolation of tumor cells
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 The excess fluids removed from the lungs or abdomen of patients with malignant effusions could serve
as substrates for liquid biopsy (i.e., molecular profiling of tumor cells in body fluids) to develop novel predictive
biomarkers and discover drug targets to treat these frequent and devastating complications of metastatic breast
cancer. UCSF investigators collaborated with Deepcell, a company that developed an artificial intelligence-
assisted, morphology-based approach to isolate tumor cells away from the predominant immune cell populations
in malignant effusions and successfully generated molecular profiles and morphology atlases of these cells. In
this proposal, we expand this collaboration to validate the Deepcell platform and develop liquid biopsy tests to
assess known actionable biomarkers and discover new ones, with a vision of transforming the treatment of
malignant effusions from a palliative setting to a therapeutic opportunity.

results.project_title: Federal Housing Assistance and Birth Outcomes in the United States
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
A growing body of evidence suggests that in-utero experiences of housing insecurity are associated with an
increased risk of adverse birth outcomes in low-income households
.
By reducing exposure to housing insecurity,
prenatal housing assistance programs may play an important role in reducing the risk of adverse birth outcomes
among low-income children. This study seeks to evaluate the impact of prenatal housing assistance on risk for
adverse birth outcomes using quasi-experimental methods and a novel linkage of U.S. Department of Housing
and Urban Development administrative records with California vital statistics birth records.

results.project_title: Mechanisms of Integrative and Conjugative Elements in Oral Bacteria
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Horizontal gene transfer through mobile genetic elements drives the adaptive evolution of bacterial pathogens
and contributes significantly to the spread of pathogenic properties throughout bacterial communities. We
recently discovered an integrative and conjugative element (a type of mobile element that is transferred from
cell to cell via conjugation) on the genome of the oral pathogen Streptococcus mutans. In this project, we will
investigate fundamental aspects of the element’s biology and its influence on S. mutans pathogenesis,
including the signals that govern this transfer, interactions with other mobile genetic elements and bacterial
defense systems, and elemental mechanisms that may ultimately harm the host bacterial cell.

results.project_title: Investigating Novel HIV Reservoirs in the Pulmonary Vasculature
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
The presence of Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) in the cells of the infected people limits the development
of an effective cure to this infection. These cells or organs where the virus persists are called “HIV reservoirs”
and scientists are still working to keep discovering new HIV reservoirs that may need study. We propose
experiments to investigate a cell type that is in the blood vessels of the lungs as potential cells acting as viral
reservoirs.

results.project_title: Project 3 Cerchietti
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The purpose of our studies is to understand if a common type of aggressive lymphoma (diffuse large B-cell
lymphoma) represents a biologically distinct entity when arises in elderly people. We will study epigenetic
mechanisms associated with aging in favoring the activity of oncogenes and how this process may represent
unique therapeutic vulnerabilities. If successful, these studies will launch the development of specific and likely
low-toxicity treatments that could benefit elderly patients with incurable lymphomas.

results.project_title: Nonlinearities in Human Vestibular Reflexes
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Older adults have poorer vestibular, or balance, function and the reasons for this are not well understood. This
research will examine the natural disease state of age-related changes in the human vestibular system, with an
emphases on a novel, sustained stimulation approach to study nonlinear aspects of vestibular reflexes.
Information learned from this research will help to better understand basic aspects of human vestibular function
as well as underlying causes of balance difficulties in older adults and may help to develop new clinical tools
for the diagnosis and monitoring of vestibular disease.

results.project_title: CD79A as a molecular switch regulating B cell activation
results.phr_text:
In this application we propose to define how a molecular motif, responsible for B cell activation, possesses an
intrinsic regulatory function that can prevent or modulate B cell activation. The overarching goal of these
studies is to better understand how the earliest events in lymphocyte activation impact the balance of activating
and inhibitory signaling, which shape B cell responses and immune tolerance. Gained knowledge has direct
translational implications for the design of chimeric antigen receptor for immunotherapies that exploit this
molecular motif.

results.project_title: Dose control of recombinant Adeno-associated virus with Chemical Epigenetic Modifiers
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Recombinant adeno-associated virus (rAAV) is a popular DNA vector for gene therapies, but
both under- and over-expression of rAAV transgenes can hinder therapeutic benefit. Our group
has recently developed a technology that can chemically control gene expression through
reversible epigenetic editing. The proposed work will apply this chemical epigenetic technology
to rAAV with the goal of improving the safety and efficacy of future gene therapies.

results.project_title: Predicting Clinical Deterioration in Mechanically Ventilated Children using High-Frequency Physiologic Data
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Early identification of children at high risk of deterioration is a challenge, but a data-driven approach that
incorporates high-frequency physiological data from bedside monitors will improve our ability to identify this at-
risk population. The proposed work will derive, validate, and design for the implementation of a machine
learning-based prediction model that identifies mechanically ventilated children at risk of new or worsening
cardiorespiratory dysfunction. This is a critical step towards implementing acceptable and effective real-time,
longitudinal prediction models at the bedside of the critically ill child.

results.project_title: Repurposing Ferumoxytol Nanoparticles to Promote Orofacial Stem Cell Function for Autotherapies
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance Statement
Oral inflammatory diseases, such as periodontitis, are characterized by progressive destruction of supporting
structures, which is mainly attributed to the degeneration of endogenous stem cells. The findings of this proposal
will identify a novel cellular mechanism in activating somatic stem cell abilities through repurposing an FDA
approved nanoformulation for a new biomedical, clinical application.

results.project_title: Exploring the function of novel arginine phosphorylation in streptococcal physiology
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Bacteria belonging to the genus Streptococcus are responsible for various human diseases and phosphorylation
of proteins plays a major role in bacterial physiology and virulence. In this study, we propose to unravel the role
of arginine phosphorylation, a novel form of phosphorylation, in the pathophysiology of streptococci. Our study
could potentially identify a novel bacterial arginine kinase and shed new molecular insights into how arginine
phosphorylation modulates streptococcal proteome.

results.project_title: Implementing Sustainable mobile health Technology to Optimize smoking cessation Program for Lao people with HIV (I-STOP)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project is a collaborative initiative between US researchers and Lao Ministry of Health officials to compare
2 smoking cessation implementation strategies for people with HIV who smoke in 8 antiretroviral therapy clinics
in Laos. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is ultimately expected to advance
understanding of real-world impact of smoking cessation approaches in low- and middle-income settings.
Findings from this project will contribute evidence that has the potential to shift national tobacco treatment
strategies in Laos and in other low- and middle-income countries and subsequently reduce tobacco-induced
cancer morbidity and mortality.

results.project_title: Using miRNA to identify new therapeutic pathways for dilated cardiomyopathy
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
 Mutations in many genes place patients at very high risk of developing dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), which
often leads to heart failure and early death. Personalized mutation-specific therapies have shown great promise
in other areas, but none are available for DCM. I will test the hypothesis that identifying the molecular pathways
by which different mutations lead to DCM may facilitate the development of targeted therapeutic strategies.

results.project_title: Spatial and Temporal Resolution of EosinophilSpecialization in Allergic Microenvironments
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Eosinophils are a key type of white blood cell in allergic disease that were historically characterized as only
promoting inflammation, but compelling evidence is emerging that eosinophils have a variety of functions in
distinct tissue environments. This proposal will research the range of eosinophil functions during allergic
disease, which may improve the understanding of how eosinophil-depleting drugs affect human health. This
work may substantially expand the role of eosinophils to include resolving allergic inflammation and may inform
strategies to bring personalized and predictive medicine to the treatment of allergic, inflammatory, and
autoimmune diseases.

results.project_title: THRIVE-DM: Improving Diabetes Care with Strategies for Addressing Health-Related Social Needs and Community Partnerships
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project aims to pilot and assess an innovative, enhanced closed-loop health-related social needs (HRSN)
screening and referral model designed to maximize the proportion of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes (T2DM)
patients with HRSN who connect with and obtain resources from social service organizations to address those
needs. The objectives of this proposal are consistent with the goals of the RFA-DK-22-038 to assess both the
feasibility and acceptability of screening and implementing referral service linkages initiated within the context
of the health care visit and assess the impact on both HRSN and T2DM outcomes. We expect that evidence
generated from implementing and piloting this community-engaged, patient-centered model with form the basis
for a fully powered study of this approach, contributing critical evidence for how safety-net health systems can
advance health equity at the clinical, institutional, and community levels.

results.project_title: Harnessing PRX1 expressing cells for endogenous periodontal regeneration
results.phr_text:
In patients affected by periodontitis, after controlling the disease, periodontists and general dentists need to
perform regenerative procedures to re-establish the normal anatomy and function of the periodontium. However
current regenerative therapies are ineffective as they are unable to fully regenerate the missing periodontal
tissues. With the final goal of developing more effective periodontal regenerative therapies, this research
proposal aims at characterizing the periodontal stem cells and at identifying strategies to harness them to
endogenously sustain periodontal regeneration.

results.project_title: Mental Health Risk and Resilience among Latinx SGM Adolescents and their Parents
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This proposal utilizes a family-based approach to address how culturally-relevant family relationship dynamics
among Latinx sexual and gender minority (SGM) adolescents and their parents inform health inequalities. A new
parallel adolescent-report measure of Latinx parent acceptance will be developed to work with an existing parent-
report measure of Latinx parent acceptance of their SGM adolescents; this new measure – along with other key
indicators of general and SGM-specific family relationships and structural and social determinants of health will
be studied as predictors of family mental health. The new dyadic tool and intersectional approach will provide
novel information to develop culturally-relevant, family-based interventions to reduce health disparities among
Latinx SGM adolescent populations.

results.project_title: Using Geocoded Data and Virtual Neighborhood Assessments to Understand the Impact of Neighborhood Environment on Momentary Paranoid Ideation in Psychosis
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Understanding the social and environmental determinants of mental health is a key objective for current clinical
psychological research given the impact that such factors have on the emergence and maintenance of costly
mental health disorders such as psychosis spectrum disorders. The proposed study will utilize an innovative
multimethod approach combining census tract neighborhood databases, virtual neighborhood audits,
ecological momentary assessment, geographical information science methodology, and virtual neighborhood
visits by naïve raters to illuminate how neighborhood environmental factors contribute to momentary
experiences of paranoid ideation and to examine whether these environments play an independent role in
increasing paranoid ideation. Gaining understanding of how localized contextual factors contribute to
momentary paranoid ideation is vital to accurately assessing psychosis spectrum symptomatology in the
community and individually adapting community-based mental health treatments to maximize both short and
long-term benefits.

results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Research findings indicate that specialized cells in the kidney tubule are critical to fighting bacterial infections.
By examining the mechanisms these cells use to eliminate bacteria, we can gain insight on how kidney infections
happen as well as develop new non-antibiotic treatments.

results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The Underrepresented-Population-Drug-Target-Protein (UpDTP) database and population-specific in vitro
reagents (PQ-ivR) developed and characterized by Precision Quantomics Inc. hold the potential to transform

results.project_title: The role of the N-terminus of GATA1 in erythropoiesis
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
GATA1 is a gene that is essential for red blood cell development, and mutations in GATA1 cause a spectrum
of blood diseases in humans. In this proposal, we study the effect of one type of GATA1 mutations that lead to
the loss of the N-terminal domain. We seek to define the function of this domain in red blood cell development
and to understand how it controls metabolism and differentiation.

results.project_title: Pax8-Hnf4a co-regulation in ischemic kidney injury
results.phr_text: Injury to the kidneys due to a short-term loss of blood supply is a common problem affecting hospitalized patients, but it lacks any specific treatment. The goal of this project is to better understand how the genes that determine the ways kidney cells use energy are controlled because these processes make the kidney vulnerable to injury. This understanding may lead to ways to prevent and treat kidney injury.

results.project_title: Development of a Comprehensive Hen's Egg Model for Genotoxicity Testing
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Evaluating pharmaceuticals and various industrial chemicals for their capacity to cause DNA damage is a
crucial step in protecting human health due to their potential to cause cancer and contribute to other diseases.
As regulatory agencies shift away from the use of animals in risk assessment, toxicological risk assessment is
in need of a reliable non-animal model to evaluate chemicals for DNA damaging potential. We will develop,
optimize, and validate a comprehensive hen’s egg model for assessing chemicals for DNA damage potential,
while fulfilling upcoming regulatory guidelines.

results.project_title: Investigating the role of Lipocalin Prostaglandin D2 Synthase and its metabolite PGD2 in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) has emerged as the most prevalent chronic liver
disease with increasing incidence rates worldwide; but no FDA-approved treatments are available
currently. Absence of Lipocalin Prostaglandin D2 Synthase (L-PGDS) developed fatty liver
disease accompanied with insulin resistance and weight gain in mice; however, the precise role
of L-PGDS in NAFLD is unknown. Research in this SuRE First (R16) proposal will investigate the
molecular mechanisms of signaling by L-PGDS and its metabolite PGD2 that has potential for the
discovery of novel NAFLD therapeutic targets.

results.project_title: The role of phosphorylation in the cellular organization of the proteome
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This research will provide spatial and temporal knowledge on how phosphorylation regulates the function and
organization of proteins in the cell, which will allow devising approaches to control cellular functions and
phenotypes. This research will also provide mechanistic insight on deleterious protein variants. Collectively,
this research will be relevant in combating genetic diseases and diseases where signaling malfunctions,
including cancer, metabolic, neurological and infectious diseases.

results.project_title: Effects of wildfire smoke on respiratory antiviral defense responses
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Exposure to smoke emitted from wildfires has been linked to a variety of health effects, including increased risks
associated with respiratory viral infections, thus presenting a critical public health concern. Using human in vivo
and in vitro models, the studies in this application will provide a comprehensive characterization of antiviral
defense response changes associated with woodsmoke exposure in humans and link mechanistic understanding
of respiratory immune dysfunction to these exposures. This cross-disciplinary proposal brings together a diverse
skill set to study a unique interface between the chemistry of wildfire smoke and clinically important outcomes of
influenza infections.

results.project_title: Effect of hippocampal feedback projections on the function of the early olfactory system
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The proposed research will investigate the role of vCA1 feedback on neural representations of environment
and odors in the main olfactory bulb, a circuit critical to sensory perception and memory. Mice are one of the
major model organisms for studying olfaction, and many circuits principles are conserved across evolution,
making them critical to understanding neurodegenerative and neurological disorders like Alzheimer’s Disease,
Parkinson’s and COVID. This proposal will improve our understanding of the functional coupling between brain
regions involved in sensory perception and those involved in learning, emotion, and memory.

results.project_title: Rapid Diagnosis and Treatment Response Phenotyping of Immune Checkpoint Inhibitor-Associated Acute Interstitial Nephritis
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy leverages the body’s immune system to target cancer, but it can lead
to off-target side effects that present as acute interstitial nephritis in the kidneys. There are no non-invasive
biomarkers of ICI-induced acute interstitial nephritis, which poses significant diagnostic and therapeutic
challenges. We will recruit a longitudinal cohort of 400 participants receiving ICIs who develop acute kidney
injury to identify biomarkers and dysregulated pathways in acute tubulointerstitial nephritis to improve
diagnosis and treatment response phenotyping.

results.project_title: Molecular mechanism of eukaryotic chromosome replication
results.phr_text:
Project narrative
Each time a cell divides it must produce accurate copies of its chromosomes by replicating the chromosomal
DNA. This process is essential and defects in chromosome replication can lead to mutations, chromosomal
rearrangements and cancer. This project will generate novel assays and tools for the study of chromosome
replication in vitro and elucidate molecular mechanisms that ensure chromosome replication fidelity under
normal and replication stress conditions.

results.project_title: Bridging the Treatment Gap by Expanding Access to Care for People with Epilepsy in Kenya (BEACON)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Globally, epilepsy is highest in sub-Saharan Africa, and in Kenya, a vast majority of people with epilepsy do not
receive appropriate treatment (epilepsy treatment gap). We will conduct the first cluster-randomized trial in
western Kenya to assess the effectiveness of task sharing supported by the epilepsy medical records system
in improving access to and retention in care of people with epilepsy and thus epilepsy care outcomes. This
research will enhance epilepsy research and clinical capacity by implementing scalable and sustainable
strategies to reduce the epilepsy treatment gap in low-resource settings.

results.project_title: Validation of quantative method for thiamine detection in animal feed, tissue and plasma
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The proposed Thiamine HPLC-FLD quantification method will fill a diagnostic gap in the
laboratories of the FDA Vet-LIRN network by standardizing a method for accurate quantification
of thiamine, thiamine pyrophosphate(diphosphate), and thiamine monophosphate in animal
feeds, tissues, and blood. This standardized method will facilitate implementation at laboratories
with HPLC-FLD testing abilities, improving the availability of monitoring pet feeds to provide
early warnings for mis-formulations and create surge capacity in emergent cases that might
require significant feed recalls. The extension of this method into tissues and blood will allow
confirmation of thiamine deficiency in suspect cases, facilitating treatment of any affected
animals and providing evidence for any necessary related feed recalls.

results.project_title: Tau Mediates Microtubule and Mitochondrial Dynamics to Control Cellular Organization and Alveolar Epithelial Repair
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Degenerative lung diseases are adding significant burden to the health care in the United States. Currently there
are no effective treatments and lung transplantation remains the best resource to improve lung function and
survival. Understanding the genetic and cell biological mechanisms that initiate and promote disease
pathogenesis in the aged lungs will aid in discovery of novel treatments to block or reverse these diseases.

results.project_title: Analytical characterization and validation of blood-biomarkers for monitoring TBI evolution
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
This proposal will investigate 7 promising neurotrauma biomarkers to be practically adopted for use in multi-
institutional clinical studies in acute and subacute TBI, with rapid, reliable results. The goal of this study is to
develop reference materials which will allow laboratories the ability to report consistent biomarker results with
age-specific reference intervals throughout the lifespan that will allow discrimination from normal values. Finally,
we propose to develop preliminary information on how biomarker levels are affected by injury severity, whether
they can be used to monitor incipient secondary injury, and whether they have promise as prognostic biomarkers
of persistent post-concussive symptoms.

results.project_title: The role of Tie2 signaling in Aortic Valve Remodeling
results.phr_text:
Summary: We have identified a discrete stage of heart valve development that is critical for aortic valve
morphogenesis and have also discovered a unique cascade of endocardial signaling proteins that are essential
for normal valve formation prior to birth. Our goal is to understand how these signaling cascades within the
endocardium direct normal aortic valve development. As most congenital heart defects involve abnormalities of
heart valve formation, these studies will lay the foundation for understanding the etiology many congenital
heart diseases.

results.project_title: Pacific Northwest Center for Cryo-EM
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Oregon Health and Science University (OHSU) and the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) will
continue to operate a user-oriented, state-of-the-art national center for cryo-electron microscopy designated as
the Pacific Northwest Center for Cryo-EM (PNCC). The PNCC will enable users from diverse biomedical
disciplines in the effort of elucidating the structures of biological molecules and macromolecular complexes using
high-resolution cryo-EM, and it will bring new scientists into this field by providing education in the theory and
practice of this enabling technology to help build a diverse workforce in the applications of cryo-EM.

results.phr_text:

This proposal will use rAAV-delivered and CRISPR-mediated gene editing in airway progenitor cells to
permanently correct the defects in CFTR gene in cystic fibrosis patients. In addition, it will develop the next

results.project_title: Understanding the Role of EIF4A2 in Neurodevelopment
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Neurodevelopmental disorders are common, affecting 3% of the global population; these conditions include
global developmental delay/intellectual disability, epilepsy, and autism spectrum disorder and are collectively
associated with significant healthcare costs for the many children and families affected. Interneuronopathies
are becoming more widely recognized as an important cause of neurodevelopmental disorders, with Fragile X
and autism both associated with interneuron impairment. This K08 proposal will elucidate both the mechanism
and the timeline during which EIF4A2, a DEAD-box encoding gene and novel regulator of interneurons, alters
interneuron development, providing direction for future investigations of interneuron-targeted therapeutics.

2025, and 2026. The HGM is an annual international scientific conference focused on the human genome,
genomic medicine, and especially on education and bringing the benefits of new knowledge and understanding

results.project_title: Examining the influence of sociodemographic and medical factors on plasma p-tau217 performance in diverse communities
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE.
Blood-based biomarkers have the potential to transform diagnosis and clinical management of Alzheimer’s
disease in the community, but it is unclear how these biomarkers perform in diverse populations. We plan to
investigate the effects of various sociodemographic and medical factors on the performance of plasma p-
tau217, a promising new blood-based biomarker for Alzheimer’s disease. Results from this study will ultimately
contribute to improved early identification and screening for Alzheimer’s disease in communities that are
disproportionately affected by the disease.

results.project_title: The Personalized Remote Radiation Tracking Portable Organ Dosimetry Devise (PRRT PODD)
results.phr_text:
Narrative
The overall goal of this work is to improve outcomes for neuroendocrine tumor (NET) patients by fashioning cost
effective, patient friendly technology to enable 177Lu-DOTATATE treatment personalization based upon daily, at-
home measurements of the radioactivity in their organs at risk and tumors. We are developing compact, durable,
easily transportable technology that will enable treatment personalization while forgoing the need for serial visits
to imaging centers over 7 plus days for each treatment administration.

results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
To enable development of fast and accurate brain and human body modeling methods and their transition to
clinical practice via a dedicated computational conference on Brain and Human Body Modeling aligned with
NIMH mission.

results.project_title: The impact of targeting CD40-CD154 pathway in nonhuman primate vascularized composite allograft model
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Vascularized composite allografts (VCAs), which involve the transplantation of a combination of skin, muscle,
bone, nerves, offer immediate therapy for individuals who have suffered irreparable tissue damages or
deformities (i.e. face, hand etc.). However, VCAs are highly susceptible rejection and also requires life-long
immunosuppression which is often toxic to the patients. Therefore, this study aims to utilize a preclinical
nonhuman primate model to explore novel therapeutic strategies targeting CD40/CD154 signing pathway with
anti-CD154mAb. The ultimate objectives are to minimize VCA rejection, preserve protective immunity, promote
tolerance, and optimize patient health.

full_study_section.name: Genetic Variation and Evolution Study Section[GVE]

results.project_title: An Ancient Neural Enhancer that has Rapidly Evolved in the Human Lineage
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
A fundamental question in biology is - how did humans acquire their unique characteristics from their primate
ancestors? We have identified a non-coding element—a member of a class of DNA sequences called human
accelerated regions (HARs)—that our evidence indicates is a strong candidate to have generated human-
specific traits involving cognition during human evolution. Understanding HARs is relevant to NIH’s mission of
reducing illness and disability, as HARs are linked to neuro-developmental disorders such as schizophrenia and
autism.

results.project_title: Collaborative to understand impacts of early preventive interventions on suicide and overdose mortality using data harmonization methodology
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Our objective is to integrate and harmonize 29 randomized controlled trial datasets (N=42,509) of early
preventive interventions to examine whether they reduced risk for suicide, suicidal thoughts and behaviors, fatal
and nonfatal substance use disorder, opioid use disorder, accidents, and all-cause mortality.

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Large-scale integrated data analysis of lymphocyte receptor repertoires with workflows
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
High-throughput Adaptive Immune Receptor Repertoire sequencing (AIRR-seq) has become a fundamental
method for investigating B cell and T cell adaptive immune responses. We developed nf-core/airrflow (AIRRflow),
a high-throughput, scalable analysis workflow using the Immcantation Framework that facilitate AIRR-seq data
processing in high-performance clusters and cloud infrastructure. Through novel features that enable the
integrated analysis of large-scale AIRR-seq datasets and improve interoperability with public databases and
downstream analysis tools, we aim to make AIRRflow an even more useful tool for the infectious and immune-
mediated disease community.

full_study_section.name: Biobehavioral Regulation, Learning and Ethology Study Section[BRLE]

results.project_title: Molecular mechanisms underlying sub-thalamic influences on extinction learning
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE. Fear of trauma-associated stimuli even after they have ceased to be threats is a core
pathology of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) that results from being unable to learn that stimuli
previously linked to trauma are no longer dangerous (deficits in extinction learning). Of relevance to the
Strategic Objectives #1 and #3 of NIMH’s mission which are to “define mechanisms of complex behaviors
while striving for preventions and cures”, our proposal will shed light on how molecular mechanisms in sub-
thalamic neurons influence extinction learning. The proposed research is relevant to public health because our
results will provide a foundation from which future studies could identify core pathways underlying extinction
learning across the entire brain, eventually resulting in new pharmacotherapies to reduce the burden of
maladaptive fear associated with PTSD.

results.project_title: Unraveling the Role of p53 in Endothelium Homeostasis after Ionizing Radiation Exposure
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The current project is designed to study radiation-induced coronary heart disease (RICHD), a major concern in
cancer survivors receiving radiation therapy. With miniaturized human vessel tissues and novel mouse models,
I will map how radiation exposure dysregulates the vascular health over time and correlate molecular changes
to specific mutations in TP53 gene. The ultimate goal is to provide insights for the stratification of cancer patients
based on their genetic risk for RICHD to improve patient outcomes post-radiation therapy.

results.project_title: Immigration Policies, Dietary Acculturation, and Childhood Obesity.
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Policies that restrict immigrants’ access to health and other services can erode both mental and physical well-
being. We propose to conduct a novel data linkage to analyze how such policies and immigration enforcement
associate with measures of diet and obesity for children of Mexican immigrants using nationally-representative
data collected across 10+ years. Findings from this study will advance our understanding of the multiple levels
of influence that immigration policy climates can impact children of Mexican immigrants, and may in part explain
why this important and growing group faces a higher burden of obesity than their non-Hispanic White peers.

full_study_section.name: HIV Immunopathogenesis and Vaccine Development Study Section[HIVD]

results.project_title: Synergizing neutralization and non-neutralization antibody targets at the HIV/SIV viral spike apex
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Immunity to enveloped, RNA viruses that utilize a trimeric-protein-spike, Class I membrane-fusion cellular
invasion mechanism maps to host antibodies targeting the apex of the influenza and SARS-CoV-2 viral spike.
In this exploratory project, we will investigate whether equivalent antibody-targeted epitopes at the apex of the
HIV/SIV viral spike can mediate a similar level of protection from viral challenge, a level which has been
elusive for HIV vaccine candidates for nearly 40 years. This hypothesis will be tested by engineering a vaccine
containing only the two key spike-apical, antibody-targeted epitopes and testing it in a non-human primate
model of HIV/SIV infection.

results.project_title: Sequential Strategies to Reach and Reengage Individuals after Lapses from HIV Care in Zambia
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Lapses from HIV care are one of the most enduring challenges to HIV programs globally, and are associated
with high rates of viremia and overall morbidity and mortality. The proposed research seeks to identify person-
centered strategies using combinations of navigation and community-based medication delivery to both facilitate
return to HIV care as well as sustain long-term reengagement post-return among individuals with treatment
lapses in Zambia. This proposal advances a high priority research agenda to identify the most effective and
efficient strategies for improving reengagement in care, and will help maximize not only the public health impact
of HIV programs but will also advance strategies to improve care delivery for chronic diseases worldwide.

results.project_title: Identification of predictive biomarkers for severe acute leptospirosis and its long-term sequelae
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Leptospirosis is a significant global human health problem that causes fulminant liver
dysfunction, kidney failure, and severe pulmonary hemorrhage. Our long-term goal is to identify
predictive biomarkers for severe acute leptospirosis and its long-term sequelae.

results.project_title: Application of precision medicine to phototherapy: a stepped care approach to consolidate sleep and slow cognitive decline in older adults
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Consolidated sleep is crucial for older individuals' cognition, health, and well-being, but the fragmentation of
sleep and wake increases with age. This study will investigate underlying mechanisms contributing to sleep-
wake fragmentation and explore the utility of a novel intervention, afternoon phototherapy, to reduce the
consequences of sleep-wake fragmentation, including ameliorated cognition. Results from this project may lead
to an inexpensive or free scalable intervention with the potential to ameliorate cognitive decline and other
concomitants of fragmented sleep, delay institutionalization, and improve the quality of life in older individuals.

results.project_title: Culturally tailoring a mindfulness meditation mobile app to reduce psychological distress in African American adults
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
 The objective of this research is to culturally tailor a commercially available mindfulness-meditation mobile app
for African American (AA) adults and assess its feasibility. A User-Centered Design (UCD) approach will be used to co-
develop a culturally tailored app prototype and will be tested in a pilot RCT in AA adults with elevated levels of stress.
This proposal will advance our understanding of methods to culturally tailor commercially available mindfulness-
meditation apps which may, in the long-term, increase access to mental health care and reduce mental health disparities in
AA adults.
