results.project_title: Long-term effects of universal health insurance in developing countries: Evidence from Mexico
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative (3 sentences)
Public health insurance programs are being implemented across the globe, putting substantial pressure on
public finances, despite the fact that there is limited evidence on their causal impact in the long term. This
study will address this knowledge gap by utilizing the rollout of Seguro Popular, a nationwide program that
provides public health insurance to approximately half of Mexico’s population. By exploiting the panel nature
of the Mexican Family Life Survey, the first large-scale, nationally representative survey that has successfully
followed respondents across international borders, this project will merge detailed migration histories, rich
individual and household health and economic survey questions, and program rollout information to identify
and document the extent to which providing universal health insurance in a developing country can improve
fetal development, support child health, promote wellness over the life course, and ultimately, reduce existing
economic disparities through improved household finances, nutrition, and provision of public health resources.

results.project_title: A total school approach using safeguarding to address HIV-related stigma and discrimination in boarding schools in Zambia
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Physical, verbal and sexual abuse documented in boarding schools in Zambia are strongly linked to stigma
and discrimination and heighten HIV stigma experiences for those affected by HIV both at school and beyond;
given the impact of HIV-related stigma and discrimination on HIV-related outcomes, there is a compelling need
for HIV stigma reduction in boarding schools within a broader context of safeguarding to foster deeper
acceptance of HIV. This study seeks to adapt the ‘total facility approach’ to addressing HIV-related stigma and
discrimination in healthcare settings and pilot-test it in boarding school communities, including individuals living
with HIV and individuals who are not. Intervention packages will be co-created with school stakeholders and
will target learners, teachers, staff, and staff from nearby healthcare facilities to create a community of safety
characterized by reduced experiences of HIV-related stigma and abuse so as to lower barriers to engagement
in care within the boarding school setting and equip young people with skills to better navigate HIV.

results.project_title: Kabawil: Adapting an Intervention to Reduce Intersectional Stigmas among Indigenous Sexual Minority Men and Traditional Healers in Mesoamerica
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Indigenous GBM in Guatemala experience intersectional stigmas, including racial discrimination, which increase
vulnerability to HIV, and other health problems. This study will test the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary
efficacy on HIV and stigma outcomes of a culturally and contextually adapted stigma-reduction intervention for
Indigenous GBM and traditional healers in Guatemala. Findings will inform the design of a large effectiveness
implementation trial to establish KABAWIL as a model for reducing intersectional stigmas and improve HIV
prevention and care for indigenous people in high-stigma, culturally conservative, resource-constrained
communities throughout the Americas.

results.project_title: Neonatal, Lactation, and Child Health Outcomes Following RSV Vaccination During Pregnancy
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
To date, there are limited data on the safety of Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) vaccination during
pregnancy. The goals of this study are to assess the effect of RSV vaccination during pregnancy on lactation
and on newborn and child health. The results of the study will complement ongoing vaccine safety surveillance
and will help patients and their clinicians make more informed decisions about RSV vaccination during
pregnancy.

results.project_title: Task-Shifting: Brief Interpersonal Psychotherapy by Youth Mentors for Latinx Youth Suicide Prevention
results.phr_text:
Latinx youth in the United States are at increased risk of poor mental health, sadness, hopelessness, and
suicide ideation, and despite need, access to mental health care is limited. Globally, task-shifting (shifting
specialized mental health interventions from clinical settings to community settings by training non-mental
health providers) is a promising approach to reducing depression symptoms and increasing access to care, yet
it has not been fully investigated as a suicide prevention strategy in the United States. This proposal will
investigate the feasibility and acceptability of an adapted evidence-based mental health intervention, task-
shifted to trusted adults (mentors), to target key risk factors for passive suicide ideation among Latinx youth in
community centers as an upstream approach to suicide (before suicide behaviors onset).

results.project_title: Defining Sjögren’s pathogenesis by endotype: maladaptive responses of endogenous salivary gland mesenchymal stromal cells
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
The proposed research focuses on endotypes of Sjögren's disease (SjD), a common systemic autoimmune
disease characterized by oral and ocular dryness and marked morbidity, with no available disease modifying
treatments. Defining the maladaptive response of endogenous salivary gland mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs)
by endotype will impact human health by providing foundational insights into SjD pathogenesis and serve as the
first step toward two new potential and innovative therapies in SjD, 1) salivary gland MSC-targeted therapy, and
2) JAK inhibition for SjD treatment. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission pertaining to
reducing illness and disability.

results.project_title: Narrowing the mechanistic gap for anterior prefrontal cortex function
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Patients with mental health conditions that affect the functioning of the front of the brain – anterior lateral
prefrontal cortex – can experience difficulties with high-level abilities such as reasoning, planning, multi-
tasking, judging the accuracy of their memories, and decision-making. We seek to gain mechanistic insights
regarding the function and detailed anatomy of this region in humans, through a combination of tightly
controlled cognitive tasks and powerful magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) methods. We expect that this
theoretically novel and methodologically sophisticated research will advance our understanding of the function
of a brain region that is critical for day-to-day life and work in our complex modern world.

results.project_title: Investigation of Cardiac Arrhythmias in TANGO2 Disorder
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
TANGO2 Deficiency Disorder (TDD) is a genetic condition associated with high mortality rates due to recalcitrant
ventricular arrhythmias, unresponsive to standard antiarrhythmic therapy. Promising new data demonstrates B-
vitamin supplementation can prevent and potentially treat arrhythmias in TDD, yet how B-vitamins impact the
pathophysiology of TANGO2 Deficiency Disorder and the mechanism driving lethal ventricular arrhythmias
remains unclear. This study proposes to assess B9, a component of B-vitamins, by combining clinical patient
data, a mouse model, and patient-derived, induced pluripotent stem cells to investigate B9’s effectiveness in
treating arrhythmias and to elucidate the mechanism of TDD-related arrhythmia development in this disease.

results.project_title: Advancing novel therapeutics and translational science to close the survivorship gap in pediatric, adolescent and young adult (AYA) lymphoma
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE:
Sharon Castellino, MD, MSc is an experienced and productive Clinical Scientist whose goal is to
improve survival for children, adolescents, and young adults (AYAs) with blood cancers and
lymphoma. The R50 award will support her leadership in the Children’s Oncology Group to bring
curative therapies and accelerate the timeline for trials with novel agents to AYA with Hodgkin
lymphoma. At the institutional level, as the leader of the pediatric leukemia and lymphoma
program, the R50 support will enable her to create an AYA trial enrollment infrastructure and
minority populations otherwise under-represented on NCI clinical trials in Georgia.

results.project_title: Genetic and genomic influences on human milk composition and impacts on infant health
results.phr_text:
Breastfeeding provides health benefits for infants and mothers, but the specific effects of the numerous
components of human milk are largely unknown. This project represents a comprehensive genetic and
genomic analysis of human milk composition, which will improve our understanding of the genes and biological
pathways underlying milk composition and enabling future studies of the health consequences of variation in
milk components. This study also leverages multi-omic data integration to assess the effects of milk
composition on the infant gut microbiome and infant immune development.

results.project_title: Spore germination pathway in Clostridioides difficile and its pharmacological intervention
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Clostridioides difficile infections (CDIs) are difficult to treat, resulting in 11,500 deaths in the United States
every year. A challenge in treating CDI is the production of spores that germinate to vegetative cells, which
cause the infection. Recurrence of infection occurs in 25% of patients. There are no antibiotics for the
treatment of recurrent CDI. CDI is the deadliest of the five bacterial urgent threats. Understanding the process
of spore germination is key to elucidating the basis for recurrent CDI. If spore germination could be prevented,
the nefarious cycles of CDI can be interrupted. We disclose the discovery of a new class of antibiotics (the
oxadiazoles) that kill C. difficile in the growing phase (vegetative cells). We also have found that certain
oxadiazoles also inhibit spore germination. Our goals are to elucidate the spore-germination pathway, to show
that inhibition of spore germination can stop recurrence of infection, and to discover new and more effective
oxadiazoles that inhibit spore germination.

results.project_title: Development of a hamster model for hepatitis B virus infection
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection affects more than 296 million people globally and approximately
820,000 people die each year from HBV infection and related complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular
carcinoma (HCC). One of the major impediments in developing a cure for HBV is the lack of immunocompetent
animal models permissive to HBV infection. The goal of this project is to develop a novel hamster model to
support the development of new therapies to cure HBV infection.

results.project_title: Remote monitoring using commercially available activity trackers and computer vision provides a holistic, low-cost assessment of Parkinson’s disease symptoms
results.phr_text:
The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the high and increasing prevalence of
neurodegenerative causes of dementia including Parkinson’s disease dementia, significant barriers to
definitive neurologist care in underserved, rural communities, and the potential of remote monitoring to
ameliorate these obstacles and improve quality-of-life. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the
NIA’s mission of to reduce the burden of neurodegenerative disease, including dementia, and extend the
healthy, active years of life.

full_study_section.name: Neural Basis of Psychopathology, Addictions and Sleep Disorders Study Section[NPAS]

results.project_title: Direct characterization and correction of circuit level computational deficits underlying compulsivity in humans
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Compulsively persisting with fixed ways of behaving even when negative consequences mount is a central
component of many psychiatric disorders. For the first time in psychiatry, is it now possible to longitudinally
record from neural circuits during a patient’s treatment course, and to do so while administering sophisticated
tests of cognition. Directly studying the neural circuits of individuals undergoing treatment for compulsivity may
reveal the biological basis for the kind of rigid thinking and behavior present in a wide range of devastating mental
disorders.

results.project_title: Adaptation and evaluation of an intersectional stigma reduction intervention to increase HIV care engagement among women who use drugs
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This proposed study addresses a highly relevant public health question: how to reduce individual-level stigma
around HIV and drug use that may undermine people’s ability to seek and remain engaged in HIV care. This
study will take place in Ukraine, which continues to experience one of the highest HIV rates in Europe. The
information gained through this study has the potential to inform the development of policies and practices to
help people living with HIV maintain access to and engaged in HIV care.

results.project_title: Defining multifunctional roles for proteins in development and disease
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Understanding the multifunctional roles of proteins is essential for designing therapeutic strategies to treat
genetic causes of disease, yet our knowledge of these secondary roles for many proteins remains incomplete.
We will elucidate the multifunctional roles of a protein involved in cancer, microcephaly, and infertility, while also
using our expertise in high resolution 3D X-Ray imaging and artificial intelligence to establish an experimental
workflow that will accelerate the discovery of multifunctional protein roles in model organisms such as Drosophila
melanogaster and Xenopus laevis.

results.project_title: Improving Shared Decision Making in Early use of Neurotechnologies Across Different Disease Stages
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The development of novel neurotechnologies has not only expanded the range of treatment options available to
patients, but also increased the complexity around ethical decision-making, in particular, when these interventions
are considered earlier in the disease progression. This study will provide in-depth new knowledge regarding
neuroethical issues around shared-decision making and decisional needs of patients and clinicians associated with the
early use of neurotechnology, and address these issues by developing and testing a patient-centered decision aid
(PtDA) for advanced neurotechnology. Responding to the BRAIN Initiative imperatives, our resulting PtDA will
enhance shared decision-making and guide ethical choices surrounding the early use of neurotechnology.

results.project_title: Home-based Digital Technologies: A Translational Approach to Support Aging-in-Place for Rural African-Americans with Alzheimer’s Disease and their Care Partners
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The proposed research will project will assess the usability, acceptability, and feasibility of remote monitoring
technologies for supporting aging-in-place for rural low-income, African-Americans and their care partners. Study
findings will contribute notably to the further development of innovative, connected, multi-sensor remote monitoring
systems that can facilitate the activities of daily living of African Americans living with ADRD. Combining this
technological support system with other services may increase the likelihood that African Americans living with
ADRD can age-in-place while reducing caregiver burden.

results.project_title: Neural Mechanisms of Anticholinergic Burden in Mid- to Late-Life Schizophrenia Spectrum Illness
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project proposes to conduct a study of the functional, neural, and molecular impacts of deprescription of
anticholinergic medications in mid- to late-life patients with schizophrenia. The information gathered through this
project is of considerable public health significance in that it is expected to yield new insights on how to improve
outcomes in the later phases of schizophrenia, identify novel neural and molecular treatment targets to promote
long-term recovery, and ultimately reduce the significant public health burden of this disabling psychiatric
condition.

results.project_title: Metals Exposure, Dementia, and Longitudinal Trajectories of Cognition, Functioning, and Neuropsychiatric Symptoms
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project aims to ameliorate dementia burden through identifying modifiable environmental risk factors. The
project will utilize neurological examination and clinical diagnosis from the National Alzheimer’s Coordinating
Center (NACC) Study and repository plasma samples from the National Centralized Repository for Alzheimer’s
Disease and Related Dementias (NCRAD), to determine the metal concentrations, and examine associations
of these metals with dementia risk and longitudinal changes in related outcomes. In addition, the concepts
learned through this grant and the career development pursued by the investigator, will be readily applicable to
his future research focusing on the intersection of environmental epidemiology and dementia.

results.project_title: The role of vascular failure and biomechanical stress in the development, progression and healing of osteochondritis dissecans lesions
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Ostechondritis dissecans (OCD) is a developmental orthopaedic disease affecting children and young adults. It
is characterized by formation of osteochondral flaps or fragments within joints which cause pain and disability
and predispose to early onset osteoarthritis. In the current proposal, our objective is to establish how
alterations in the vascular supply to the epiphyseal growth cartilage, along with biomechanical trauma,
contribute to the development, progression, and healing of OCD lesions.

results.project_title: Blood Trauma, Vascular Remodeling, and Vasoregulation with Total Body Continuous Versus Pulsatile Artificial Circulation
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Blood trauma, arterial remodeling, and dysfunctional vasoregulation during non-pulsatile artificial circulation
contribute to patient adverse events. The BiVACOR, a first-of-its-kind, impeller-based total artificial heart with
the ability to generate continuous (non-pulsatile) or pulsatile outflow, will be used to investigate in vivo effects of
non-pulsatile versus pulsatile flow. Findings will inform development of artificial pulsatility algorithms that mimic
physiologic pulsatility in order to reduce adverse events in patients.

results.project_title: Natural Phenolic Compounds against Oral Candidiasis (OC)
results.phr_text:
Candida spp. is the most common cause of invasive fungal infections among individuals living with HIV and
oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) is the most frequent opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals. We
propose the evaluation of hydrogels loaded with two natural compounds with activity against Candida spp.
These studies have the potential to develop local treatments that will deliver natural compounds to prevent and
treat oral candidiasis.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Molecular and bioenergetic dynamics of in utero chronic hypoxia on placenta and brain
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This proposal hypothesizes that chronic hypoxia leads to metabolic and epigenetic disruption in the developing
brain, which contributes to long-term functional dysfunction. Using advanced imaging and multi-omic studies,
we propose two aims: to test if there is a correlation between placental metabolic dysfunction and brain
metabolic dysfunction from chronic hypoxia and if cortical metabolic dysfunction from chronic hypoxia
correlates with transcriptomic and epigenetic disruption in the developing cortex. The findings from this study
could provide a framework for understanding the complex multi-system dynamics that impact the effect of
prenatal insults on neurodevelopment.

results.project_title: Development of a salivary gland Sjögren's syndrome tissue chip platform
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
We will develop an in vitro salivary gland Sjögren’s syndrome (SS) tissue chip (SSTC) platform that will enable
mechanistic studies of the disease pathogenesis which is predominately diagnosed in older woman. The
proposed studies will investigate the effect of endocrine disrupting chemicals exposure on salivary gland function
which may be important in the pathogenesis. The SSTC will enable future high throughput drug discovery
studies. Currently there are no disease modifying drugs to treat SS patients.

results.project_title: Identifying placental tissue tropism and cellular mechanisms of Ebola Virus transmission from mother to fetus in pregnancy
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
In the setting of pregnancy, infection with Ebola Virus (EBOV) resulting in the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) leads
to nearly 100% loss of the fetus or neonate, with or without the additional death of the mother. This proposal
seeks to evaluate the tropism of EBOV within placental tissues, transmission of EBOV across the placenta to
the fetus, as well as to define the role of cell surface receptors that may influence the tissues infected or timing
of placental infection and transmission. The data from this project will ultimately help us understand the barrier
role of the placenta during viral infections, but also will shed light on that pathogenesis of EVD in pregnancy in
order to develop therapeutics or interventions to improve outcomes for mothers and their children.

results.project_title: Cluster Randomized controlled trial of Using PrEP, Doing it for Ourselves [UPDOs] Protective Styles: A salon-based intervention to improve PrEP uptake among Black cis-gender women."
results.phr_text:
We propose an effectiveness-implementation type I hybrid study to test an intervention, Using PrEP, Doing it
for Ourselves (UPDOs) Protective Styles, and its effectiveness to improve PrEP uptake among Black
cisgender women using a cluster-randomized control trial and examining implementation determinants of
UPDOs as a real-world intervention that can be scaled across the Southern US. Project activities will be
delivered by an interdisciplinary team – advised by an external advisory panel and established community
advisory council, and implemented across six counties in North Carolina, a southern region where HIV
incidence is high— Cumberland, Durham, Forsyth, Guilford, Mecklenburg, and Wake counties. At the
conclusion of the funded project, we will have rigorously evaluated the intervention ready for scale-up across
the US south that has potential to significantly advance EHE goals, specifically for Black cisgender women, an
invisible population in HIV prevention.

results.project_title: Developing Interventions for Protecting HIV-Exposed Uninfected Infants against Severe Infections
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Developing Interventions for The Protection of HIV-Exposed Uninfected Infants against Severe Infections
HIV-exposed uninfected infants (HEU) have higher risk of infections, hospitalizations, and death than HIV-
unexposed infants (HU) during the first 1-2 years of life. By comparing HEU with HU, we will determine the
characteristics of the gut bacteria that may contribute to the poor health outcomes of HEU and how they relate
to the immune system, blood metabolites, and bacteria in the infant respiratory tract. We will also test 2 dietary
interventions that may alter the relative frequency of bacteria in the gut of HEU.

results.project_title: Transcriptional Outputs of the Necroptotic Pathway
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
 The pathway of “necroptosis” refers to a form of programmed cell death associated with inflammation,
but how activation of this pathway affects immune responses in vivo is not fully understood. The work
proposed here will use a combination of engineered effector proteins and models of viral infection to study the
immune changes induced by necroptosis.

results.project_title: Washington University ACCERT center
results.phr_text:
Overall Project Narrative
The overarching goal of the Washington University Advancing Cancer Control Equity Research through
Transformative Solutions Center (WashU-ACCERT) is to advance cancer control equity in the St. Louis region
through community engaged multilevel research interventions that address the impact of social determinants of
health on adverse cancer control outcomes. Our innovative strategies to promote community partnerships and
implement responsive research will position WashU-ACCERT to meaningfully engage with the local
communities and implement interventions that will build capacity among scholars and community partners, and
benefit our communities, health systems, providers, and people at greater risk of cancer.

results.project_title: New Jersey Biomed-Bridge (NJBB) Scholars Program: Supporting Central NJ Community College Students in their Transition to Biomedical Research Pathways at The College of New Jersey
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The College of New Jersey in collaboration with Mercer County Community College and
Brookdale Community college proposes an engaging, research-intensive experience in order to
develop a diverse and skilled local talent pipeline for the biomedical sciences, an area of rapid
growth in the New Jersey region. Our program initiatives will prepare trainees to gain the
knowledge, skills, and identity needed for successful biomedical careers, which will contribute to
expanding the public health workforce.

results.project_title: Modeling non-additive genetic mechanisms for complex traits
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Many clinically and economically important traits are complex, i.e., they are under the influence
of many underlying genes. Understanding how variation in genotype leads to variation in
phenotype is a difficult problem as genes often interact with each other, such that knowing the
effects of individual genes is not sufficient to predict how they will combine. This project will
develop new computational tools for learning from large genotype-phenotype data for humans
and model organisms in order to improve our ability to predict phenotype for new genotypes and
detect novel gene interactions.

full_study_section.name: Neural Basis of Psychopathology, Addictions and Sleep Disorders Study Section[NPAS]

results.project_title: Adolescent brain maturation and psychopathology
results.phr_text:
Public Health Significance
Understanding the alterations in neuropil and connectivity pattern in multiple layers of networks involving
structural covariance, white matter and functional connectomes is critical to elucidate adolescent brain
maturation. Alterations in these processe may elucidate potential mechanisms underlying nearly 50% of
psychiatric illnesses beginning during adolescence which are increasing in the last 2 decades especially among
adolescents from lower socioeconomic status (SES) with its adverse consequences on school performance,
family relationships, substance use and criminal justice system. This is more onerous for persons who have a
first-degree relative with schizophrenia where our proposal could highlight neural pathways as targets for
developing new treatment approaches and develop better predictive models to potentially mitigate the risk and
develop preventative efforts.

results.project_title: Identifying, Validating, and Characterizing Biological Subtypes of PsychiatricDisorders Using a Novel Computational Framework
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Newly available large-scale human neurobiological data offer an unprecedented opportunity for biologically-
grounded, data-driven stratification of psychiatric disorders—a major public health concern. The goal of this
proposal is to develop and validate a novel computational framework for the identification, validation, and
characterization of biological subtypes of psychiatric disorders using large-scale human brain imaging,
phenotypic, and transcriptomic data, and to apply the framework to the study of autism. The framework
developed here can be extended to examine other psychiatric disorders and can enable the development of
more effective and precise diagnostic and treatment strategies for the disorders.

results.project_title: Demographic and Health Effects of Climate Exposures Across the Life Course
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Anthropogenic climate change is expected to have significant consequences for the health and wellbeing of
affected populations, especially in lower- and middle-income settings. We use demographic and health surveys
from Indonesia and Mexico, combined with high-resolution climate records, to measure the effects of climate
exposures during early childhood and adolescence on the fertility, health, migration, and socioeconomic
statuses of working-age adults.

results.project_title: Role of PGM-3 and SPE-56 in fertilization and egg activation
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Understanding the necessary genetic components is important for deciphering the causes of
infertility and designing new contraceptives. I have identified several new genes involved in
fertilization in the Caenorhabditis elegans model system. This work will establish new genes
involved in fertilization on the oocyte surface.

results.project_title: Active HCV diagnosis to support prevention of HCC in LMICs
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Active Viral Hepatitis Diagnostics to Support Prevention/Treatment of HCC
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a highly lethal cancer with over 80% of the cases occurring
in low resource settings. Chronic hepatitis C (HCV) infection is major risk factor for HCC
development. The goal of this proposal is to develop and validate a diagnostic test for HCV
infections for use in low-and-middle-income-countries to identify patients for treatment thus
reducing their risk of developing HCC.

results.project_title: Regulation of Androgen Receptor by NXTAR Long non-coding RNA in Prostate Cancer and its Therapeutic Implications
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Although, the importance of AR-regulating long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) has long been
speculated, the direct negative regulation of AR (and AR-V7) transcription by lncRNA has not yet
been reported. Serendipitously, we identified a lncRNA, NXTAR (LOC105373241), located
convergently to the AR gene that is repressed in human prostate tumors and cell lines, and
discovered that its reinstatement promotes binding upstream of the AR promoter, causing
significant loss of expression of AR and its splice variant AR-V7.

results.project_title: Role of LAM-specific TREM1 in leukemogenesis
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Cancer progression is heavily influenced by supportive cells in the tumor microenvironment. The project aims to
investigate the previously unknown connection between TREM1-positive leukemia-associated macrophages
(LAMs) and leukemogenesis. If successfully completed, the project would uncover novel roles of TREM1 in LAM-
leukemia interaction during leukemia development, and yield valuable information on whether targeting TREM1
or its signaling components may be therapeutically useful in the prevention and treatment of leukemia.

results.project_title: Development of a Direct Diagnostic Test for Infectious and Congenital Syphilis
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Syphilis affects millions of people worldwide, and its global rates are on the rise. Current diagnostic tests
for syphilis are non-ideal, and having a better diagnostic test would lead to more infections being
detected and a decreased incidence of disease. In the current proposal we will extend the performance
testing of our promising, newly developed syphilis diagnostic platform that is highly specific for
detection of infectious and congenital syphilis and can be translated to a point-of-care test format, to
aid in achieving the goal of decreasing the incidence of syphilis in the US and worldwide.

results.project_title: Transitional Care for Skilled Nursing Facility Patients with Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias and their Caregivers: a Cluster Randomized Trial.
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Every year, 400,000 million skilled nursing facility (SNF) patients with Alzheimer’s disease and related
dementias (ADRD) transfer from SNFs to home and other destinations. Following these transitions, (1) patients
with ADRD experience high rates of preventable dementia symptoms and re-hospitalization, with rates highest
for Black patients and (2) caregivers of people with ADRD experience high levels of strain and psychological
harm. To improve these outcomes and promote health equity, we propose a cluster randomized trial of
Connect-Home ADRD, a transitional care intervention for persons with ADRD and their caregivers during care
transitions from SNFs to home, assisted living, and long term care.

results.project_title: Post-transcriptional control of gene expression by the mTORC1 signaling pathway
results.phr_text:
Project narrative
The mTOR signaling pathway is a conserved regulator of cell growth that is linked to
common human diseases, including cancer, diabetes, and neurologic disorders. A
central mTOR function is to control the translation of mRNAs. This proposal seeks to
discover how these mechanisms target specific classes of mRNAs and understand their
function in vivo.

results.project_title: The molecular epidemiology of enteropathogenic (EPEC) and enteroaggregative (EAEC) Escherichia coli among adult patients in Seattle
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Multiplex molecular panels have facilitated the diagnosis of patients presenting with acute
diarrhea and enabled the rapid detection of diarrheagenic E. coli which were previously
overlooked by conventional clinical laboratory methods. Enteropathogenic (EPEC) and
enteroaggregative (EAEC) E. coli are now among the most common pathogens detected by these
panels. Yet, although both are established as causes of diarrhea in infants living in developing
countries, little is known about their clinical relevance in adult patients living in high-income
countries. The proposed research will examine the clinical features, epidemiology, and
antimicrobial resistance of EPEC/EAEC infections in U.S. adults to better understand their
importance and to inform strategies for their prevention and management.

results.project_title: Cooperation of Co-Amplified Genes in Hepatocellular Carcinoma
results.phr_text:
PROJECT 2: NARRATIVE
The proposed studies will interrogate the mechanism by which two co-amplified genes, MYC and TAF2,
cooperate to promote hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development and progression and evaluate therapeutic
efficacy of combined inhibition of MYC and TAF2 along with immune checkpoint inhibitors in endogenous
mouse models of HCC.

results.project_title: Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Core (BBC)
results.phr_text:
CORE 3 - BIOSTATISTICS AND BIOINFORMATICS CORE: NARRATIVE
The Biostatistics and Bioinformatics Core (Core 3) will provide dedicated expertise and cost-efficient support in
biostatistics, bioinformatics, and research data management for the ELEVATE Program Project Grant P01
application. This core is critical for the ELEVATE program to achieve its overarching research goals of 1)
interrogating molecular mechanisms regulating non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)-hepatocellular carcinoma
(HCC) and development of novel combinatorial treatment approaches based on the identified molecular
abnormalities, 2) evaluating approaches that improve the efficacy of approved immunotherapy using an
authentic NASH-HCC mouse model, and 3) developing novel approaches that engage the immune system to
counteract HCC.

results.project_title: Open-Source Software Tools for Rapid Radiofrequency Coil Modeling and Simulation in MRI
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
 The goal of this project is to develop an open-source electromagnetic simulation suite for radiofrequency
coil design and modeling in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Novel computational electromagnetics methods
will be developed and combined with optimization routines and tensor decompositions to allow efﬁcient simula-
tions of realistic MRI setups for brain and body imaging at any operating frequency. The proposed suite will be
used for the rational design, optimization, assessment, and construction of a novel coil array for prostate
imaging at 7T MRI.

results.project_title: Revealing New Therapeutic Opportunities for Kidney Glomerular Diseases by Elucidating the Mechanobiological Functions of Novel Cytoskeletal Structures in Podocytes
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The goals of this project are to better understand the pathogenesis of proteinuric kidney disease so that
targeted new treatments can be designed. Podocyte shape and adhesion to the glomerular basement
membrane are critical for maintaining the integrity of the glomerular filtration barrier, which prevents the loss of
blood proteins into the urine. The current proposal aims to gain a deeper mechanistic understanding of the
components and dynamics of the podocyte's cytoskeleton so that we can better understand how podocytes
maintain their unique shape and adhesion within the glomerulus.

results.project_title: Non-ISGylated HIV proteins are sorted to hepatic exosomes to activate liver fibrosi
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
HIV-induced liver injury is the second-leading cause of mortality in HIV-infected patients. Rapid progression
of liver fibrosis is frequently associated with alcohol, but the mechanisms are not clear yet. Here, we are
examining how ethanol metabolism by suppressing HIV protein ISGylation in hepatocytes, sorts these
non-ISGylated proteins to exosomes to induce the pro-fibrotic activation of hepatic stellate cells
after engulfment of exosomes, thereby promoting liver fibrosis development.

results.project_title: Elucidating circuit mechanisms of brain rhythms in the aging brain
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Brain rhythms coordinate the activities of millions of neurons for complex cognitive functions, such as learning
and memory. We will dissect the circuit mechanisms that generate and route the theta rhythm (4-12 Hz) – one
specific brain rhythm critical for memory processing. Our systematic functional mapping of theta-related circuits
connecting the hypothalamus and the hippocampus will provide insights into how aging affects brain rhythm
coordination and have translational implications for improving memory function in Alzheimer’s disease.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Paradigm Shift in the Management of Patients with Previously Untreated Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia through NCI-sponsored Clinical Trials
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The National Cancer Clinical Trials Network (NCTN)-led clinical trials have transformed the landscape of the
frontline management of patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) in the past decade. With an
increased understanding of the role of measurable residual disease (MRD) in the contemporary management
of CLL, the next generation of NCTN-led clinical trials will use MRD to guide the optimal duration and intensity
of therapy. This proposal highlights my goals of helping to develop, implement, and complete these state-of-
the-art NCTN-led clinical trials that will lead to a paradigm shift in the frontline management of CLL.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: RSMI HEALS
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Twenty six million people in the United States are limited English proficient, meaning that they report speaking
English less than “very well”; this population is vulnerable to poor cancer outcomes, in part as a result of
communication problems. Medical interpretating services are mandated by laws and regulations, but access is
limited by expense and logistical factors, which may potentially be overcome with technology-enabled
solutions. We will compare three types of technology-enabled human-delivered interpreting solutions in a study
with limited English proficient breast cancer patients who speak Spanish or Mandarin (1. “UN-style”
simultaneous interpretation versus 2. audio consecutive, and 3. video consecutive interpretation) to determine
which type has the lowest error rate, has the best patient outcomes, and is the most efficient, and what factors
contribute to or impede the implementation of these solutions; we will also explore the potential of artificial
intelligence to deliver automated “UN-style” simultaneous medical interpreting, which could be a scalable and
inexpensive future solution to providing medical interpreting services to people with cancer.

results.project_title: Studying Neuronal Proteostasis During Aging and AD with Novel Protein Tagging Tools
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Dysregulated proteostasis, particularly protein turnover, is a hallmark of brain aging and Alzheimer’s Disease
(AD), but many details remain to be understood about protein turnover due to previous technical limitations. In
this proposal, leveraging new protein-tagging methodologies, l aim to (1) identify aberrations in neuronal
protein turnover dynamics and their functional consequences during aging and AD and (2) understand a
neuron-intrinsic regulator of protein turnover (autophagy/lysosome) and a neuron-extrinsic regulator of
neuronal protein turnover (microglia) during aging and AD. The findings from my studies will substantially
increase our basic biological understanding of neuronal proteostasis/protein turnover during brain aging and
AD, and ultimately identify new targets to promote resilience to brain aging and AD.

results.project_title: DeepTOBIDx: deep learning-enhanced multimodal diagnostic breast imaging
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Integrating tumor function-orientated imaging technology such as near-infrared tomographic optical breast
imaging (TOBI) with predominantly structure-oriented clinical diagnostic imaging modalities has demonstrated
considerable potential in improving the specificity of breast cancer diagnoses. This project seeks to address
the limitation of optical breast imaging in characterizing small lesions by utilizing a deep learning-based image
reconstruction framework accompanied by a dual-modal integration with diagnostic x-ray mammography under
spot compression (DeepTOBIDx) to achieve marked improvement in optical image resolution, as well as in
quantification accuracy and speed. Once validated in the proposed reader study, this work will offer
radiologists with actionable lesion functional information to effectively avoid unnecessary biopsies during the
diagnostic workup.

results.project_title: Bile Acid-Mediated Signaling In HCC
results.phr_text:
PROJECT 1: NARRATIVE
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), especially its aggressive form, nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH),
is a leading cause of cirrhosis and hepatocellular cancer (HCC). The I148M variant of the patatin-like
phospholipase A-3 (PNPLA3) gene is one of the best-described genetic determinants of HCC risk across
multiple etiologies of chronic liver disease, including NAFLD; however, the mechanisms by which PNPLA3I148M
leads to HCC are poorly understood. The focus of this application is to examine the role of the PNPLA3I148M
variant in promoting HCC development and further identify the underlying mechanisms for developing potential
therapies.

results.project_title: A Novel Target in The Tumor Myeloid Compartment for Hepatocellular Carcinoma
results.phr_text:
PROJECT 3: NARRATIVE
This project addresses a novel innate pattern recognition receptor (i.e., SRA/CD204) in the tumor
microenvironment that can impede immune surveillance and promote therapeutic resistance of hepatocellular
carcinoma (HCC). By gaining an in-depth understanding of the underlying mechanism of SRA function in these
processes and successfully testing blocking antibodies targeting this receptor in preclinical models, we can
significantly advance the current treatment options for HCC.

results.project_title: Designer Cytokine Therapy of Hepatocellular Carcinoma
results.phr_text:
PROJECT 4: NARRATIVE
Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is associated with significant morbidity without a currently effective therapy.
We describe a novel molecular reagent, a Fusion Superkine, and an innovative delivery approach permitting
safe and efficient targeted systemic administration of therapeutic agents, including viruses, that employs
microbubbles and focused ultrasound to release therapeutic agents in the liver. The novel reagent and
innovative strategies we have developed, including an effective combinatorial regimen, have the capacity to
transform and enhance the clinical management of HCC.

results.project_title: LF-TIMING: Large-scale label-free profiling of cell-cell interactions
results.phr_text:
8. Project Narrative
Advances in computer vision have provided new capabilities for rapid, functional analysis of single cells. We
have used these AI-enabled techniques to profile cells used for immunotherapy to understand which therapies
perform best and why. In this project, we will create a commercially scalable prototype integrated software
system capable of the same analysis on cells that are not fluorescently labelled (label-free). This software will
be based on new AI models trained on millions of images of cells and optimized for fast, high-throughput single
cell analysis by any customer without computational science backgrounds.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Precision Tumor Sampling of Melanoma Using Laser Microbiopsy
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Current methods for tissue biopsy methods are prohibitively painful and thus not recommended for
comprehensive melanoma screening in adult individuals, resulting in significant missed cancers. Noninvasive
methods that sample only the top layer of the skin for molecular (non-histological) analyses are not widely used
for melanoma diagnosis, likely due to collection of biomarkers from superficial skin rather than from
melanocytes that are deeper under the skin. In this proposal, we propose development of a new laser
microbiopsy that will allow tissue extraction beyond the epidermis, where melanocytes are located, with less
pain compared to traditional biopsies. This minimally-invasive laser microbiopsy can be used for histological
and molecular diagnostics, which will hopefully allow for comprehensive melanoma screening to reduce the
disease burden.

results.project_title: The Young Empowered Scientists for ContinUed Research Engagement (YES for CURE) Program at the Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center (DF/HCC)
results.phr_text:
YES for CURE Project Narrative
 Increasing the participation and retention of underrepresented minorities (URMs) in cancer-related STEM
fields is critical for eliminating cancer disparities and improving cancer outcomes in the United States. Early
engagement in scientific research has been linked to enrollment and retention of students in STEM degree
programs and careers. The Young Empowered Scientists for ContinUed Research Engagement (YES for CURE)
Program, in the Dana-Farber/Harvard Cancer Center, is a multi-year holistic and comprehensive cancer and
cancer disparities research experience and education program for URM high school and undergraduate students
in the Greater Boston area.

results.project_title: IRACDA at Texas A&M University
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This proposal seeks to leverage the research and teaching strengths of TAMU, a large R1 institution and
PVAMU, a partner R2 institution, and the premier HBCU in Texas, to train a diverse group of skilled scientists to
excel at both teaching and research using a successful research-intensive community mentoring model. It is
expected that this IRACDA-trained cadre of scientist-educators will partner with undergraduate institutions to
increase science literacy and interest among historically underserved student populations and serve to recruit a
new generation of scientists into biomedical and health research.

results.project_title: Novel gene regulatory networks underlying two specialized modes of craniofacial development in a new model system of pupfishes
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The spatial and temporal coordination of gene transcription is crucial to ensure that fundamental biological
processes, such as embryonic development, are successfully orchestrated, thereby allowing for the normal
functioning of an organism. By leveraging an endemic group of pupfishes from the Bahamas, which exhibit
extremely divergent craniofacial morphologies, I propose a multi-omics approach to unravel and functionally test
the gene networks and regulatory regions of the genome controlling changes in gene expression underlying their
naturally divergent craniofacial development.

results.project_title: Multi-scale, multi-modal imaging assessment of trajectories of cognitive impairment in Multiple Sclerosis
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
This research project will use micro- and macro-scale anatomical and physiological brain imaging techniques to
identify biological mechanisms of cognitive decline in people with multiple sclerosis (MS). We will explore the
link between neuronal integrity and alterations in brain networks across different stages of MS. This research
will provide insight into novel therapeutic targets to treat cognitive impairment in MS and, in addition, tools that
can be used by clinicians to predict patients at risk for cognitive decline.

results.project_title: Translational development of new agents alone and in combination to combat Gram-negative pathogens important in Ventilator- Associated Bacterial Pneumonia: Leveraging the Gram-negative toolbox that is
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative:
The pathogens Acinetobacter baumannii and Klebsiella pneumoniae, particularly when carbapenem-resistant,
cause significant morbidity and mortality for patients. They have recently acquired a number of novel
resistance mechanisms that render many of our most active antimicrobials less useful. We will employ the
latest mechanistic, translational research approaches via a highly integrated set of three Projects and three
Cores to design novel therapeutic regimens to restore our ability to successfully treat these bacterial
‘superbugs’.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

results.project_title: Efficient red-to-NIR photo-uncaging and applications in therapy
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The high spatial and temporal resolution of light makes optical regulation using the light-responsive group an
appealing approach for cellular events controlling, which has broad applications in cell biology, neurobiology,
and biomedicine. Due to the fundamentally importance of light-responsive groups and the shortage of tools with
effective red-to-near infrared sensitivity, we will try to develop an efficient system using rigidified structures based
on weak covalent bond, and apply them in drug delivery for cancer treatment. Given the wide usage of these
optical tools in basic science and biomedical application, these techniques would allow timed delivery of targeted
bioactive molecules in deep tissue.

results.project_title: Functional Consequences of Early Childhood Otitis Media
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Otitis media is the second most common reason children go to the doctor. This project will
provide evidence of long-lasting functional listening deficits in children resulting from otitis media after
the pathology has resolved. This will have a significant theoretical and translational impact on the
early identification and intervention of pediatric hearing loss resulting from otitis media.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Antibody bound bacteria during HPV infection and cervical dysplasia
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Despite the clear association between high-risk human papillomavirus (HR-HPV) and cervical cancer, there is a
lack of understanding why some women clear HPV infection while others suffer from chronic infection that leads
to cervical dysplasia and cancer. There is emerging evidence that the vaginal microbiome plays an important
role in this process however the mechanisms linking vaginal bacteria with host responses, specifically antibody
responses, to HPV infection and cervical neoplasia progression are underexplored. This project will study the
role of antibody bound and unbound bacteria and associated bacterial functions in women with different HPV
infection status and cervical dysplasia pathology.

results.project_title: ExpLoiting thErapeutic VulnerAbilities in hepaTocEllular carcinoma (ELEVATE)
results.phr_text:
OVERALL: NARRATIVE
The P01 proposal ExpLoiting thErapeutic VulnerAbilities in hepaTocEllular carcinoma (ELEVATE) aims
to interrogate molecular mechanism of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) arising from obesity-induced non-
alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and evaluate a variety of combinatorial treatment options, based on
underlying molecular abnormalities, using an authentic NASH-HCC mouse model. The studies will generate
translationally relevant data from preclinical models having the potential to significantly impact the
management of HCC patients, facilitating prolonged survival.

results.project_title: Mouse Model and Pathological Analysis Core
results.phr_text:
CORE 2 - MOUSE MODELS AND PATHOLOGICAL ANALYSIS CORE: NARRATIVE
Core 2 will support the research of the ELEVATE program projects by 1) generating and providing
experimental mice of four different hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) models, 2) providing access to human
HCC tumor specimens and patient blood samples, and 3) providing pathological analysis of both human and
mouse tumor specimens.

results.project_title: Ambient Temperature Molecular Detection of Sexually Transmitted Infections from Vaginal Swabs on a Power-free Device
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
When left untreated, STIs such as Chlamydia (infection with C. trachomatis) and Gonorrhea (infection with N.
gonorrhoeae) can result in long term adverse health effects that disproportionally affect women, including
increasing risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, infertility, and pregnancy complications, however, barriers such
as lack of privacy and accessibility to clinical settings, high screening technology price points, and stigma lead
women to get screened for STIs less frequently than they would prefer. The proposed study aims to develop a
low-cost, PCR-level-accuracy diagnostic device with an easy-to use and read interface for the detection of C.
trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae which can be utilized by the lay consumer at the point of need (at-home) rather
than at the point-of-care (in-clinic), creating a more accessible and equitable technology to screen for STIs in
women.

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

results.project_title: Shape-Adaptive Cochlear Implant Electrode Arrays
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Cochlear implants (CIs) have been one of the most prevailing neural prostheses, yet a significant number of CI
recipients still experience only poor to moderate speech understanding. Current CIs have trouble achieving
simultaneous atraumatic insertion and effective placement of intracochlear electrodes, and we are tackling these
challenges by using a novel approach using shape-memory polymers (SMPs) as a mechanically-adaptive
element for CI electrode arrays. This project will validate that the SMP-inlaid CI electrode arrays will lead to more
reliable cochlear implantation alongside favorable electrode placement.

results.project_title: Targeting the tumor microenvironment with engineered CD4+ T cells
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
This project will develop a new strategy to engineer “helper” CD4+ T cells that orchestrate the function of other
immune cells in tumors to allow these cells to better activate immune responses. We will then apply this
strategy to tumor targeting CD4 T cells obtained from patient tumors with the goal of inducing anti-tumor
immune responses and clinical benefit in patients. We hope this project will lead to a clinical trial of this
approach in patients with melanoma and other solid tumors who have failed existing therapies.

results.project_title: Assessing and Promoting Vaginal Health for Transgender Men on Testosterone: A Mixed Methods Study
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE:
Transgender men (TGM) taking testosterone as gender-affirming hormone therapy often experience changes
affecting their vaginal health such as thinning of the vaginal epithelium, inflammation, and unfavorable shifts in
the vaginal microbiota which can lead to bacterial vaginosis. Such changes, in conjunction with sexual behaviors
of TGM, are associated with negative sexual health outcomes such as increased risk of HIV and sexually
transmitted infection (STI) acquisition and symptoms such as irritation, discharge, and dyspareunia. The
proposed research in this K23 proposal aims to utilize community-engaged mixed methods research to develop
culturally relevant clinical tools that can be used by healthcare providers to collect both vaginal history data (via
a vaginal health survey instrument) and clinical specimen data (via self-collected vaginal swabs) to better assess
and manage vaginal symptoms that TGM experience and, ultimately, improve their sexual health outcomes.

results.project_title: Circuit, cellular, and molecular plasticity in hypothalamic microcircuits underlying flexible infant-directed behavior
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Receiving parental care is essential for appropriate physical, cognitive, and emotional development in infants
across species, and failure to care for an infant predisposes an individual to neurodevelopmental and
psychiatric disorders. Caregiving behavior is mediated by neural circuits that promote parental bonding with
infants. In this grant, we propose to study the neurobiology underlying the expression of pro- and anti-parental
behavior in males and females across behavioral states at the circuit, cellular, synaptic, and molecular levels.

results.project_title: A clinician-in-the-loop smart environment to support management of chronic health conditions
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 To meet the needs of the growing adult population who manage chronic health conditions, we propose to
enhance our clinician-in-the-loop smart environment to prevent and treat condition exacerbations. We will
design conformal prediction methods to forecast future exacerbations. Additionally, we will analyze the impact
of external events like the COVID-19 pandemic and frequent wildfires on behavior, socialization, environment,
and health state. For all of our machine learning tasks, we will train language models from nurse summaries to
provide text explanations of observed behavior and machine learning predictions.

CORE 1 – ADMINISTRATIVE CORE: NARRATIVE
Core 1 will provide critical support to ensure the seamless integration and effective planning and management
of the ELEVATE program. The core will oversee the overall research direction and fiscal management,
ensuring accountability and compliance with all institutional, state, and federal requirements for grants
management and resource sharing, to ensure that the program goals are met.

results.project_title: Novel Designed Multi-Ligands as Tocolytics for Dysregulated Myometrial Pathways in the Treatment of Preterm Labor
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Preterm labor leads to preterm delivery of an underdeveloped fetus in 50% of cases. There are no FDA-
approved medications available to prevent preterm delivery. The research planned in this application will
employ tissues from pregnant women and mice to explore the therapeutic potential of novel ‘designed
multi-ligands’ and combination tocolytics to delay preterm birth. Our research Aims are designed to address
myopathic dysregulation of the uterus to advance a ‘designed multi-ligand’ and combination drug strategy
to prevent preterm birth.

results.project_title: TMJ Disc Regeneration
results.phr_text:
This proposal describes work in which a biologic scaffold composed of mammalian extracellular
matrix will be used as an inductive scaffold for the in vivo generation of the temporomandibular
joint disc. This inductive template will stimulate the rapid endogenous formation of a
fibrocartilaginous disc that closely mimics the structure, composition and function of native disc
material. The proposal will provide the first safe treatment following disc removal, improving
outcomes for patients by preventing joint damage from long term bone-on-bone articulation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: MusiQuest STEAM: interactive digital media for K-5 STEM education integrating audio and music
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
MusiQuest STEAM is an interactive digital media program that combines hands-on
STEM technical components with guided lessons that address Next Generation Science
Standards for grades K-5. By incorporating audio (music, sound, hearing, etc.) in every
lesson, MusiQuest STEAM will present artistic connections to STEM that help build
students' knowledge of key concepts, and inspire their interest in learning more about
biomedical science and related research. The long-term impact on public health of
improved outcomes in STEM education is greater participation in health-related
professions, especially from groups that are currently underrepresented in these fields.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Role of the CD43 Receptor on Effector CD8+ T Cells During Acute Allograft Rejection
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Transplantation is a curative therapy for organ failure in many different diseases. Although acute rejection
mediated by T cells is a significant contributor to the premature failure of grafted organs, there is limited
understanding of how CD8+ T cells differentiate into effector populations after grafting. Greater understanding of
the signaling pathways controlling the effector CD8+ T cells that reject allografts will lead to more targeted
therapeutic strategies to improve graft survival.

results.project_title: Thermostable measles fusion glycoprotein as a new vaccine strategy
results.phr_text:
Measles (MeV) causes a severe transient immunosuppression in healthy individuals and can cause
lethal encephalitis in immunocompromised people. The current live vaccine virus is effective but
requires low temperature for transport and cannot be used in severely immune compromised individuals.
Recent advances in our MeV research are ready to be applied to developing a new vaccine strategy
that will lead to a thermostable subunit vaccine that will also be safe for the severely immune compromised
individuals.

results.project_title: The Role of Coxiella Effector Proteins in Infection and Disease
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative:
Intracellular pathogens represent a serious threat to human health, and to devise
strategies to combat infections by these microbes a more detailed understanding of how
they modulate host cell function is needed. This project is focused on identifying
molecular mechanisms that allow the intracellular pathogen Coxiella burnetii to manipulate
the function of host proteins, which include innate immune sensors that activate pathways
of host defense against intracellular pathogens.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: Factors Shaping the Genomic Spectrum of Structural Variants
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Double strand breaks (DSBs) are a type of DNA damage that is relevant to congenital diseases such as Ataxia
telangiectasia, Li Fraumeni syndrome, and Bloom syndrome, as well as cancer and infertility. Incorrect repair of
DSBs result in a type of mutation called structural variants (SVs). I will study the impact of mutations in DSB
repair genes on the types of SVs in human genomes, which will result in better understanding of mechanisms
of DSB repair, and how defects in this repair shape the genome and affect human disease.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Understanding the pathogenesis of classic Hodgkin lymphoma in persons living with HIV through conventional and spatial transcriptomics
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The risk of developing classic Hodgkin lymphoma has increased in persons living with HIV whose HIV is well-
controlled by combination anti-retroviral treatment. Our proposal investigates how benign and classic Hodgkin
lymphoma lymph node samples, with respect to RNA and protein expression in the non-malignant cells in the
tissue samples, differ from those in people without HIV. Our proposed study will eventually help in reducing the
risk of developing classic Hodgkin lymphoma in persons living with HIV.

results.project_title: Regenerative and Rehabilitation Strategies to Reduce Inflammation Following Volumetric Muscle Loss Injury
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
There are no effective surgical strategies for the repair of volumetric muscle loss (VML) injuries. A nonsurgical
strategy capable of restoring the muscle function that is lost to VML injury could improve the quality of life, enable
a return to work, and ease the burdens associated with activities of daily living for thousands of people each
year.

results.project_title: Exploring Mechanisms Linking Maternal Childhood Adversity to Adolescent Psychopathology: The Role of Early Childhood Deprivation and Threat
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Relevance to Public Health
The goals of this study are to examine pathways that maternal childhood abuse may impact the
development of her offspring from infancy to adolescence. Identifying risk and resilience factors
in offspring of abuse survivors will provide critical evidence for developing interventions that may
mitigate adverse outcomes across two generations.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

results.project_title: Chimera-BONCAT: A novel in vivo model for in-depth characterization of the human microglial response to alcohol
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 This project will establish and characterize a novel animal model used to investigate how alcohol affects brain
function through the neuroimmune response (specifically through microglia, which are the resident immune cell
of the brain). We aim to engraft genetically engineered human microglia derived from stem cells into the mouse
brain, allowing us to selectively enrich the molecular signature of only human microglia from the mouse brain
after the mice have been exposed to alcohol. Because we are studying the human microglial response in a living
animal, we anticipate the results will have higher translational relevance in order to further our understanding of
the negative consequences of alcohol use disorder in the human brain.

results.project_title: Risk, Resilience, and Recovery: A Longitudinal Mixed-Method Study Examining the Role of Peer Relationships in Pediatric Pain
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: There is a remarkable increase in the incidence of chronic pain during the
transition from early to middle adolescence, a developmental period that is also characterized by the
heightened significance and salience of peer relationships and experiences on and offline. Although peer
relationship difficulties are commonly observed in youth with chronic pain, whether these difficulties are a
cause, correlate, or consequence of pediatric chronic pain is unknown. The long-term goal of this research
program is to identify specific peer relationship processes (e.g., traditional and cyber-victimization, social
support, and social connectedness) that influence pain persistence, exacerbation, and recovery in a cohort of
youth at-risk for chronic pain, such that more developmentally appropriate and effective prevention and
intervention programs can be created.

results.project_title: The development of a GMP eDHFR vector to monitor investigational CAR T cell therapies
results.phr_text:
Narrative
This STTR phase 1 proposal lays the groundwork and supportive evidence for an easily transferable GMP-
compliant viral vector that can be used to monitor chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapies in human
patients. We recently developed the underlying technology that uses E. coli dihydrofolate reductase (eDHFR), a
small bacterial protein, that can act as a positron emission tomography (PET) imaging tag when paired with a
radiolabeled drug, fluorine-18 trimethoprim ([18F]-FTMP). Once enabled, this platform will substantially impact
our collective understanding of why a cell therapy product is successful or fails on an individual patient level
using non-invasive imaging.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: Policy and implementation context of an unconditional cash transfer program to address homelessness and improve HIV service uptake among marginalized youth in the United States
results.phr_text:
This K01 Mentored Research Scientist Development Award seeks to investigate the intersections of U.S.
housing and HIV policies, while refining and measuring the implementation of an unconditional direct cash
transfer intervention to address homelessness and promote HIV service engagement among lesbian, gay,
bisexual, transgender, and queer or questioning (LGBTQ) youth. The proposed training plan will build on PI
Rao’s experience in implementation research and in working directly with community partners and provide her
with the necessary skills and experience to execute the aims, including 1) methods to describe and analyze
health policies, 2) qualitative and mixed-methods approaches, and 3) content expertise in guaranteed income
and unconditional cash transfers in the United States. Over the five years of the award and through a
combination of mentor-specific and Scientific Advisory Committee Meetings, coursework and other didactic
training, experiential learning, research group meetings, and national and international scientific meetings, as
well as the execution of the proposed aims, PI Rao will be well-positioned to submit a hybrid implementation-
effectiveness R01 and pursue an independent research career.

results.project_title: Host-virus interactions in hantavirus glycoprotein assembly
results.phr_text:
Hantaviruses (e.g., the rodent-borne Sin Nombre virus and Andes virus) are bunyaviruses that
cause severe human disease. No vaccines and treatments are available to prevent or treat
infections caused by these agents. Here, we plan to study how these viruses hijack human
proteins and pathways to multiply and cause disease.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: Characterizing Latino Caregiver Engagement in Early Intervention Services for Autism
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Active caregiver involvement is a key feature of state-of-the-science early evidence-based interventions (EBIs)
for autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and is federally mandated in publicly-funded early intervention services.
Latinx children are increasingly being diagnosed with ASD at younger ages, yet experience disparities in
service access and quality which may extend to disparities in caregiver engagement in services. The present
study seeks to characterize patterns and determinants of Latinx caregiver engagement in ASD early
intervention services as a means of informing culturally- and linguistically-responsive engagement tools.

results.project_title: Targeted antibiotic therapy for Shigella among children in low-resource settings
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This study will characterize the poor outcomes of Shigella diarrhea that can be prevented by appropriate
antibiotic treatment and evaluate strategies to identify Shigella at the point-of-care to target therapy. The results
from the study will define the value of targeted treatment interventions for Shigella and optimize their
implementation. Targeted treatment of Shigella may reduce morbidity and mortality from Shigella diarrhea
among children in low-resource settings while reducing antibiotic use for diarrhea overall, limiting antimicrobial
resistance.
