results.project_title: Renal acid ceramidase-S1P pathway in salt-sensitive hypertension
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative: The high salt diet stimulates the production of sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) in the kidneys
to increase the excretion of extra sodium load. Acid ceramidase is the key enzyme to produce S1P and inhibited
in mice with high blood pressure. Enhancing the function of acid ceramidase can be a new therapeutic strategy
for the treatment of salt-sensitive high blood pressure.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Assessment of a recently developed boron-based HIF inhibitor as a prospective therapy for renal cell carcinoma (RCC)
results.phr_text:
The VHL tumor suppressor protein (pVHL) is often inactivated in clear cell Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC),
leading to continuous activation of the hypoxia-inducible-factor (HIF) pathway. Our proposed research aims to
assess the potential of honokiol and its analogs, which act as HIF pathway inhibitors, as a promising
therapeutic option for RCC treatment.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

results.project_title: Promoting Access to Payment Pathways for Emerging Molecular Diagnostics
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE.
Molecular diagnostics (MDx) can provide personalized care and improve patient outcomes; however,
disparities in payment for MDx create barriers that delay or prevent patients from accessing these diagnostic
tests. The proposed project uses innovative mixed methods to address key gaps in our understanding of MDx
payment disparities and identify strategies to promote access to MDx payment pathways. Results will lay the
groundwork for developing policy and practice interventions that guide equitable MDx implementation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: PRIME-KS
results.phr_text:
PROGRAM NARRATIVE
The Precision Imaging to Evaluate Kaposi Sarcoma (PRIME-KS) study addresses the urgent need for precision
in Kaposi Sarcoma monitoring among people living with HIV in Low and Middle Income Countries. SkinScan3D
offers an efficient, low-cost, and accessible solution to make monitoring less burdensome and more accurate for
patients and providers. This transformative technology will advance health equity globally.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Investigation of the serine protease Masp1 as a novel regulator of Bmp signaling during early embryonic development.
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
During early development, patterning of the embryo into separate domains is essential to
ensure the correct size and placement of subsequent tissue formation; indeed, disruption of this
process can lead to malformations of structures such as the craniofacial bones in human
patients. Multiple members of the TGF signaling pathway, including BMP, are essential for
patterning events. Here, we seek to determine the molecular function of the Masp1 protein in
contributing to patterning of the embryonic ectoderm through intersection with BMP signaling
with implications for our understanding of Masp1- associated developmental disorders.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

results.project_title: Electrical Field Guided TMS and Constraint Induced Language Therapy to TreatPost-Stroke Aphasia in the Subacute Stage
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS), sometimes in conjunction with Speech-Language Therapy, has been
demonstrated to improve language function in subjects with chronic aphasia. We will use electrical field
modeling to optimize TMS stimulation intensity in a double-blind study of continuous Theta Burst Stimulation
combined with modified Constraint Induced Language Therapy as compared to sham stimulation and modified
Constraint Induced Language Therapy in subjects with subacute aphasia. Additional aims are to identify
anatomic, behavioral and genetic predictors of response to treatment and to identify the mechanisms
underlying the beneficial effect of using network neuroscience imaging techniques.

organization.org_name: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Single cell multi-omics approaches in identifying driving cells and genes in pediatric MODS patients requiring ECMO support
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Multiple organ dysfunction syndromes (MODS) frequently occur in pediatric patients and severe MODS patients
needed Veno-Arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation support (ECMO) (label as ECMO patients) as a
palliating maneuver to recover their cardiopulmonary function. The major knowledge gap exists regarding the
cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying MODS deterioration for their advanced life support. The proposed
work will provide a comprehensive overview of cellular and molecular mechanism associated with deterioration
of MODS patients who may require ECMO support, which will be applicable for early diagnostic purposes.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Research Study Section[AIDS]

results.project_title: Influence of the Cervicovaginal Phageome on Health and Disease in Women Living with HIV.
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The female reproductive tract (FRT) microbiome consists of the bacterial microbiome, which can protect against
pre-term birth, bacterial vaginosis and sexually transmitted infections including HIV, and the viral microbiome,
which includes bacteriophages who, as natural predators of bacteria, may serve to regulate bacterial populations.
Our prior work showed the FRT bacteriophages form communities which corresponded with FRT diseases;
however, the mechanisms behind bacteriophage contribution to regulating FRT bacterial populations is largely
undetermined. Using a unique longitudinal cohort comprised of US women living with HIV and AIDS compared
to healthy controls, we will investigate the FRT bacteriophage communities over time, the impact of AIDS and
antiretroviral therapy on FRT bacteriophages and bacteria, and identify bacteriophage species and genes that
predict shifts to pathogenic FRT bacterial microbiomes, which may lead to novel preventative strategies and
phage-based therapeutics for FRT diseases, thereby improving women’s reproductive health.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: Psychophysical distillation of pure pain by nociceptive-specific heating
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Quantitative sensory testing (QST) and brain neuroimaging can both give important mechanistic insight into
chronic pain, but they could be improved by a technique that can stimulate nociceptors in isolation. Our lab has
developed a procedure for nociceptive-specific heating (NoSH) stimulation with no interference from innocuous
warm fibers. Nociceptive sensitivity will be measured in patients with fibromyalgia, a nociplastic pain condition,
and compared with data from pain-free controls, which may constitute a novel biomarker for use in other
mechanistic studies and clinical trials.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Biochemistry and Biophysics of Membranes Study Section[BBM]

results.project_title: In vitro and in silico investigations of changes in bacterial cell membrane dynamics due to polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) modifications
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The overall goal of this study is to investigate the impact of exogenous polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) on
bacterial membrane lipid homeostasis using in vitro and in silico approaches. We will explore the value of
exogenous PUFAs to Vibrio cholerae by characterizing the various structural modifications to membrane
phospholipids and determining how incorporation of these molecules influences bacterial permeability and
antimicrobial resistance. Ultimately, PUFAs may influence bacteria in a manner that affects their susceptibility
to antibiotic treatment, thus introducing another avenue for prevention and therapeutic intervention of diseases
caused by antibiotic sensitive and resistant pathogens.

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Exploration of D-Glucose and D-Mannose Metabolism to Target arenaviruses
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Arenaviruses are the causative agents of several viral hemorrhagic fevers; however, there are very limited
countermeasures against arenavirus infections, such as vaccines or antiviral drugs, leading to consideration of
global threats of pandemics. By targeting the viral glycans with sugar analogs we propose to develop a novel
way to treat arenavirus infections. In this project, we will develop the antiviral compounds usable as pan-
arenavirus therapy.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

results.project_title: Molecular Mechanisms of Clarin-1 and Clarin-2 function in mechanosensory hair cells
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Hearing loss is a major health problem that is frequently of genetic origin and commonly disrupts the development
and function of hair bundles of cochlear hair cells. We propose here to study several genes linked to genetic
forms of hearing loss that affect hair bundle development and function. We propose to elucidate the molecular
function of these genes and the pathophysiological processes associated with mutations in these genes that
cause hearing loss.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Library of Medicine

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Library of Medicine

results.project_title: Automated methods for standardization and enhancement of metadata in biomedical databases
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Biomedical datasets relevant to fundamental biology and human health are increasingly deposited in
centralized databases, enabling opportunities to train powerful machine learning models and perform
large-scale meta-analyses. Unfortunately, poor metadata in biomedical databases is currently a barrier to these
opportunities and thus there is a critical need for metadata curation. We will develop machine learning
methodologies for automated standardization and enhancement of biomedical metadata, allowing the
information contained within centralized biomedical databases to be used to the fullest extent possible.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

full_study_section.name: Surgery, Anesthesiology and Trauma Study Section[SAT]

results.project_title: DELTA ECMO ABI study (Assessing Acute Brain Injury after Rapid Reduction of PaCO2 upon ECMO Cannulation using Portable MRI and Biomarkers)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE …
When a person experiences heart and lung failure, he/she may require a life-saving treatment called
Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO). ECMO is accomplished by hooking up the patient to a machine
that functions like an extra set of heart and lungs, thus allowing the patient to recover their own heart and lung
function while being supported by an ECMO machine. Unfortunately, ECMO support often is associated with
brain injury leading to major disability or death. Our work will investigate the cause of this brain injury and
ultimately, if we are correct, help avoid or decrease it. Using an innovative brain imaging system called “portable
MRI” that can be performed at the patient’s bedside, as well as blood tests that can detect early on ongoing brain
insults, we will examine whether rapid and large reductions of carbon dioxide levels in the blood contribute to
ECMO-related brain injury.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Understanding Schizophrenia Risk Mechanisms Via Multimodal Analysis of Patient-derived Neurons and 3D Cortical Organoids and Correlation with Clinical and Cognitive Phenotypes
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Schizophrenia is a common and debilitating mental illness with relatively unknown etiology or pathophysiology.
We are proposing to identify pathophysiology by studying neurons derived from schizophrenia patient and control
induced pluripotent stem cells. Electrophysiology, cell biology, imaging, and molecular analyses will be applied
to these models to discover pathophysiology associated with specific clinical and cognitive symptomatology
unique to each individual patient with the goal of developing new therapeutic treatments.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Targeting proton-sensing GPR68 as a ferroptosis-based therapy for glioblastoma
results.phr_text:
Glioblastoma (GBM) aggressively spreads to surrounding brain tissue, often preventing surgical resection;
approved therapy works in only 30% of patients. Our results with genetic and pharmacological GPR68
knockdown suggest GPR68 is critical for GBM survival and treatment resistance, and this Phase I project is
focused on selecting a lead GPR68 inhibitor and establishing proof-of-concept that GPR68 is a therapeutically
relevant and tractable target. Successful completion of this project will move us closer to developing a new
therapy that could finally make a significant shift in GBM patient survival.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

full_study_section.name: Cardiovascular and Respiratory Diseases Study Section[CRD]

results.project_title: Air Pollution and Mortality Risk in Veterans with Chronic Respiratory Disease: Assessing the Role of Individual and Place-Based Risk Factors
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This proposal will assess acute air pollution mortality risk for individuals diagnosed with chronic respiratory
diseases; a high-vulnerability group for environmental exposures. Using a patient data architecture built from
clinical records, environmental conditions, and place-based characteristics of U.S. Veterans across a 20-year
period, we will unpack the individual risk factors and neighborhood inequities that drive air pollution mortality
risk in at-risk populations. Our findings will provide powerful insight into environmental risk for individuals with
respiratory disease and inform regulatory policy and behavioral interventions to reduce health burdens in this
population.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Coinfections and HIV Associated Cancers Study Section[HCAC]

results.project_title: Short-course rifapentine for TB prevention for all: clinical  pharmacology matters
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
People with HIV (PWHIV), young children, and pregnant persons are the populations at highest risk for
tuberculosis (TB) and TB-related morbidity and mortality, so provision of safe, effective TB preventive treatment
(TPT) is of high importance in these groups. In ASTERoiD, a Phase 3 randomized clinical trial, the
Tuberculosis Trials Consortium (TBTC) is assessing an ultra-short (6 week) course of a single drug,
rifapentine, aka “6wP,” for TPT in a large, diverse, international population of people at risk for TB. We propose
to add clinical pharmacology (measurement of drug concentrations) to ASTERoiD so that we can confirm the
right dosing of TB and HIV medicines for key priority populations (PWHIV, pregnant persons, and young
children)(which will facilitate their safe inclusion in the trial), verify that PK targets are being met (and
understand who is at risk for high or low drug concentrations), and evaluate relationships between drug
concentrations and key treatment outcomes (like safety and tolerability).

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Molecular Virology, Cell Biology, and Drug Development Study Section[HVCD]

results.project_title: Identification of HIV Rev-Rev interaction inhibitors by a high throughput, small molecule, cell-free screen
results.phr_text:
Narrative
 Although there are many anti-HIV medications in use, none target Rev, an essential viral protein
needed to export certain forms of the viral RNA that are then translated into proteins. A critical property of Rev
is its ability to bind to itself. Here we propose to use a previously developed cell-free assay to test ~125,000
drugs for inhibition of this property of Rev, hoping to identify at least a handful that have the qualities of interest
and merit further testing.

full_study_section.name: HIV Comorbidities and Clinical Studies Study Section[HCCS]

results.project_title: Long-term clinical and immunologic consequences of inflammation in perinatal HIV
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
With antiretroviral treatment (ART), children living with perinatal HIV achieve viral suppression, but inflammation
persists, and may lead to early onset cardiovascular, metabolic and neurocognitive disorders. The goal of this
study is to determine the durability of inflammation in persons with perinatal HIV after prolonged ART, its
pathogenesis and the clinical consequences of sustained inflammation in a 10 year follow up study of the
Pediatric Immune Activation cohort. Understanding long-term outcomes for the 2.7 million children living with
HIV globally is of important public health relevance in order to develop early screening biomarkers and
preventative interventions so they can thrive as adults.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Identifying and addressing bias in depression and anxiety quality measures
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Existing and proposed mental health quality measures may be biased against health systems, facilities, and
clinicians serving more Black and Hispanic patients, measuring the patients they serve rather than the quality
of care they provide. This research will use detailed records data from five large health systems to evaluate
potential biases in existing and proposed measures and evaluate alternatives to reduce biases.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Development of a natural language processing (NLP) based therapist tool for culturally responsive care
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Black, Indigenous, People of Color (BIPOC) and Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer
(LGBTQ+) communities experience disparities in the quality of mental health care. There are no feasible,
scalable tools to date that provide feedback surrounding culturally responsive care. The purpose of the current
study is to develop a natural language processing-based feedback tool to improve culturally responsive care
among therapists.

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Social Sciences and Population Studies B Study Section[SSPB]

results.project_title: Investigating the impact of COVID-19 pandemic child care closures on developmental outcomes of young children in low-income families
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Using a quasi-natural experiment approach with unique data, this research will contribute
fundamental knowledge about the medium- and potential long-term effects of the COVID-19
pandemic and childcare services disruption on the developmental progress of vulnerable and at-
risk children. Child care services may be instrumental to timely identification of developmental
delays, therefore findings of the study will provide essential evidence about these impacts and
the mechanisms behind them that can inform and alert health care providers and child care and
early education policy makers dealing with the consequences of this crisis. Our results will also
speak to the broader issue of the consequences of structural inequalities and lack of family
support for our children’s developmental outcomes, and can serve as guidelines for policies and
health initiatives targeted at vulnerable children and their families.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

full_study_section.name: Neurological, Mental and Behavioral Health Study Section[NMBH]

results.project_title: Psychosis in Ancestrally Diverse Settings (PADS)
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
African diaspora communities and other underrepresented populations have been poorly
represented in large scale genetic and epidemiological research on serious mental illnesses
(SMI), and yet these populations have the largest disparities in health care and outcomes. This
study builds on a prior study of untreated psychoses in Nigeria and Trinidad, newly adding a
cohort of patients receiving inpatient psychiatric care, and featuring a philanthropically-
supported whole-genome sequencing aim. Comparative clinical and genomic analyses with
data for US veterans and civilians with linked electronic health records, and with other diverse
populations in Africa and globally will inform how biological and non-biological factors influence
clinical presentation and health outcomes among individuals with psychotic illness.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Deciphering the role of METTL3 in Mammalian Placenta Development and Maintenance Across Pregnancy
results.phr_text:
Relevance to Public Health:
Defect in trophoblast lineage development results in early pregnancy loss or leads to pregnancies that are
associated with pre-term birth, intrauterine growth restriction and preeclampsia, which cause serious
adverse effects on maternal and infant health. These are major public health concerns. Therefore, a better
understanding of trophoblast cell lineage development and function is critical to gain insights into important
features of pregnancy loss and pregnancy associated disorders.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Cell Signaling and Molecular Endocrinology Study Section[CSME]

results.project_title: Investigating mechanisms underlying diabetes associated with exocrine pancreas diseases
results.phr_text:
Narrative
 Type 3c diabetes mellitus (T3cD) accompanies exocrine pancreas diseases like chronic
pancreatitis (CP) and has distinct clinical features and greater prevalence than previously
appreciated, but the mechanisms underlying T3cD are poorly understood. From studies of islets
in living subjects with CP, we have identified molecular and functional changes in islet cells that
could promote prediabetes. In this proposal we aim to identify signaling and genetic
mechanisms underlying islet dysfunction in pre-T3cD development.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Increasing Access and Participation to Early Phase Clinical Trials to the Underrepresented Populations
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
In this project, Dr. Baranda will continue to lead in the development of sustainable and intentional strategies to
extend access and increase participation to early phase Experimental Therapeutics Clinical Trials Network
(ETCTN) clinical trials to underrepresented populations including the veterans using a roadmap built from
lessons learned from the National Cancer Institute’s (NCI) CATCH-UP.2020 (Create Access to Targeted
Cancer Therapy for Underserved Populations) program.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

full_study_section.name: Biobehavioral Regulation, Learning and Ethology Study Section[BRLE]

results.project_title: Hormonal Programming of the Mesocorticolimbic Circuit During Adolescent Development
results.phr_text:
Narrative
This research will investigate the role of gonadal hormones (estrogen in females, testosterone in
males) in programming adolescent development of the mesocorticolimbic dopamine circuit, which is
functionally linked to motivation, reward, and cognitive control. Studies will reveal how hormones
influence typical maturation and within what developmental window(s) these influences can occur,
and how typical maturation can go awry (e.g., atypical timing of puberty onset). Knowing how typical
maturation can go awry will provide novel insights into the developmental processes during puberty
and adolescence that could lead to the emergence of psychopathology marked by deficits in cognitive
control.

NIH Office of the Director

results.project_title: Noninvasive and early detection of endometriosis using a biological neural circuit-based novel gas sensor
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
There is a critical need for noninvasive and robust endometriosis detection technologies. Although exhaled
breath-based endometriosis detection can offer those advantages, primarily due to the lack of sensitivity and
reliability of existing engineered gas sensors, exhaled breath-based disease diagnosis has not been
implemented in clinical settings. In this proposal, we systematically validate and quantify the performance of our
novel olfactory neuron-based gas sensor for early and robust detection of endometriosis using 2-D cell cultures,
3-D organoids, and in a mouse model of endometrisois.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

full_study_section.name: Skeletal Muscle and Exercise Physiology Study Section[SMEP]

results.project_title: Role of FGF21 in DMD
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The proposed research project aims to investigate the role of FGF21, a novel myokine, in Duchenne Muscular
Dystrophy (DMD). The objectives of the study include understanding the mechanisms that lead to FGF21
expression in dystrophic muscle and examining how FGF21 contributes to the pathology of DMD, particularly in
relation to muscle, bone, and whole-body metabolism. The project seeks to establish a foundation for
comprehending the interactions between muscles and bones in the context of DMD, thus this work has the
potential to shed light on the intricate mechanisms involved in DMD pathogenesis and may offer insights into
novel therapeutic strategies.

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Early Predictors of Infant-Parent Coordinated Attention and Word Learning in Preterm and Full-Term Infants
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Preterm (PT) birth is associated with elevated risks for language impairments, but we know little about why
and how PT-related individual differences in language acquisition emerge. The present proposal will examine
infant-parent coordinated visual attention as a key mechanism underlying the developmental cascades from PT-
induced alterations in basic attention functions and motor abilities to real-time word learning performance. The
findings can improve the precision in predicting disruptions in language acquisition and help identify clinically
useful predictors of PT-related language impairments.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: New Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor signaling in renal cancer
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
It is imperative to identify new therapeutic targets in ccRCC, which is resistnt towards radio or chemotherapy.
Here we provide evidence for the noncanonical role of VHL on regulating m6A modification and gene expression,
which uncovers new mechanistic insight important in kidney tumorigenesis. This study, if successful, will set the
foundation for therapeutic intervention targeting the VHL-Mettl3/14-m6A signaling axis in ccRCC.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Population and Public Health Approaches to HIV/AIDS Study Section[PPAH]

results.project_title: A secure analytics platform to study the prognosis of people with HIV in the USA, Canada and Europe and comparative effectiveness of treatment regimens: the Antiretroviral Therapy Cohort Collaboration
results.phr_text:
PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/ PROJECT NARRATIVE
In the modern era of antiretroviral therapy (ART) for HIV, mortality and morbidity is much rarer than the pre-
ART era so very large studies of people with HIV (PWH) are required to address current research questions.
To enable such research, data from multiple cohort studies of PWH (HIV cohorts), often from many countries,
need to be combined in HIV cohort collaborations. Such collaborations have evolved with increasing
awareness of the need to protect research participants’ privacy, international data protection laws and more
widespread use of data use agreements to govern data transfers. This project will develop a novel, secure,
data-sharing platform, which will anonymize and safely contain data, and allow international collaborators to
conduct secure, privacy-protecting analytics using open science principles. Research conducted through this
platform will improve understanding of cause-specific mortality and cause-specific hospitalizations, develop
prognostic models for less-studied subgroups of PWH, and investigate the comparative effectiveness of novel
treatment strategies.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

results.project_title: Revealing new short tandem repeat variation in the human population across sequencing technologies: towards rare disease diagnosis and discovery
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Short tandem repeats (STRs) are repetitive DNA sequences that cause dozens of genetic diseases in humans
and are difficult to sequence and interpret, leaving individuals with STR-associated disease undiagnosed. This
proposal will establish a genetic diagnosis for hundreds of patients, while searching for new STR disease loci.
To accomplish this, we will develop new computational approaches and call STRs across the genome in
thousands of individuals to establish a population-scale STR catalog, with an emphasis on diverse and under-
served populations.

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

results.project_title: Deciphering Cellular and Genetic Features that Give Rise to Osteonecrosis of the Jaw
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ), characterized by persistent and painful exposed bone, is a devastating
outcome that can occur in patients taking anti-resorptive drugs, and is most common amongst cancer patients
taking high doses of these drugs, who harbor a ~5% risk of developing ONJ. Here we integrate cellular,
molecular, and pharmacogenomic approaches to characterize the development of ONJ, and identify genetic
risk factors for developing this condition.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

results.project_title: A Comprehensive qPCR-Based Oral Microbiome Profiling Platform for Research and Discovery
results.phr_text:
The oral microbiome is vital for dental health and provides insights into systemic conditions. While
next-generation sequencing has limitations for biomarker discovery, qPCR-based molecular detection can offer
specificity, sensitivity, and quantification. The development of a comprehensive oral qPCR panel using this
technology can provide a cost-effective and efficient research tool to monitor disease progression and
therapeutic response in large cohorts, as well as enable in the future the discovery and leveraging of microbial
biomarkers for clinical research, screening tests, and diagnostics.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Molecular Virology, Cell Biology, and Drug Development Study Section[HVCD]

results.project_title: Ionic liquid-based nanoemulsion containing combination antiretroviral drugs forthe transdermal treatment of pediatric HIV infection
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
HIV treatment in pediatric patients is challenging and the treatment adherence is low due to factors such as
lack of age-appropriate formulations, palatability issues of oral formulations, the daily reminder of HIV infection
with oral therapy. This project will develop novel strategies to improve transdermal delivery of dolutegravir-
rilpivirine combination for non-invasive and effective management of HIV infections in pediatric patients.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Immunopathogenesis and Vaccine Development Study Section[HIVD]

results.project_title: HIV Vaccine Design Incorporating Selective Avidity
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
An effective HIV vaccine will be useful for stemming the spread of HIV worldwide and domestically. We aim to
engineer an immunogen better capable of guiding the development of neutralizing antibodies against diverse
HIV strains and to test the design in an established mouse model.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Combination metabolic therapy for diffuse midline glioma
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Diffuse midline gliomas (DMGs) are deadly brain tumors in children. Our studies have identified a unique
combination of metabolic vulnerabilities that can be exploited for therapy and for visualizing early response to
therapy in DMGs. Clinical translation of our studies has the potential to improve outcomes and quality of life for
children with this pernicious form of cancer.

organization.org_name: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: Leveraging social media to promote body positivity among Latinx adolescents
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Body positivity, the promotion and acceptance of diverse body sizes and appearances, is one approach to
mitigating weight stigma, which is associated with depression, anxiety, disordered eating, reduced physical
activity, and weight gain. Latinx adolescents have higher rates obesity than their white counterparts and are at
risk of experiencing multiple forms of stigmatization. This study will assess the impact of a social media campaign
that promotes body positivity on weight stigma and mental health among Latinx youth, compared to a control
campaign.

organization.org_name: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Rewiring T cell exhaustion with immune checkpoint blockade therapy
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Immune responses to checkpoint blockade therapy in patients with malignant melanoma depend upon self-
renewing T cells. The goal of this project is to identify mechanisms that underlie the regulation these cells
based on a novel immunotherapy to ultimately promote better long-term patient outcomes.

organization.org_name: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI

agency_ic_admin.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

results.project_title: PATHFINDER: Finding the genomic and clinical pathways underlying heterogeneity in complex disease
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
The research in this proposal aims to uncover the mechanisms underlying heterogeneity in complex diseases
through the identification of: (i) the context (tissues, cell types, gene networks) in which causal genes operate,
and (ii) shared and distinct genetic risk profiles among patients. This knowledge will be integrated with additional
clinical data in statistical and machine learning models to stratify patients into more homogeneous disease
subtypes, contributing to the development of new precision medicine strategies. The study will be initially applied
to schizophrenia, inflammatory bowel disease, and coronary artery disease, acting as a guide in the psychiatric,
cardiometabolic, and immunological fields.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Integrative and Clinical Endocrinology and Reproduction Study Section[ICER]

results.project_title: The Impact of Oral Contraceptives on Neuron-derived Exosomal miRNA Expression in the Developing Brain
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Center for Disease Control data indicate that ~20% of adolescents and young adult women are prescribed oral
contraceptives (OCs), yet our understanding of how synthetic hormones contained in OCs may impact the
neurobiological landscape is markedly limited. We propose to measure neuron-derived exosome microRNA
expression profiles in adolescent/young adult females (ages 15-22) prescribed oral contraceptives (OC)
compared to natural cycling, OC naïve adolescent females. Study outcomes will elucidate the influence of
exogenous hormones on brain development.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Development of Neutralizing Antibodies to Machupo Virus
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project will leverage a cutting-edge biotechnology platform to develop neutralizing antibodies to Machupo
virus (MACV) by immunization with a first-in-class prefusion stabilized MACV GPC trimer and innovative phage
display technologies.

organization.org_name: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Dynamics and Evolution of HIV Gag and GagPol processing
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Maturation of the HIV-1 capsid is an essential step during the biogenesis of infectious virions. Maturation occurs
when the viral protease cleaves the Gag protein into its constituent domains. The proposed research will lead to
a better understanding of the mechanism by which the viral protease proteolytically processes Gag, how the
dynamics of Gag and the immature virion regulate the timing of this process, and the evolutionary constraints
that the virus faces in order to maintain efficient proteolysis and maturation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Novel B. Pertussis vaccines that elicit mucosal immunity
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Current acellular pertussis vaccines do not prevent nasal colonization or transmission of B. pertussis, highlighting
the need for next-generation vaccines that generate mucosal immunity. Here we will test a novel booster vaccine
for adults and a novel pediatric vaccine that incorporates novel CD4+ T cell recognized antigens from B. pertussis
that generate tissue-resident T cells in the nose and lungs. We hypothesize that these vaccines will reduce
nasal colonization in individuals previously immunized with acellular pertussis vaccines and prevent development
of a B. pertussis nasal reservoir in infants who are immunized this new formulation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Precision medicine for pancreatic cancer. Biomarker-guided drug delivery of platinum to tumors
results.phr_text:
Here, we will test the central hypothesis that platinum drugs devised to target and penetrate the tumor glycocalyx
barrier will achieve enhanced levels of drug uptake in models of pancreatic cancer translating into enhanced
clinical efficacy. These findings will address the two critical unmet needs in the treatment of pancreatic cancer
to find 1) therapeutics to effectively treat drug resistant disease and 2) predictive biomarkers to identify which
patients will benefit most from the available therapies.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health
National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: Viscerosensory Modulation of Brain Circuits in Larval Zebrafish
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The brain receives signals from all of our internal organs through the sensory vagus nerve, but
the way in which this information modulates individual neurons and circuits is not understood.
This proposal investigates how internal organ information is represented in the sensory vagus
nerve. Our work will then enable investigating how each internal organ signal influences brain
function and behavior.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Integrative and Clinical Endocrinology and Reproduction Study Section[ICER]

results.project_title: Microbiome mediated effects of gender affirming hormone therapy in mice
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project will determine the contribution of the gut microbiome to the effects of gender affirming hormone
therapy (GAHT) in mice. Our study will provide information on whether GAHT exerts effects on skeletal
maturation, and the mechanisms whereby the gut microbiome mediates the skeletal effects of GAHT. The
project is important because the skeletal effects of GAHT in humans is a critical medical concern in
transgender medicine.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Maternal B cells in health and disease.
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
A detailed understanding of B cell and antibody responses to placental versus foreign antigen will illuminate
how dysregulated responses contribute to pregnancy complications and inform the design of vaccine programs
which best protect mothers and children from infection. We propose to study B cell and antibody responses to
placental versus foreign antigen. Results will identify molecular mechanisms suppressing B cell activation; map
tolerance pathways that protect the conceptus from antibody-mediated damage; and identify a pregnancy
factor capable of boosting humoral immunity, which will be clinically useful to boost responses to vaccines and
fight infections.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

full_study_section.name: Bioengineering of Neuroscience, Vision and Low Vision Technologies Study Section[BNVT]

results.project_title: Brain-computer interface (BCI)-based identification of color vision deficiencies (CVDs) related to Parkinson’s Disease (PD)
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Present methods for assessing color vision (CV) are not sensitive/specific enough to detect the changes in CV
caused by Parkinson’s disease (PD), or are unsuitable for people cognitive impairments and/or motor deficits
(CIs/MDs) that occur during both the prodromal and clinical stages of PD. We recently demonstrated a new brain-
computer interface (BCI)-based method for CV assessment and propose to test the hypothesis that this new
assessment has enhanced sensitivity, specificity, and test-retest reliability for detecting color vision deficiencies
(CVDs) related to PD compared to existing behavior-based assessments. If successful, our research will enable
the use of CVDs as early biomarkers of PD, CV assessment as a method for monitoring PD progression, and
may lead to the use of CV assessment for the early detection of CVDs caused by other neurological disorders.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

full_study_section.name: Interdisciplinary Clinical Care in Specialty Care Settings Study Section[ICSC]

results.project_title: Symptom Monitoring using Patient-Reported Outcomes to Optimize Medication Use (SyMPTOM)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
For curatively treated hormone receptor positive breast cancer, taking 5-10 years of a daily oral endocrine
therapy such as tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor cuts the risk of breast cancer recurrence nearly in half, yet
nearly half of women taking endocrine therapy to prevent breast cancer recurrence do not meet minimum
thresholds for adherence, often due to symptoms. We propose to test whether oncology teams can improve
long-term oral oncologic medication adherence through better symptom monitoring and management.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

full_study_section.name: Interdisciplinary Clinical Care in Specialty Care Settings Study Section[ICSC]

results.project_title: Symptom Management and Transitioning to Engagement with Post-treatment Care for Adolescent and Young Adult Cancer Survivors (AYA STEPS)
results.phr_text:
RELEVANCE STATEMENT
For adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors, the impacts of treatment are significant and long-lasting,
including difficult physical symptoms (e.g., pain, fatigue), emotional distress, and an increased risk of long-term
health problems. Engagement in recommended follow-up care is critical; yet, the proportion of AYA survivors
who engage in follow-up care rapidly declines with age and time since treatment, resulting in inadequate
surveillance for late effects and missed opportunities for symptom management, psychological support, and
health promotion. The proposed study examines the efficacy of an accessible digital health intervention, AYA
STEPS (Symptom Management and Transitioning to Engagement with Post-Treatment Care for AYA Survivors),
that is designed to enhance the ability of AYA cancer survivors to manage their high symptom burden and
engage in recommended follow-up care by improving self-efficacy for symptom management and patient
activation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

full_study_section.name: Therapeutic Development and Preclinical Studies Study Section[TDPS]

results.project_title: Ultrasound Cavitation for Facilitated Cardiac Transduction of AAV
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Gene therapy for inherited and acquired cardiovascular diseases has been limited by either low
efficiency or toxicity of the vectors used to introduce genes into cells of the heart. We will
investigate how gene therapy using a promising vector approach that relies on bioengineered
adeno-associated viruses (AAVs) can be improved by site-directed ultrasound-mediated
cavitation of microbubble contrast agents. These studies are intended to produce vital
knowledge of ideal conditions, efficacy, and safety of cavitation-mediated transduction needed
for translation into humans.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

full_study_section.name: Community Influences on Health Behavior Study Section[CIHB]

results.project_title: Driving Environmental Justice: Community Monitoring of Diesel Truck Emissions and Impacts onAsthma Morbidity in Immigrant Communities
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
North Richmond, South Fresno, and Southwest Stockton, California are three environmental justice
communities with asthma prevalence and asthma-related emergency room visits double that of the rest of the
State. Our community-partnered study will increase our understanding of the short-term respiratory health
effects of residing near diesel exhaust pollution sources, including frequented truck routes, for Latino/x/e
children with asthma while also identifying and co-prioritizing mitigation strategies for adoption and policy
change.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Digestive Diseases and Nutrition C Study Section[DDK-C]

results.project_title: The role of lipid droplet proteins in eicosanoid production and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) affects ~30% of the global adult population and is associated with
morbidity and mortality from hepatic and extra-hepatic complications, causing a major health burden for our
society. Hepatic lipid droplets (LDs) have emerged as important players in NAFLD, yet their impact on its
pathogenesis and progression is not fully understood. By studying common genetic coding variants in two LD
proteins (PNPLA3-I148M and PLIN2-Pro251), this proposal aims to elucidate the role of LDs in NAFLD, leading
to a better understanding of this disease and providing new therapeutic targets.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Therapeutic Strategies for the Management of Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia-Associated Pulmonary Hypertension
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Around 50% of infants born extremely preterm develop a chronic lung disease known as bronchopulmonary
dysplasia of which some infants will also develop pulmonary hypertension of which 50% of children will die
before the age of 2. Physicians are currently limited in their (1) ability to predict which infants will develop
this more severe form and (2) ability to select the most appropriate therapy that will improve outcomes in
infants with this condition. This proposal will develop a tool to predict which infants are more likely to
develop bronchopulmonary dysplasia and pulmonary hypertension, will examine whether currently used
therapies for this disease improve infants’ condition, and determine whether using different amounts of
oxygen improve outcomes in infants with this disease.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Development of Memory Networks in Children
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The proposed project is relevant to public health because memory deficits occur in many psychiatric and
neurological disorders and are common as a result of early life adversity. Identifying the neurophysiological
mechanisms of memory retrieval in the developing brain will inform the design of effective interventions for
alleviating memory impairment in children and thus have a positive impact on life-long wellbeing. Further, this
project will pave the way to designing clinical tools to map memory in the developing brain that will influence
diagnostic and therapeutic surgical approaches and ultimately improve quality of life in patients with drug-
resistant focal epilepsy.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

results.project_title: Psychosocial Predictors of Health Behaviors and Outcomes in Patients with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Positive Head and Neck Cancer
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Human Papillomavirus (HPV) has emerged as a leading factor in the development of head and neck cancer
(HNC); despite the more favorable prognosis of HPV positive HNC, patients may experience distinct patterns
of psychological distress that contribute to health behaviors (i.e., tobacco and alcohol use) and have a direct
bearing on relapse, morbidity, and mortality. However, the lack of knowledge of this relationship in the context
of HPV positive HNC is a critical barrier to patient care and psychosocial intervention development. In support
of the NCI’s mission of helping people with cancer live longer and healthier lives, results from this study will
develop an understanding of the unique psychosocial needs of patients with HPV positive HNC and the
association to health behaviors and long-term health outcomes.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Molecular Virology, Cell Biology, and Drug Development Study Section[HVCD]

results.project_title: Targeting CD127-expressing tissue reservoir cells as a strategy for HIV cure
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
HIV persists despite antiretroviral therapy in part because CD4+ T cells persistently infected with the virus can
replicate themselves in a process called homeostatic proliferation. In this proposal, we set out the determine the
outcome of targeting infected cells responding to IL7 – a key mediator of homeostatic proliferation – on HIV
persistence, using both in vitro and in vivo models. Our study combines measurements of HIV persistence with
in-depth characterization of the features of persistently-infected cells that are susceptible vs. resistant to our
therapy, in order to shed light on the multiple mechanisms HIV exploits to persist in long-lived, self-renewing
host cells.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

results.project_title: Late Stage Development of Sustained-release Relaxin for Treating Joint Contracture
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Current surgical and non-surgical treatment options for patients suffering from shoulder stiffness (contrac-
ture, or arthrofibrosis) are limited in scope and effectiveness, with a significant number of patients never regaining
full joint function. Ortholevo has developed a unique treatment for shoulder contracture. This first of its kind
therapy delivers the protein, relaxin-2, using a sustained release polymeric microparticle formulation to restore
the range of motion and reduce shoulder contracture.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Understanding reservoir effects and curative potential of a CD3/CCR5 bispecific antibody in infant macaques
results.phr_text:
We are seeking a safe and effective agent to combat human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which has killed
about 35 million people. We are developing a treatment that removes HIV-infected cells from the bodies of
infected infants, in hopes of achieving durable remission of the infection. In this grant we will rigorously and
separately test the potential of the treatment to remove reservoir cells and to induce remission, and
test if its efficacy can be further improved by addition of a broadly neutralizing antibody.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

results.project_title: Synthetic Genetic Controller Circuits for Transcription Factor-Directed Differentiation
results.phr_text:
Narrative:
We develop synthetic genetic controller circuits for autonomous transcription factor-directed
differentiation. The genetic circuits sense the state of the cell to express programming
transcription factors at the optimal levels, robustly to epigenetic silencing. We showcase this
technology on the problem of differentiating hiPSCs to the hemogenic endothelium, which is a
critical intermediate to generate hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

results.project_title: Wood Pellet Emissions and Children's Environmental Health in Mississippi
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Given the desire to move from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources, the market for wood pellets is
booming, and wood pellet production plants are rapidly sprouting up across the United States, most notably in
predominantly black and poor communities in the deep south. Taking advantage of the staggered opening of
wood pellet production plants in Mississippi--a state also grappling with significant pediatric health and quality
of life issues, this project will measure and model the propagation of both air and noise pollution from wood
pellet production into the surrounding community and will examine how and to what extent these wood pellet
production exposures impact the health and well-being of children living nearby. Understanding how multiple
physical and chemical environmental exposures impact children’s respiratory and stress health will reveal key
insights that can help us better assess economic benefits against environmental health costs of wood pellet
production as an alternative energy source and investing in local human capital will create a cohort of diverse,
local researchers and concerned residents who will become first-authors in their future stories.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

full_study_section.name: Therapeutic Development and Preclinical Studies Study Section[TDPS]

results.project_title: The KChIP2-JNK2 axis as a therapeutic target for sudden cardiac death
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Heart failure myocardium exhibits electrophysiologic pathological remodeling that underlies the development of
arrhythmias leading to sudden cardiac death. Here we aim to delineate the mechanisms behind KChIP2
transcriptional repression of the stress kinase JNK2 gene and the possible causal role of increased/activated
JNK2 to arrhythmia mechanisms and sudden cardiac death onset. The outcomes of this proposal will establish the
therapeutic potential of KChIP2 gene transfer and/or JNK2 inhibition as prospective anti-arrhythmia interventions for
a translational path toward future arrhythmia therapies in HF patients.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: Development of a system to protect and concentrate large DNA for genome analysis
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Within the human genome, structural variations change more base pairs than point mutations, and those
variations may lead to different diseases. However, long DNA molecules aid in assembling these large
variations by spanning the length of the variation. This research aims to develop a system that will produce
long molecules that can be analyzed with sequencing or physical mapping to find these larger variations.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
NIH Office of the Director

results.project_title: Children's Allergy and Asthma Data Repository (CADRE)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Identifying modifiable prenatal and early life risk factors is crucial for developing strategies to prevent childhood
asthma. While individual birth cohort studies have identified several asthma-related genetic, personal and
environmental risk factors, these studies were mainly limited to homogeneous cohorts and modest sample sizes.
We propose establishing a children's allergy and asthma data hub (The Children's Allergy and Asthma Data
Repository, or “CADRE”) to ensure enduring access for the scientific community to allergy and asthma birth
cohort data.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Mechanisms of Silent Synapse Maturation for Excitatory Network Refinement
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Experience-dependent neural network refinement is a fundamental process during postnatal brain development.
This project is to investigate the molecular mechanisms that underlies silent synapse-based cortical excitatory
network refinement. Specifically, we aim to dissect a signaling hub, coordinated by the signaling scaffold PSD-
95 that controls the pace of silent synapse maturation local visual cortex circuits and visual perception.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Romosozumab as an adjunct to physiologic estrogen replacement in adolescents and young adults with functional hypothalamic amenorrhea
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Teenagers and young adult women whose menstrual periods cease due to restrictive eating disorders, such as
anorexia nervosa, and/or from excessive exercise, have low bone density and increased fracture risk. This
double-blind, placebo-controlled study will examine whether administration of a medication (romosozumab) for
6 months that increases bone formation and reduces bone breakdown, followed by a single dose of an additional
medication (zoledronate) to extend the effects of romosozumab will provide a necessary boost to allow bone
health to normalize in teenagers and young adult women with these disorders who are also receiving estrogen
replacement.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Allergy, Immunology, and Transplantation Research Committee[AITC]

results.project_title: Mechanisms Contributing to T Cell Immune Dysregulation in STAT3 Gain-of-Function
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Primary immune regulatory disorders (PIRD) are a rapidly expanding subset of inborn errors of immunity
characterized by disorganized and aberrant immune responses, and often present with variable manifestations
such as autoimmunity and infectious complications. This project will investigate the development of antigen-
specific responses and cellular factors contributing to T cell dysregulation in STAT3 gain-of-function syndrome,
a known monogenic PIRD. Results from these studies have the potential to uncover new biomarkers,
targetable cellular pathways, and further insight into disease pathogenesis and human immunology.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: HIV Comorbidities and Clinical Studies Study Section[HCCS]

results.project_title: Appetite regulation with DTG based ART in postpartum women living with HIV and their infants (Ar-DART)
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative:
With the ongoing scale up of Dolutegravir (DTG), an integrase strand transfer inhibitor antiretroviral treatment,
in Sub-Saharan Africa, weight gain has been noted in postpartum women living with HIV. How maternal DTG
impacts the physiology of maternal and infant body weight regulation has not been studied. In a cohort of
maternal-infant dyads from Uganda, we propose to study how DTG-based regimens affects energy intake and
expenditure along with biological measures of appetite and metabolic pathways relevant in weight regulation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

results.project_title: Extracellular vesicles in Environmental Epidemiology Studies of Aging
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
While the human body is composed of ~200 different cell types and chronic diseases stem from dysfunction of
multiple cells types in specific organs, most human environmental studies have overlooked such complexity.
By capturing cell type-specific signals in easily obtainable biospecimens (i.e., standard blood draw) I propose
to identify early biological responses to environmental exposures that are predictive of future health-related
conditions, specifically of the effects of air pollution on accelerated brain aging—a primary focus of my
laboratory. Due to the central roles that extracellular vesicles have in aging and chronic disease, this work will
provide a model that can be applied to many other types of exposures and various chronic diseases.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - C[TWD-C]

results.project_title: Bridges to the Baccalaureate Research Training Program
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative: The long-term goal of the SUNY Upstate Bridges to the Baccalaureate Program T34
training grant is to increase the number of under-represented students who transfer from three SUNY
community colleges (MCC, OCC, WCC) and complete baccalaureate degrees in disciplines relevant to
biomedical and behavioral sciences at Binghamton University. The inclusion of underrepresented groups in the
biomedical and behavior science workforce is critical to reducing health disparities and improving the health of
all people in the United States.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Nutrition and Metabolism in Health and Disease Study Section[NMHD]

results.project_title: Dietary iron requirements in a diverse group of US adults
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The current Dietary Reference Intakes (DRIs) for iron are based on a relatively small number of studies from
homogenous populations outside the US. The proposed study will determine dietary iron requirements in a large,
representative sample of US adults. These data will serve as a crucial resource for informing the necessary
updates to the current DRIs, ensuring they accurately reflect the specific needs of the increasingly diverse US
population.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

results.project_title: Assessing RF heating of active implantable medical devices in low-field MRI systems
results.phr_text:
Narrative
This project aims to assess RF heating of deep brain stimulation devices and cardiac electronic implants during
MRI in newly approved low-field MRI scanners at 0.55 T. Results will produce data that allow determination of
safe imaging parameters, and support development of standards and imaging guidelines which bring MRI
accessible to these patients.

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Digestive Diseases and Nutrition C Study Section[DDK-C]

results.project_title: The Role of the PBN Melanocortin System in the Regulation of Ingestive Behaviors
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The parabrachial nucleus serves as a crucial sensory hub, relaying data from internal and external senses to
shape motivated behaviors; in this intricate network, the activation of melanocortin 3 and 4 receptors (MC3R and
MC4R) expressing neurons can either stimulate or suppress ingestive behaviors. Of particular importance, the
PBN MC3R neurons represent a novel population in the PBN as they contradict the overall role of the PBN in
inhibiting feeding. Understanding how these two neuronal populations in the PBN integrate opposing ingestive
behaviors is the major goal of this project.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

full_study_section.name: Human Complex Mental Function Study Section[HCMF]

results.project_title: Neural basis of visual attention in the primate brain
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The proposed research aims to advance our understanding of how the brain prioritizes information from cluttered
visual environments to guide ongoing behavior. This process, broadly referred to as selective attention, is
impaired in several clinical populations, including individuals with spatial neglect after stroke, attention deficit
hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), schizophrenia, and autism spectrum disorders (ASD). By better understanding
the separable neural processes that contribute to selective attention, we hope to generate more pointed
hypotheses about its dysfunction, leading to more effective treatments and interventions.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Implementation strategies for caregiver and teacher use of behavioral interventions with ADHD: A pilot study
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Behavioral interventions at home and school, as well as the communication between home and school, are
critical in shaping the mental health outcomes of children with or at-risk for Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity
Disorder (ADHD), a prevalent and impairing mental health condition, but caregivers and teachers need
implementation supports to use behavioral interventions with fidelity. Using a community participatory
approach, we will develop implementation strategies for caregivers to support their use of behavioral
interventions as early intervention for children with or at-risk for ADHD, and pilot test them alongside existing
teacher-facing Coordinated caregiver-facing and teacher-facing implementation strategies, disseminated
through schools, have the potential to promote healthy outcomes for children with ADHD on a large scale.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Michigan-Unijos Mentored Program for Enhanced Research Administration (MUMPERA)
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Global Infectious Disease Research Administration Develop Program for Low-and-Middle-Income Countries
is an intervention to increase the capacity of Research Administrators and Finance Managers of NIAID/NIH
projects to support the mission of the institute in ameliorating infectious diseases in the world. This investment
by the institute has rippling positive effects, on not only the prime institution, but also other local in-country
institutions as well as regional institutions; through this, information of funding opportunities for health
research, establishing grant management offices, and strengthening existing ones, has been implemented.
It has brought great awareness to the business of grants administration, among Faculty Researchers, and
institution management support for new policies and procedures for the implementation of external funding;
it has also impacted on internal funding operations, for global health or social researches, by other
international or local funders.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: 2024 International Meeting on the Molecular Biology of Hepatitis B Viruses (International HBV Meeting)
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Hepatitis B virus (HBV) chronically infects 290 million people world-wide and causes liver cancer
and liver failure for which there are no curative treatments, so there is an urgent need to develop
better antiviral therapies. The International HBV Meeting is the only meeting that brings together
scientists studying HBV and its satellite hepatitis delta virus (HDV) to present and discuss the
newest fundamental discoveries of HBV and HDV biology that have the potential to evolve into
new antiviral approaches for curing HBV and HDV infections, thereby preventing the development
of the associated liver diseases. This application seeks funding for travel grants to support
attendance of early-stage investigators and under-represented scientists at the HBV meeting to
maximize diversity of attendees and the variety of ideas and opinions that they bring with them.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Maternal regulation of microtubules in egg developmental competency
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative: Factors provided to the egg by the mother drive development of the fertilized egg and early
embryo, however, little is known about this maternal regulation in vertebrates. This study will identify a new
factor that acts in regulating the cytoskeleton, giving competency to the vertebrate egg to proceed in embryonic
development and has direct relevance to human reproductive success and female fertility.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Research Study Section[AIDS]

results.project_title: Impact of estrogen replacement therapy on bone health in an aging population of women living with HIV
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Due to the effectiveness of antiretroviral therapy (ART), there is an increase in women living with HIV (WLWH)
who are aging and will undergo menopause. We intend to measure the impact of i) simian immunodeficiency
virus (SIV) infection ii) ART-suppression iii) menopause and iv) presence or absence of hormone replacement
therapy (HRT), on bone architecture and quality in a unique nonhuman primate model. These studies will focus
on compound bone loss, bone health and fracture risk in our model of postmenopausal WLWH-with and without
HRT and our results could inform future care options to protect these women from compounded risk of bone
fractures and osteoporosis.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Population and Public Health Approaches to HIV/AIDS Study Section[PPAH]

results.project_title: Strengthening informed consent for authentic participation in perinatal HIV research
results.phr_text:
Public Health Relevance: Strengthening the informed consent process is an important step in attaining
authentic participation in clinical research, particularly by the vulnerable populations affected by HIV. We will
evaluate a visual informed consent document that uses pictures to aid in achieving better comprehension of
the requirements of participation in research. The study is nested in an on-going trial in South Africa among
mothers living with HIV and their infants.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Molecular Virology, Cell Biology, and Drug Development Study Section[HVCD]

results.project_title: Architecture and dynamics of immature HIV lattice
results.phr_text:
Narrative:
We will investigate what holds the immature HIV lattice together and how dynamics propagate
through the lattice. We will then establish if these dynamics drive the auto-processing of Gag-
Pol, which is the first step of the HIV maturation process.

organization.org_name: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

full_study_section.name: Biochemical and Cellular Oncogenesis Study Section[BCO]

results.project_title: Overcoming Therapy Resistance in Fusion Oncoprotein Driven Pediatric Leukemia
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 NUP98-NSD1 fusion-positive acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a poor prognostic subtype in children and
is frequently associated with co-occurring mutations in the transcription factor WT1. Focusing on the cellular and
developmental context, our proposal aims to dissect mechanisms of action of the fusion oncoprotein NUP98-
NSD1, investigate WT1's role in therapy resistance, and identify novel therapeutic targets for childhood AML.
