These results are poised to reshape our understanding of childhood susceptibility to AML and provide a rationale
for therapeutic intervention in future clinical studies.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Human Complex Mental Function Study Section[HCMF]

results.project_title: The effects of gender-affirming sex steroids on brain development in adolescents
results.phr_text:
Transgender and gender-nonbinary (TNB) adolescents may receive gender-affirming hormone therapy (GAHT)
with estradiol or testosterone to induce physical changes that align with their gender identity. This has been
shown to improve symptoms of anxiety and depression, but parents and caregivers often worry that giving
GAHT during adolescence, a period of rapid brain maturation, may affect their child’s brain development and
function and, in turn, their child’s ability to think and learn. In this proposed project, we will use advanced
neuroimaging techniques and a battery of well-established tools for cognitive assessment to study the
neurocognitive effects of GAHT in TNB adolescents.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

full_study_section.name: Cellular Signaling and Regulatory Systems Study Section[CSRS]

results.project_title: Engineered orthogonal signaling systems for selective phosphorylation of protein kinase substrates
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Enzymes called protein kinases are important regulators of cellular responses to environmental cues, and their
deregulation is a hallmark of cancer. We will develop technology based around engineering of kinases and their
protein substrates that will allow us to better understand how protein kinases carry out their functions in cancer
cells. Understanding signaling pathways important for tumor cell survival and growth may suggest new
therapeutic opportunities for treating cancer.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Aging

full_study_section.name: Cellular and Molecular Biology of Neurodegeneration Study Section[CMND]

results.project_title: Decoding the BETA-arrestin2-LMBRD2 cascade in ALPHA-synuclein pathogenesis.
results.phr_text:
The defining pathological hallmark of Lewy body diseases (LBDs) is the accumulation of misfolded and toxic a-
synuclein (aSyn) through multiple mechanisms. This proposal will investigate the significance and mechanistic
basis of a novel pathway that mediates the accumulation, transmission, and toxicity of aSyn through animal and
cellular models, which is expected to shed critical new insights to new ways to treat LBDs.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Parkin tumor suppression
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The loss of endogenous tumor suppression is an obligatory step towards cancer, but the mechanisms are
elusive. We have now discovered that Parkin, a molecule altered in early-onset Parkinson’s disease, functions
as a unique dual mode tumor suppressor, inhibiting intrinsic tumor traits of cell motility and metabolism while
also reprogramming an antitumor immune microenvironment. This pathway involves Parkin “priming” of
immunogenic cell death, control of cytosolic and mitochondrial danger-sensing pathways and transcriptional
activation of interferon gene expression. The proposed studies will elucidate the cellular and molecular
requirements of Parkin innate immunity in cancer and uncover novel strategies to improve the response to
immunotherapy in advanced disease patients.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Cellular, Molecular and Integrative Reproduction Study Section[CMIR]

results.project_title: The roles of mouse Y chromosome Zfy genes in male reproduction.
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
ZFY is an essential and conserved Y chromosome encoded male fertility factor but how it imposes its important role has
not been established. Using new mouse models that we developed, we will investigate the molecular function of mouse
Zfy. Our findings will impact on understanding on genetic regulation of spermatogenesis and origin of male infertility, with
consequences for advancing knowledge about these processes in humans.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Wetlands in Argentinaas hubs for exchange and emigration of bird-borne arboviruses
results.phr_text:
Project narrative
During their movements, birds can disperse infectious agents (bacteria, viruses) and ectoparasites (ticks,
fleas, lice) representing an important mode of transport of emerging pathogens. Wetlands are known to serve
as hotspots for resident bird diversity as well as a stopover and overwinter sites for migratory birds, since they
are stable ecosystems, with high food productivity. We intend to use this study as a foundation to
understanding how wetlands works as hub for arboviruses exchange and spillover in an interconnected
wetland networks across the Americas.

organization.org_name: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

full_study_section.name: NHLBI Mentored Patient-Oriented Research Study Section[MPOR (MA)]

results.project_title: Impact of Restrictive Drug Coverage Policies on Heart Failure Care
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Heart failure is a major, common, and costly public health problem in the United States, and despite the
existence of several proven, guideline-recommended medications to reduce mortality and hospitalization,
many patients are not prescribed or do not fill these medications. This study aims to quantify the impact of
restrictive drug coverage policies, such as copayment and prior authorization, on gaps and inequities in
prescribing, adherence, and outcomes for patients with heart failure. Our findings could inform policy-makers,
health systems, and clinicians on ways to improve care and reduce inequities for patients with heart failure.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: EEG Signature Analysis for Drug Repurposing for Rare Diseases
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
There is a great unmet need to repurpose already approved drugs for rare disorders as success rate in drug
discovery has a high rate of failure, is costly and a slow process. In addition, drug companies may not have good
incentive to take such a risky approach to drug development for the 90% of rare diseases that have no approved
therapeutic treatment. Given the need to address repurposing in an efficient and systematic manner,
PsychoGenics Inc. will develop a novel machine learning-based statistical approach to drug repurposing that
can identify compounds and predict their phenotypic therapeutic potential for a portfolio of different rare disorders
(at once) to guide the early stages of drug validation and translation to the clinic.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

results.project_title: Catheter Cap with Anti-biofilm Luminal Insert
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Patients that require hemodialysis are at increased risk for blood stream infections, largely due to
long term dependance on vascular access and a high prevalence of central venous catheter
(CVC) use. The results of this work will improve safety and reduce the cost of delivering
hemodialysis to patients with end stage renal disease by preventing catheter related infections.
This will be accomplished by developing a simple to use catheter end cap that functions as an
antimicrobial barrier and delivery device to kill infection-causing microorganisms inside
hemodialysis catheter hubs.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Comorbidities and Clinical Studies Study Section[HCCS]

results.project_title: Addressing Research Gaps to Optimize Dolutegravir-based ART in Children and Adolescents
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
The accelerated rollout of dolutegravir (DTG)-based antiretroviral therapy (ART) as a universal regimen for the
treatment of human immunodeficiency virus infection (HIV) in children and adolescents in low- and middle-
income countries (LMICs) was done with limited research data in that population. There is currently limited
data on the pharmacokinetics of the pediatric DTG formulations, drug-interactions in the settings of treatment
of active or latent tuberculosis (TB) as well as long-term outcomes in children and adolescents in real-world
settings. This proposal will address these fundamental research gaps and provide relevant data to inform
optimization of DTG-based ART in children and adolescents in LMICs.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Immune Microenvironments That Impact HIV Persistence and Expression During ART
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
During antiretroviral treatment (ART) in people living with HIV (PWH), latently HIV-infected cells reside
primarily in lymph nodes, spleen and gut-associated lymphoid tissues and sporadically produce virus. Little is
known about factors that induce latently HIV-infected cells to produce virus, but we believe that B cells in the
tissue microenvironment play an important role. This project will define the role of B cells and other immune
cells in the microenvironment in promoting virus expression with the long term goal of developing strategies to
reverse or alternatively enhance viral latency in vivo to achieve a functional remission of HIV.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Investigating Syphilis Pathogenesis Through Genetic Engineering of Treponema pallidum
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Syphilis affects millions of people worldwide, and its global rates are on the rise. Syphilis causative
agent, Treponema pallidum (T. pallidum), can cause severe neurological sequelae, and individuals with
syphilis are at higher risk of transmitting and acquiring HIV. Applying our newly developed genetic engineering
approach to the syphilis agent will provide us with a better understanding of syphilis pathogenesis and
pathogen persistence, and help devise new methods to control this serious infection.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

results.project_title: Mapping and prediction of quantitative transcription factor dosage effects to understand variation in craniofacial morphology and disease
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The research proposed here will systematically quantify the effects of craniofacial transcription factor dosage
changes on molecular, cellular, and morphological phenotypes. This work will provide: (1) mechanisms
underlying sensitivity to transcription factor dosage in normal-range and disease-associated variation, (2)
insights into the specific facial phenotypes observed in a range of craniofacial syndromes, and (3) basic
insights into the mechanisms of transcription-factor mediated regulation. Finally, by driving forward our
understanding of craniofacial variation and disease, the proposed research will nominate key genes and
pathways that one day could inform disease prediction and/or therapeutic development.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: Real-time mapping of neuronal connectivity at a synapse resolution
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Dissecting synaptic connectivity is essential for understanding normal brain functions and diseases. However,
current available fluorescent sensors that are aimed for detecting synaptic contacts have limitations in in vivo
settings. We propose to demonstrate the versatility of a newly developed sensor and apply it to investigate
both excitatory and inhibitory connectivity in the context of learning, which will yield valuable resources that
contribute significantly to the study of neural circuits.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Oxytocin for induction of labor: understanding goals and mechanisms
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Over 1 million pregnant patients per year in the US undergo induction of labor with oxytocin. Despite widespread
use of this medication, we have a limited understanding of how oxytocin should be dosed and how the uterus
should contract in response to oxytocin to achieve the ultimate goal of cervical dilation and labor progression.
We propose a clinical and translational study investigating the physiologic and functional response to exogenous
oxytocin by placing universal intrauterine pressure catheters in patients undergoing labor induction to determine
contraction parameters predictive of success and assessing serial maternal serum oxytocin levels and
myometrial oxytocin receptor function in response to oxytocin dosing.

organization.org_name: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: CMV+ milk: morbidity risk & translational potential of neutralizing antibodies
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This proposal is relevant to public health as it addresses a serious infectious disease in one of our most
vulnerable populations, preterm infants. Our research team will evaluate strategies to reduce human milk
transmission of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in preterm infants. The application of knowledge gained will
reduce CMV illness and long-term disability.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: REACH-EpiVCID
results.phr_text:
Environmental factors associated with social determinants of health associate with dementia after brain bleeds,
and modifiable changes to the genome, called epigenetic signals, might mediate that association. We will
investigate epigenetic signals and their association with both social determinants of health and dementia
outcomes in 607 White, Black, Hispanic, and Asian survivors of brain bleeds who are already being enrolled in
an existing separate NIH clinical study. In this new study, we will determine which epigenetic changes causally
mediate the relationship between environmental exposures and dementia, in order to help identify biological
pathways that can be modified by drugs or behavioral interventions to reduce health disparities in dementia after
brain bleeds.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

full_study_section.name: Genetics of Health and Disease Study Section[GHD]

results.project_title: Deep mutational scanning of MYH7 in genome-edited cardiomyocytes
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Genetic variants in myosin heavy chain 7 (MYH7) are common causes of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM),
a potentially life-threatening heart disease. Most of the MYH7 variants are classified as variants of unknown
significance, which affects the ability to accurately identify patients at risk for HCM. This proposal will
determine the disease-causing potential of thousands of MYH7 variants to better interpret genetic test results
for patients and will identify shared mechanisms by which MYH7 variants cause HCM, which may inform
potential future interventions.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences

results.project_title: CTSA Postdoctoral T32 at The Scripps Research Institute
results.phr_text:
The T32 postdoctoral training program of the Scripps Research CTSA aims to establish a new
generation of early career scientists capable of bridging science and medicine in the context of a rapidly
changing world of healthcare and emerging diseases. Basic science, elucidation of mechanisms of
diseases, discovery of new therapeutic approaches and drugs, and digital monitoring of health are
primary areas of investigation for our members. In addition, an important component of citizenship is
included in our training to promote three important core competencies: (i) mentorship, (ii) inclusion of
all groups regardless of gender, racial, and cultural backgrounds, and (iii) community engagement.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Genomics, Computational Biology and Technology Study Section[GCAT]

results.project_title: DNA Methylation Dynamics of Mammalian Development
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 DNA methylation is one of the oldest known epigenetic modifications to the genome, playing an important
role in the gene regulatory landscape by typically acting in a repressive context, with aberrant DNA methylation
observed in various diseases and developmental disorders. Despite its importance, this property has not been
assessed during the dynamics of mammalian development at high-resolution. We have developed new tools
that will enable us to address key hypotheses regarding the mechanistic role of DNA methylation in conjunction
with other epigenetic properties that will we apply to the developing mouse embryo with a further focus on
intestinal epithelial cell lineages.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Human Genome Research Institute

results.project_title: Promoting Genetic Counselors in Independent Research Through Advanced Training and Education (PROMOTE-GC)
results.phr_text:
Genetic counselors are vital to genomic medicine, but research questions in which they have
key insights remain unanswered because most genetic counselors lack the practical
experience, research methods expertise, and necessary research community to formulate,
conduct, and lead large-scale research projects. PROMOTE-GC is designed to address these
barriers by providing a part-time, 2-year research training experience for master’s-level genetic
counselors that includes 1) mentored intensive research experiences, 2) training in research
methods, and 3) support in building a durable, multidisciplinary professional research
community they can call on in the future. This training benefits not only the individual genetic
counselor participants, but also the genomic medicine enterprise by enhancing the research
capacity of these vital members of the workforce.

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Viral Pathogenesis and Immunity Study Section [VPI]

results.project_title: Mapping the virus-host interactions that determine interferon resistance of Seoul orthohantavirus
results.phr_text:
Hantavirus disease is a form of zoonotic viral hemorrhagic fever (VHF) that results when humans inhale
excreta from hantavirus-infected rodents, with case-fatality rates exceeding 40% for some hantaviruses. In its
natural reservoir host, the brown rat, Seoul virus causes asymptomatic, lifelong infection, posing a persistent
threat to humans worldwide due to the global rat distribution. This proposal capitalizes on the functional
proteomics expertise of the team to identify host-specific interacting partners of Seoul virus proteins that
determine resistance to interferon-mediated viral restriction in reservoir host cells, thereby identifying novel
effectors to limit viral infection in humans.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Psychosocial Development, Risk and Prevention Study Section[PDRP]

results.project_title: A New Foundation: Advancing Adolescent Neglect Science through Measurement Development
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
 The neglect of children and adolescents is prevalent and imperils health and well-being throughout the
lifespan. This project involves the careful conceptualization, development, and initial validation of a
multidimensional youth self-reported measure of adolescent neglect, conceptualized as unmet adolescent
needs (versus parental omission). The measure will make it possible for future research to rigorously study
adolescent neglect and will provide the necessary conceptual foundation for effective intervention.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

results.project_title: Pathogenic mechanisms of adult hearing loss caused by Zfp719 mutations
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The identification of gene mutations associated with hearing loss in humans and animal models
has contributed greatly to our understanding of cell type specific functions in the inner ear.
Experiments in this grant proposal are strongly motivated by the premise that a detailed
elaboration of the molecular and cellular mechanisms of cochlear development and function will
not only provide better insight into the workings of this complex sensory organ, but may also
profoundly change the way inner ear disorders, including hearing loss, are treated in the future.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Improving Global Measurement of Intimate Partner Violence
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Intimate partner violence (IPV), the most common form of violence worldwide, is responsible for
a variety of physical and mental health problems for victims and exposed children that can persist
throughout the life course. Despite increased awareness of the negative societal impacts of IPV
and an international commitment to reducing IPV enshrined in the Sustainable Development
Goals, numerous challenges exist in commonly used questionnaires to measure IPV. Improving
the precision, validity, and cross-cultural consistency of IPV measurement is a prerequisite for
accurately assessing the scope of the problem, evaluating efforts to prevent and reduce IPV, and
effectively allocating resources to address this pervasive global health threat.

agency_ic_admin.name: John E. Fogarty International Center for Advanced Study in the Health Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health
John E. Fogarty International Center for Advanced Study in the Health Sciences

full_study_section.name: Population and Public Health Approaches to HIV/AIDS Study Section[PPAH]

results.project_title: Developing and testing a digital health tool for INterseCtional stigma assessment and reduction at multiple Levels and mUltiple DimEnsions (INCLUDE) to improve HIV care in ART centers in Nepal
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative:
HIV is a significant public health issue, and intersectional stigma (stigma from multiple dimensions, such as
having mental health problems, gender, and/or sexual orientation) is an important barrier to achieving the 95-
95-95 goal, which is to diagnose 95% of all people living with HIV, provide antiretroviral therapy (ART) for 95%
of those diagnosed, and achieve viral suppression for 95% of those receiving ART. To address this issue, we
are proposing to develop a digital tool, called INterseCtional stigma assessment and reduction at multiple
Levels and mUltiple DimEnsions (INCLUDE), for routine use in ART centers. The aim of this study is to assess
the acceptability and feasibility of using INCLUDE to measure and address intersectional stigma and if
successful, this can provide a valuable intervention for studying and addressing intersectional stigma.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: In Vitro Identification of miR-718 targets and miR-718-induced epigenetic modifications
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are critical regulators of gene expression and may be causative factors in disease
development. This study will examine what genes are targeted by increased levels of an understudied miRNA-
miR-718- and the relationship of these gene targets to changes in epigenetics in a human neuronal cell line.

organization.org_name: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Biobehavioral Regulation, Learning and Ethology Study Section[BRLE]

results.project_title: Investigate the Neural Circuits of Infant-Directed Behaviors
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Child abuse has profound negative impacts on children’s physical and mental health. As current
understanding of its neural underpinnings is limited, effective treatment to prevent and correct
these hostile behaviors is lacking. The proposed study will elucidate the neural circuits underlying
the generation of positive and negative infant-directed behaviors using mice as an animal model.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Cellular and Molecular Technologies Study Section[CMT]

results.project_title: Development of in vitro human spinal neural tube model to study genetic and environmental etiology of Spina Bifida.
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
 This research program is highly relevant to public health as spina bifida (SB), resulting from the defects
of spinal neural tube (SNT) formation, is the second most prevalent birth defect in humans with life-long
disabilities and neurological disorders. We will investigate how genetic predisposition and its interaction with
environmental factors regulate human SNT formation with in vitro 3D SNT organoids and develop an SNT chip
with an advanced microfluidics system to recapitulate the spatiotemporal microenvironment. The ultimate goal
of this research program is to provide the scientific and technical progress toward developing novel intervention
strategies for SB.

full_study_section.name: HIV Molecular Virology, Cell Biology, and Drug Development Study Section[HVCD]

results.project_title: Targeted Degradation of HIV Integrase as a Novel Treatment of Infection
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Management of HIV infection is facilitated by a number of current antiretroviral therapies that effectively block
HIV function. However, the probability of patient relapse increases over time, as HIV mutates and becomes
resistant to approved therapeutics. This project involves the development of a new class of compounds that
can target both the original and the mutated form of HIV, allowing for long-term management for HIV patients.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: Chaperoning Preassembly Modules for Mitochondrial Ribosome Assembly
results.phr_text:
Henry, Michael F.
Project Narrative
This proposed research seeks to better understand the causes of mitochondrial disorders; a group of
diverse diseases that includes cancer, infertility, diabetes, heart disease, blindness, deafness and
neurodegenerative diseases. The yeast model organism will be used to study a feature of
mitochondrial genome expression conserved in humans. This information is necessary for discovering
the underlying causes of mitochondrial disorders and may help identify potential therapies that could
prevent, or even reverse, mitochondrial diseases.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

full_study_section.name: Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases Clinical Trials Study Section [AMSC]

results.project_title: An Observational Study of IL1 Inhibition for Blocking ACVR1-Induced Flare Activity and Heterotopic Ossification in Fibrodysplasia Ossificans Progressiva
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This project will contribute to improved public health by helping understand if treating immune overactivity can
decrease abnormal bone formation in patients with FOP. The new knowledge will validate important tools and
approaches for clinical studies in small cohorts of patients, and also provide critical preliminary data for designing
larger studies that may be beneficial for patients with common causes of abnormal bone formation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

full_study_section.name: Emerging Imaging Technologies in Neuroscience Study Section[EITN]

results.project_title: Predicting recovery after TBI: Development and comparison of MR-supplemented models using non-parametric and machine learning multimodal fusion
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The ability to leverage early biomarker, clinical, and demographic data to accurately predict a patient’s likely
recovery trajectory following moderate-to-severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) is paramount to allow definition of
appropriate therapeutic strategies and to evaluate medical (as well as ethical and legal) decision-making
including withdrawal of life-supporting therapies. Here, we develop, and compare to existing clinical algorithms,
two novel strategies that leverage non-parametric models and machine learning techniques to fuse and
incorporate routine multimodal and multiplex MR signals into prediction frameworks. Ultimately, this project aims
at developing a broadly accessible platform that can be used by practicing clinicians all over the world to
supplement prognoses with quantitative and spatial multimodal MR data.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: Investigating electromagnetic field-based neuromodulation of slow-wave brain activity and glymphatic system
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Glymphatic activity (specifically the movement of neurofluid in extracellular and extravascular space that drains
soluble neural metabolites from the nervous system) is essential for brain health, and development of
interventional approaches to enhance glymphatic activity has great implication to care of neurological disorders
including Alzheimer’s disease. We propose to 1) assess the feasibility of modulating glymphatic system
through electromagnetic field-based slow wave entrainment in pigs anesthetized with propofol, and 2) measure
the impact of slow wave entrainment on glymphatic activity using multi-contrast MRI.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Inhaled ciclesonide - a phase I study in preterm infants
results.phr_text:
Dexamethasone and other synthetic glucocorticoids are commonly used to prevent
bronchopulmonary dysplasia in preterm infants but they are known to impair brain and somatic
growth. Ciclesonide is a synthetic glucocorticoid prodrug that is rapidly converted to its active
form in the lung and has been shown in neonatal models of brain and lung injury to be as
efficacious in preventing lung injury without causing significant brain or systemic toxicity. In this
study, we will pursue a phase I dose escalation clinical study using an inhaled preparation of
ciclesonide to establish its safety and toxicity profile in preterm infants, while also assessing
levels of CIC metabolites and glucocorticoid receptor activation profile.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Defining the role of ILF2-ILF3 in human cell fate
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
In the United States, congenital malformations and deformations are the leading cause of death in infants. The
proposed research aims to uncover novel gene regulatory interactions that specify cell identities during normal
development. The objective of this study is to use human pluripotent stem cells to how cell identities are specified,
with the ultimate goal to inform new strategies for the treatment and prevention of congenital disorders.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Cloud/Subscription based, Customer-Responsive Dosimetry Tool for alpha-Particle Emitters
results.phr_text:
Proj Narrative
Radiopharmaceutical therapy (RPT) – the use of targeted radionuclides to deliver radiation specifically to
cancer cells and their microenvironment – is a growing area with a substantial number of large and small
pharmaceuticals companies developing products in this area. The dosimetric evaluation of therapeutic
radiopharmaceuticals is a key requirement for safe and effective therapy with these agents, especially
for alpha-particle emitters. In this proposal, we will calculate microscale S values and implement a
methodology specifically to address the requirements of alpha-emitter dosimetry in RPT.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Pathophysiology of Obesity and Metabolic Disease Study Section[POMD]

results.project_title: Pathophysiological mechanisms in the brain's endogenous glucagon-like peptide 1 system mediated by obesogenic diets
results.phr_text:
New therapies are needed for the treatment of obesity and obesity-related conditions like type II diabetes that
address core limitations of GLP-1-based therapeutics. In this application we will investigate the activity states of
the brain’s endogenous GLP-1 system in diet-based models of obesity, a major gap in knowledge. Further, we
will investigate how dysregulation of the brain’s GLP-1 system contributes to obesity pathogenesis and whether
elevation of the activity state of this system is a tractable treatment strategy for obesity using laboratory mice,
behavior, and neural circuit techniques.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: Topical Neurokinin-1 Receptor Antagonist as an Effective Non-addictive Analgesic for Ocular Pain
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Ocular pain is highly prevalent, leading to decreased quality of life and suffering, and yet its pharmacologic
management remains very limited. Protracted ocular pain is often associated with chronic inflammation that
persists in the absence of ongoing insult. This project, grounded on our two pre-clinical models of chronic
ocular pain, proposes to determine the analgesic efficacy and underlying mechanisms of topical neurokinin-1
receptor (NK1R) antagonism, as an effective non-addictive therapeutic strategy for chronic ocular pain
management, utilizing its dual anti-nociceptive (anti-pain) and anti-inflammatory (thereby anti-neuropathic)
properties.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

full_study_section.name: Reproductive, Perinatal and Pediatric Health Study Section[RPPH]

results.project_title: Comorbidities in Pregnant Women with Prenatal Alcohol Exposure and Adverse Birth Outcomes
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The aims of this study are to: (1a) estimate the extent of comorbidities among pregnant women
with prenatal alcohol exposure; (1b) build maternal morbidity risk profiles based on social and
behavioral determinants of health among women with prenatal alcohol intake using machine
learning (ML) methods; (2a) examine the effects of comorbidities on adverse birth outcomes
among alcohol-exposed pregnancies; and 2(b) build risk profiles for adverse birth outcomes
using ML methods. This study presents a model of study that combines both maternal and
infant health in the context of maternal-fetal exposure to alcohol, using innovative methods of
data analyses that will yield previously unidentified risk profiles. Given the need for careful
allocation of scarce health care resources for prevention and treatment programs, the
identification of women and their infants for adverse health outcomes most at risk is critical.
.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Novel Mcl-1 Inhibitor for Combination Treatment of Refractory Multiple Myeloma
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative:
Over the long-term, this significant and innovative research will determine the efficacy of targeting the anti-
apoptotic Bcl-2 family protein Mcl-1 to inhibit refraction and recurrent disease development and improve the
efficacy of traditional therapy to increase the number of multiple myeloma patients responding to this
treatment. Therefore, the impact on cancer mortality rates could be significant.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

results.project_title: Develop a wireless, skin-conformable and dual-sensing wearable system in support of voice and upper airway telehealth care
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Voice and upper airway (VUA) diseases hamper a person’s speaking and breathing functions when performing
day-to-day activities. In this project, we will develop a flexible, wireless wearable device to monitor VUA
symptoms via a unique, hybrid accelerometry and electromyography sensing technology. With this new wearable
system, clinicians will be able to track patient VUA health conditions outside clinics, whereas patients will be
empowered to be more in charge of their health.

organization.org_name: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

results.project_title: HRV-guided tDCS: Integrating a biomarker for clinical utility
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The integration of biomarker guidance with transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) could individualize and
optimize dosing to improve its clinical utility. We propose to develop a tDCS system that includes the collection
of the nonspecific biomarker of heart rate variability (HRV), by validating impedance-based heart rate (i-HR) and
its clinical response to tDCS intervention in adults with depression. With the advantage of home-based data
collection, this proposal rigorously builds a breakthrough system that includes wearable neuromodulation and
monitoring of vital signs linked to brain health.

full_study_section.name: Digestive and Nutrient Physiology and Diseases Study Section [DNPD]

results.project_title: ASSESSING PSYLLIUM GIVEN WITH MEALS FOR FRUCTAN SENSITIVITY IN CHILDREN WITH IRRITABLE BOWEL SYNDROME
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a disorder of gut-brain interaction that affects up to 20% of school children
worldwide. Children and adults with IBS may improve their symptoms when restricting fermentable
carbohydrates from their diet – but this restriction is challenging, does not work in all individuals, and may have
unintended health consequences. This proposal will begin to investigate a non-dietary restriction therapy by
evaluating psyllium (a soluble fiber) given with meals for fermentable carbohydrate (fructan) induced childhood
IBS symptoms.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Research Study Section[AIDS]

results.project_title: Development of anti-PD-1-targeted chimeric antigen receptors and genetic circuits to deplete viral reservoirs in the nonhuman primate model of lentiviral infection
results.phr_text:
Project narrative
This proposal develops the next generation of an anti-PD-1 chimeric antigen receptor T cell approach which
cleared germinal centers of signs of T follicular helper cells and associated viral replication in the non-human
primate model of lentiviral infection, albeit increasing extrafollicular viral replication due to depletion of PD-1+
CD8+ memory T cells.
While exciting, additional safety features need to be implemented in this approach to make it clinically useful
and it is arguably easier to engineer greater safety than to develop other approaches.
By integrating more sophisticated genetic circuits and programmable control mechanisms into the current anti-
PD-1 CAR platform, targeted depletion of TFH cells is improved, thereby providing foundational knowledge to
enable further studies towards the role of TFH cell depletion for an HIV cure in the nonhuman primate model.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: Elucidating the role of luminal pH in regulating phagosome transport
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Macrophages, a type of immune cells, capture microbial pathogens in vesicles known as phagosomes,
which are gradually filled with acid as they move towards the center of the immune cell where they fuse with
another vesicle known as the lysosome for pathogen elimination. The goal of our proposal is to elucidate
how the acid in the phagosome lumen governs the transport of the phagosome. Pathogens that cause
severe diseases in humans employ various mechanisms to subvert phagosomal acidification, and therefore
insights gained from this study will have significant implications for developing effective methods to combat
these highly dangerous microbes.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: Phosphorylation of α/β Tubulin is a 'Toggle Switch' in Human Breast Cancer
results.phr_text:
Alternating phosphorylation states of α− and β-tubulin in microtubules define a “toggle switch”
model to be explored as a novel decision-point in cell behavior. Phosphorylation of α-tubulin or
β-tubulin could determine whether a breast cancer cell metastasizes to a remote site or proliferates
into a primary tumor, respectively. The α/β-tubulin toggle switch could have intrinsic biological
significance as well as clinical value as a therapeutic target and prognostic indicator of metastatic
potential.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

results.project_title: Biodesign for Health Equity
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
We are developing a new training program for biomedical engineering (BME) students that will cultivate their
Engineering Habits of Mind (EHoM) and serve as a bridge to a career in medical device research and
development (R&D). This experiential learning (EL) opportunity will consist of a clinical immersion conducted in
rural and urban healthcare facilities to identify unmet medical needs with a focus on understanding the social
determinants of health (SDoH) and promoting health equity. In parallel, student teams will build prototyping
skills by working on existing R&D projects to improve healthcare with our clinical partner and lead design,
fabrication, and proof-of-concept testing through simulated use verification and validation activities.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Polyamine modification of host immune responses and oxidative balance in the cervicovaginal space: potential mechanisms governing cervical remodeling in preterm birth
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Mechanisms driving spontaneous preterm birth remain incompletely understood, although premature cervical
remodeling appears to be a common pathway leading to preterm birth. The proposed research aims to identify
mechanisms through which polyamines, which are relatively abundant metabolites in the cervicovaginal space,
affect cervical remodeling and risk of preterm birth. Of significant translational and public health importance,
this work will provide the basis for potential development of polyamine-based preventative or therapeutic
interventions to mitigate risk of spontaneous preterm birth, the leading cause of neonatal morbidity and
mortality worldwide.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Characterizing the role of affective information in early word learning using observational and experimental designs
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 The goal of this project is to develop and test a framework describing the multimodal affective environment
that supports language development in early childhood. Using computational analyses of infants’ at-home
environments in the first years of life as well as a series of tightly-controlled experiments, we ask (1) how
affective contexts shape word learning and (2) how children with depressed caregivers adapt their learning
strategies to the decreased affective information in their environments. Understanding how children with
depressed caregivers use affective information to learn new words may inform tailored efforts to promote
equity in educational outcomes.

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Interrogating the Role of Bacterial Methyl-modifying Enzymes in Pathoadaptation and Host Epigenetic Interference in Cancer
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Members of the human microbiota have been shown to play an important role in cancer initiation and
progression, but the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. Building on novel insights from published
and preliminary studies in bacterial epigenetics, mammalian epigenetics, and cancer microbiome research, we
propose that bacterial enzymes called DNA methyltransferases, which are abundant within the human
microbiota, can drive colon cancer development by promoting bacterial virulence as well as modify the human
cell genome. If successful, we will uncover a novel host-microbe interaction that could be targeted for disruption
as a strategy to prevent or treat cancer

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: The Third Pittsburgh Rust Belt Microbiome Conference
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The Third Pittsburgh Rust Belt Microbiome (RBM) Conference will be open to nation-wide participation while
providing a unique opportunity for Rust Belt region scientists, clinicians other healthcare workers to interact in
an inclusive, interactive conference environment that will focus on cutting-edge mechanistic and translational
research in the role of the microbiome in infectious disease, clinical science and personalized medicine. The
conference will also highlight work and professional development opportunities for students and junior
researchers in the microbiome space.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Meganuclease-mediated gene editing for durable control of HSV-2 infection
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
HSV-2 can have deep social and health consequences for the estimated 500 million infected individuals, yet
current antiviral therapies can only reduce symptoms and disease severity, and do not cure. We have
developed an innovative therapeutic strategy consisting of targeting and eliminating HSV genomes directly
within viral reservoirs using gene editing meganucleases. Leveraging our strong, unique expertise in gene
editing enzyme technology and HSV virology, Caladan Therapeutics and Fred Hutch propose to develop and
advance an anti-HSV-2 gene therapy towards clinical applicability, offering a plausible pathway toward a cure
for individuals infected with HSV-2.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: NIH Office of the Director

results.project_title: Integrated proteomic and metabolomic biomarker profiling for understanding metabolic syndrome in pregnant women living with HIV on Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate/Lamivudine/Dolutegravir (TLD)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE:
Effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) is critical during pregnancy for women living with HIV (PWHIV) for optimal
maternal and fetal health, but there are knowledge gaps in pharmacology of new HIV drugs, adverse effect
profile, and safety in pregnancy that prevent efficient and effective deployment of our most promising new ART
in pregnant women. The objective of this proposal is to advance our knowledge of adverse effect profile
associated with -- Dolutegravir (DTG), Tenofovir Disoproxil Fumarate (TDF), and Lamivudine drug combination
--in PWHIV and their offspring, using advanced “omics” technologies (integrated proteomics and metabolomics).
Research goals include clinical and biomarker characterization of metabolic syndrome, and providing insights
into the mechanistic intricacies of metabolic syndrome in large community-based cohorts of black and white
PWHIV in the US and Nigeria, with the overall goal of optimizing HIV therapeutics for PWHIV.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Research Study Section[AIDS]

results.project_title: ENHANCEMENT OF CD4CAR T-CELL PERSISTENCE IN VIVO
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
HIV remains a substantial public health burden, as antiretroviral therapy (ART) is capable of suppressing viral
replication but not curing infected individuals. Therefore, transmission continues globally with treatment barriers
that include limited healthcare access and toxicity from ART. To achieve viral suppression without the need for
ART, this proposal will advance HIV-targeting CAR T cells with enhanced long-term persistence.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: Evaluation of PrEP implementation strategies for the general population in Botswana
results.phr_text:
Lack of effective HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) programs is a significant contributor to ongoing spread
of HIV in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA). Our proposed study, to be conducted in Botswana, will leverage a
successful national ART program and infrastructure to first test a set of strategies for the general population
(18-49 years old) to increase PrEP uptake using information and communications technology to expand reach,
reduce barriers due to mobility and competing needs for work. Based on lessons learnt from the preliminary
study, we will then assess if PrEP uptake and persistence will be better with the new strategies as compared to
the way PrEP is currently being offered in Botswana.

full_study_section.name: Biobehavioral Regulation, Learning and Ethology Study Section[BRLE]

results.project_title: Role of neurexin in social adaptation and amygdala plasticity
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Social behavior is a key element of mammalian function and impairments are a core feature of
Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD). There are known genes that influence social function, and
genetic risk factors for ASD, but the influence of these genes on neural circuits of social
behavior is mostly unknown. Understanding the impact of these genetic factors on these neural
circuits is necessary to uncover how they influence social function.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Identification of essential biomarkers in the polyploid cancer cell lifecycle
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Polyploid cancer cells have emerged as a dangerous subpopulation of tumor cells but remain poorly
characterized. This proposal seeks to identify genes that allow this subpopulation to arise and form daughter
cells and to use archived, de-identified samples from ovarian cancer will be analyzed for putative markers of
polyploid cancer cells. Results from this project serve as a foundation for detection of polyploid cancer cells in
cancer specimen and to develop novel therapies aimed at eliminating this population or the formation of
daughter cells.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Nursing Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Nursing Research

full_study_section.name: Health Promotion in Communities Study Section[HPC]

results.project_title: Navigating Financial and Health-Related Social Needs in Adolescent and Young Adult Cancer Survivors (AYA-NAV): A Digital Intervention Pilot Study
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The overall goal of this mixed methods study is first, to refine our current model of financial and health-related
social needs navigation to integrate an established digital platform of community resources and to optimize our
vocational navigation support (Aim 1). Then, we will evaluate the feasibility, including AYA uptake and
engagement (Aim 2) and explore the preliminary impact on reducing financial toxicity and improving global
health outcomes (Aim 3) among 80 racially, ethnically, and socioeconomically diverse AYA cancer survivors in
New York City. Our intervention is patient-informed, leverages clinical and community partnerships, and thus
has a high likelihood of success as well as sustainability, scalability, and overall impact.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Sensitive Treponema pallidum genome recovery through tiling amplicon sequencing
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Sensitive Treponema pallidum genome recovery through tiling amplicon sequencing
Genomic epidemiology is now a routine part of the public health response to pathogen
outbreaks. Here, we propose to design and validate a tiling amplicon sequencing
approach for complete genome recovery from Treponema pallidum, the causative agent
of syphilis. Amplicon tiling approaches recently enabled the sequencing of >16 million
SARS-CoV-2 genomes and we expect these methods will allow for more sensitive and
rapid recovery of T. pallidum sequencing in laboratories across the world.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Fellowships in Kidney, Urology, and Hematology[DDK-G]

results.project_title: Mechanisms of cyst progression driven by Na,K-ATPase in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is a multifactorial disease with poorly understood
mechanisms. Our previous research implicates the ouabain-induced signaling pathway of the Na,K-ATPase as
a contributor of cyst progression in ADPKD. This proposal uses novel animal models to begin uncovering the
mechanisms behind this ouabain-induced Na,K-ATPase signaling in ADPKD and reveal targets for future
ADPKD therapies.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: Intervention to Help Orient Men to Excel (IN-HOME): A culturally appropriate CHW training program to reduce minority caregiver burden
results.phr_text:
Informal caregivers of older adults aging in place are at a substantial risk of negative emotional,
mental, physical health implications, and increased mortality because of prolonged distress,
intense physical demands, and sense of loss that affect caregivers’ physiological and
psychological functioning. Among all caregivers, minorities are more likely to be long-time
caregivers and are at higher risk for caregiver burden, stress, and burnout – and while more
men in general, and Black and Latino men specifically, are full time caregivers for older adults,
there are few resources to support this particularly at-risk group. We will finalize a culturally
competent, online professional development course for community health workers to support
male minority caregivers, then explore the impact of trained CHW outreach on caregiver
knowledge, skills, and health, and wellbeing.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities
NIH Office of the Director

full_study_section.name: Psychosocial Development, Risk and Prevention Study Section[PDRP]

results.project_title: Psychosocial Predictors of Risk for Suicidal Behavior Among Gender Minority Adolescents
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
 Gender minority adolescents (GMAs; adolescents whose gender identity is different than their sex
assigned at birth) have extremely high risk for suicidal behavior, but little is known about how psychosocial
experiences contribute to GMA risk for suicidal behavior. The proposed longitudinal study will examine how
psychosocial experiences predict risk for suicidal behavior over time among diverse GMAs and non-GMAs,
providing critical evidence to more accurately predict which GMAs have high risk for suicidal behavior as well
as to identify novel intervention targets to reduce high rates of suicidal behavior among GMAs.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: Research and Engagement for Advancing Chronic pain Healthcare Equity (REACH)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This K23 project seeks to address the critical gap in the utilization of pain psychology among
socioeconomically disadvantaged patients with chronic low back pain (cLBP), a prevalent health issue
contributing to health disparities. The project proposes a three-pronged approach: first, to quantify the effect of
socioeconomic status on pain psychology utilization; second, to identify barriers to and facilitators of pain
psychology services, which will guide the creation of a tailored intervention, the Empowering Pain Psychology
Access and Collaboration (EPPAC); and third, to pilot the EPPAC intervention, assessing its acceptability,
feasibility, and preliminary efficacy compared to usual care. The successful execution of this project will
generate data and expertise, contributing to the PI's long-term goal of promoting equitable and effective use of
evidence-based treatments among marginalized pain populations.

organization.org_name: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: Design and pilot testing of a culturally tailored breastfeeding promotion intervention for non-Hispanic black women
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
There are significant racial disparities in breastfeeding rates, particularly for non-Hispanic black (NHB) women,
who are already disproportionally impacted by adverse health outcomes. The proposed research aims to
understand the decision-making process, individual level determinants, and environmental barriers to
breastfeeding among NHB women. Findings will inform the systematic and community-engaged design of a
tailored breastfeeding peer counselor program to improve breastfeeding outcomes (e.g., initiation, duration,
intensity, breastfeeding goals) among NHB women.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

full_study_section.name: Drug and Biologic Therapeutic Delivery Study Section[DBTD]

results.project_title: Magnetically Triggered Protein Release for Varying Severities of Spinal Cord Injury
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating condition that affects thousands of Americans every year and
there are currently no available treatments that restore lost function. There is an urgent need for biomaterial
interventions that deliver drugs locally, as systemic administration results in limited drug titer at the injury site;
however, current biomaterial approaches are not capable of responding to a patient’s unique inflammatory
response. This proposal details the development of a prototype magnetic biomaterial composite capable of
releasing precise dosages via magnetically triggered release of an anti-inflammatory growth factor to mitigate
the reactivity of astrocytes and create a growth-permissive environment for axonal regeneration.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Pathophysiology of Obesity and Metabolic Disease Study Section[POMD]

results.project_title: Defining the contributions of hypothalamic microglia and perineuronal nets to obesity pathogenesis
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Obesity is among the most common and costly disorders affecting Western society, yet underlying pathogenic
mechanisms remain unclear. We propose that activation of brain microglial cells by high-fat diet consumption
causes loss of key regulatory structures called perineuronal nets (PNNs), leading to disruption of the control
system for body weight. Here, we will formally test this model by directly assessing the contributions of
microglial activation and PNN loss to the development of obesity.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: Normobaric Oxygen Therapy for Spinal Cord Injury
results.phr_text:
This proposal tests the hypothesis that exposure to brief periods of 100% oxygen will have an anti-
inflammatory impact on the injured cervical spinal cord. We further hypothesize that combining 100% oxygen
therapy with treatment with a perfluorocarbon molecule will result in neuroprotection as shown by reduced loss
of neurons after spinal cord injury. We predict that this will improve breathing ability after cervical spinal cord
injury.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: Characterizing Economic Determinants of Violence and Safety Disparities Among Sexual and Gender Diverse Populations
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Financial security has been identified as a determinant of violence and safety, yet this relationship has not
been examined for sexual and gender diverse (SGD) populations despite experiencing disproportionately high
rates of violence and facing vulnerability across multiple dimensions of financial security. The proposed study
will utilize quantitative, qualitative, and policy evaluation research designs to examine the role of financial
security and the impact of policy in shaping SGD violence disparities. Findings from this study will contribute to
the evidence base on economic determinants of SGD population health and inform upstream violence
prevention strategies in alignment with NIMHD’s strategic plan to address minority health disparities.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities
NIH Office of the Director

full_study_section.name: Healthcare and Health Disparities Study Section[HHD]

results.project_title: Examining the Mechanisms and Consequences of Sleep Health Inequities Affecting Black SexualMinority Men
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
We propose to conduct a community-based longitudinal mixed-methods study characterizing sleep health
inequities in a sample of Black sexual minority men across a 12-month period, focusing on upstream
determinants (intersectional stigma and discrimination) and downstream consequences (mental health,
physical health, and health behavior). Results will elucidate mechanisms through which intersectional stigma
and discrimination at individual and structural levels affect sleep health and how compromised sleep health, in
turn, contributes to mental and physical health problems in this group. Community input and mixed-methods
data will inform future policies and intervention efforts, paving the path to health equity for this underserved
group.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Library of Medicine

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Library of Medicine
NIH Office of the Director

results.project_title: EMPOWHer: Embracing Midlife & Menopause Positively-Offerings by Women with HIV
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
The primary goal of this proposal is to develop “EMPOWHer” Embracing Midlife and Menopause Positively:
Offerings by Women with HIV, a virtual education program designed to enhance clinician knowledge and
confidence with providing midlife health and menopause care to women with HIV(WWH). The EMPOWHer
program will be co-created by WWH from diverse US geographic regions in partnership with
transdisciplinary/transprofessional clinicians and researchers.

principal_investigators.title: PROFESSOR AND ASSOCIATE DEAN OF RESEARCH

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Nursing Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Nursing Research

results.project_title: Comprehensive Advancement in Research Education and Training for Social Determinants of Health (CARES)
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This R25 CARES program addresses gaps in social determinants of health (SDOH) education for nursing
researchers, aiming to equip early career scholars, especially those from under-represented backgrounds, with
comprehensive SDOH research fundamentals and methodologies. The program includes short courses,
summer institutes, mentorship, and networking activities over three years for three cohorts. By fostering a
supportive community, enhancing research proficiency, and promoting diversity, the program seeks to
empower nurse researchers to conduct impactful SDOH research, contributing to the advancement of
knowledge in the field.

organization.org_name: GRADUATE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH POLICY

full_study_section.name: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome Research Study Section[AIDS]

results.project_title: Examining the Interplay of COVID-19 and HIV: Impacts on HIV Care, Disparities, and Long-Term Outcomes
results.phr_text:
Narrative
 The proposal addresses two challenges to Ending the HIV Epidemic (EHE): increasing comorbidities,
coinfections, and complications in PWH and widening disparities in HIV care outcomes. Understanding any
lasting impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on the care of people with HIV and structural issues at the root of
HIV and other healthcare disparities is crucial for the success of EHE initiatives. We expect this K01 to
generate landmark publications and rich preliminary data for an R-series proposal from a new investigator to
expand research into support and care for PWH and the short- and longer-term impacts of the SARS-CoV-2
and future pandemics on EHE.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Training and Workforce Development Study Section - C[TWD-C]

results.project_title: Bridges to the Baccalaureate: Cumberland Bridge to Rowan
results.phr_text:
The Cumberland Bridge to Rowan (CB2) Bridges to the Baccalaureate Research Training
Program is a biomedical research training program seeking to diversify the biomedical
workforce. Trainees in the program will develop scientific and research skills that will support
discovery in biomedical sciences which ultimately support public health.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Cellular, Molecular and Integrative Reproduction Study Section[CMIR]

results.project_title: Contribution of the paternal histone epigenome to embryo development and pregnancy loss
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Paternal epigenetic contributions, or non-genetic changes to DNA, are delivered to the embryo from
mammalian sperm, however the mechanisms through which they regulate embryo development, placentation,
and maintenance of pregnancy are largely unknown. We propose the use of sperm from bulls of high and low
fertility to investigate the role of the paternal epigenome in abnormal embryo development and pregnancy loss.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: An Outcome-Focused Measure of Mental Health Care Quality based on Standardized Patient-Reported Symptoms
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 It would be very helpful to have measures of the quality of mental health services to inform patients’
choice of clinicians and organizations, the training and supervision of clinicians, value-based purchasing and
quality improvement efforts. Patient-reported symptoms can be electronically collected and used to study the
quality of care for common depressive and anxiety disorders. This project develops and tests a new outcome-
focused measure of mental health care quality that can be implemented nationally to improve services and
outcomes in the community.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

full_study_section.name: Skeletal Biology Development and Disease Study Section[SBDD]

results.project_title: Impact of maternal dietary vitamin A on risk and severity of cleft lip/palate in genetically sensitized embryos
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
This project will address a critical gap in our knowledge regarding factors that influence the risk that a child will
be born with cleft lip/palate and, equally importantly, how severe that presentation will be. The latter is the
major determinant of the number of craniofacial surgeries that the child will endure. Specifically, the project will
investigate the impact of maternal dietary vitamin A levels and its interaction with specific cleft genes as well as
how early developmental events in the embryo influence severity of the presentation of cleft lip/palate.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Respiratory Integrative Biology and Translational Research Study Section[RIBT]

results.project_title: Antimicrobial blue light-activatable optical endotracheal tube to combat biofilms on the endotracheal tube
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is one of the most common nosocomial infections with significant
morbidity and mortality, and biofilms on endotracheal tubes are recognized to be a leading cause of VAP,
and currently there are no available options that are both treatment-effective and cost-effective to prevent
VAP effectively. In this application, we aim to explore the utility of a novel optical endotracheal tube
(Optical-ETT), which emits antimicrobial blue light from the ETT surface, to prevent biofilm formation and
eradicate preexisting biofilm on the ETT. A successful completion of the studies this application will
provide the preclinical evidence required to determine the effectiveness and safety of the Optical-ETT,
and will demonstrate the functionality of a prototype system of Optical-ETT.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award A Study Section[MRAA]

results.project_title: Epitranscriptomic and post-transcriptional regulation of the RNome in gram negative and firmicute bacteria
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Public Health Relevance: The proposed research project will expand our understanding of the genetic code,
RNA modifications, and the control of gene expression in response to various stressors in a wide variety of
bacteria. This new information will help us understand how bacteria evolve and adapt to harsh environments.
This will assist us in preparing for emerging or re-emerging bacterial infections.

organization.org_name: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award C Study Section[MRAC]

results.project_title: RNA regulation in germline development and fertility
results.phr_text:
Germ cells are essential for fertility. Our long-term goal is to understand the mechanisms that regulate
specification and maintenance of the germline. The immediate goal of our research is to investigate the
function and contribution of conserved genes to stem cell specification and sex-specific development
of the germline, which has implications for understanding normal reproductive development, Disorders
of Sexual Differentiation, and fertility, areas of biomedicine greatly in need of more research.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: HIV Immunopathogenesis and Vaccine Development Study Section[HIVD]

results.project_title: Identifying drivers of genital inflammation and HIV acquisition in women living in sub-Saharan Africa
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Of the 1.2 million new HIV infections each year, almost 70% occur in sub-Saharan Africa and most occur in
young women of reproductive age following heterosexual sex; the female genital tract (FGT) therefore plays a
pivotal role in the acquisition of HIV infection in women. In this project, we will utilize innovative multi-omic
characterization of vaginal bacteria and host measures of genital inflammation using samples from a unique
clinical cohort of South African women living in an area of extraordinarily high HIV incidence and prevalence.
This research has the potential to inform novel strategies for reducing HIV infections in women, particularly for
those living in sub-Saharan Africa.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Mental Health

results.project_title: A modular bioluminescence imaging platform using a novel multi-aperture method
results.phr_text:
InVivo Analytics seeks funding for developing a modular imaging platform for bioluminescence
imaging of small animal models addressing challenges in imaging performance and sensitivity,
multi-view imaging, anatomical co-registration, user accessibility, and automated image data
analysis.

organization.org_name: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
