full_study_section.name: HIV Immunopathogenesis and Vaccine Development Study Section[HIVD]

results.project_title: Eliciting Broadly Neutralizing Antibody Responses against HIV-1 Fusion Peptide Epitope by AB Toxin B Subunit-Based Immunogens
results.phr_text:
Innovative ideas are crucial for developing an effective HIV/AIDS vaccine. The aim of this project is to create
AB toxin-based vaccines with the capability to elicit broadly neutralizing antibodies targeting the fusion peptide
region of HIV-1 and capable of neutralizing Tier 2 viruses, ultimately paving the way for a protective vaccine.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Development of soluble and membrane bound immunogens to shepherd HIV-1 MPER specific BCR maturation
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative.
The induction of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bnAbs) by vaccination is a global health priority
as a means to prevent HIV infection, and the membrane proximal external region (MPER) of the
HIV-1 envelope protein is a site of particular interest. Vaccine induction of bnAbs will likely require
sequential immunization with additional immunogens designed to shepherd affinity maturation of
the B cell receptor (BCR) to acquire neutralization breadth and potency. This project seeks to
develop soluble and membrane-bound boost immunogens that present the MPER epitope in a
more native-like context with the aim of maturing primed BCRs to acquire bnAb features.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities

results.project_title: Cancer Screening Mammography in Transgender and Gender Diverse (TGD) Individuals
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Transgender and gender diverse (TGD) individuals are often diagnosed with late-stage cancer and often die
from cancer prematurely. These individuals appear to be underscreened for breast cancer at rates and for
reasons that are unknown. This K23 application will enable the principal investigator to investigate these rates
and reasons; to learn from her 6 senior mentors; to take necessary coursework; and ultimately to emerge as a
national leader with the goal of helping TGD individuals acquire equity in cancer screening and cancer care.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Cancer Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Cancer Institute

results.project_title: Hijacking Post-translational Arginylation for Targeted Protein Degradation
results.phr_text:
Project narrative
The cancer substrates regulated by arginylation and subsequent degradation are largely unknown. This proposal
aims to unbiasedly unveil the arginylation substrates and their sites in cancer cells and recruit ATE1 to achieve
targeted protein degradation through arginylation-ubiquitination-degradataion cascade. The novel approach
called arginylation targeting chimera (ArgTAC) holds full potential to be developed as cancer therapies.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

results.project_title: Integrated computational approaches to determine contributions of the oral virome
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The oral cavity is a complex environment where a diverse array of organisms coexists in dynamic interplay with
the human immune system. While bacteria and fungi have traditionally been the focus of research on the
human microbiome, recent studies have highlighted the significant role of phages (viruses infecting bacteria) in
shaping the oral microenvironment. Our proposal aims to re-examine the large set of existing metagenomic
data to comprehensively investigate the role of the oral virome and its interactions with the microbiome which
will help us to understand the intricate dynamics of the oral microenvironment; ultimately inspiring new
approaches to promote oral health and prevent/manage oral diseases more effectively.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Population based Research in Infectious Disease Study Section[PRID]

results.project_title: Socioeconomic impacts of La Crosse encephalitis in western North Carolina
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
This project focuses on the socioeconomic impact of neuroinvasive/non-neuroinvasive La Crosse virus disease
(most common cause of arboviral pediatric encephalitis in the United States) in western North Carolina.
Economic wellbeing may contribute to disparities in risk awareness, adherence to personal protection, and
clinical recognition and this relationship will be verified, along with site assessments of mosquito-related risks.
Findings are expected to contribute to the development of public/environmental health strategies to intervene
to improve risk reduction, treatment, and recovery resources, thereby reducing impact on survivors and
families.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

results.project_title: Translational Programming of Beta-cells in Response to Glucose Toxicity
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Failure of pancreatic β-cells to secrete insulin in response to glucose is a hallmark of diabetes pathogenesis.
Under normal conditions, glucose stimulates synthesis of the insulin protein, but prolonged exposure to high
glucose during the development of diabetes impairs this critical β-cell function. By discovering new mechanisms
by which glucose regulates production of the hormone insulin, this project has the potential to identify novel
targets for the development of treatments to halt or delay diabetes progression.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Kidney, Urologic and Hematologic Diseases D Study Section[DDK-D]

results.project_title: Nicotinamide Adenine Dinucleotide (NAD+) Metabolism During Observational and Experimental Heat Stress and the Effect of Niacinamide Among Individuals at Risk for Mesoamerican Nephropathy
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Climate change has widespread and consequential impacts on human health, one of which may be the
development of a form of kidney disease in Central America related to heat stress exposure called
Mesoamerican Nephropathy. This project studies mechanisms connecting heat stress and Mesoamerican
Nephropathy, with a particular focus on metabolic derangements arising during kidney injury that may be
targeted with an oral B-vitamin to protect against disease. Understanding how heat stress produces kidney
injury and identifying ways to help mitigate this injury is of vital importance in Mesoamerican Nephropathy and
beyond as extreme heat events become more and more frequent globally with climate change.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

results.project_title: Development of Retronasal Smell Perception in Young Children and Relation with BMI
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Between 4 and 6 years of age, children develop eating habits that last a lifetime, often with negative
consequences for health. Flavor perception is a major determinant of food choices but is poorly understood
among young children. The present proposal addresses this issue by investigating how different senses (taste
and smell) contribute to flavor perception in early childhood, and how flavor perception relates to weight status.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

full_study_section.name: Pathophysiology of Obesity and Metabolic Disease Study Section[POMD]

results.project_title: Diet and the neurodevelopment of impulsivity
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Consumption of a Western Diet, high in saturated fat and sugar, during the adolescent phase of development
impairs hippocampal-dependent learning and memory function during adulthood. The hippocampus is also
known to regulate aspects of food intake control that are relevant for obesity, including impulsive behaviors to
obtain and consume palatable yet otherwise unhealthy food. We propose to determine the impact of an
adolescent Western Diet on food impulsive behavior, identify the neurobiological circuits involved, and
determine whether the impact of the diet can be reversed by exercise and/or treatment with a GLP1R agonist.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Allergy, Immunology, and Transplantation Research Committee[AITC]

results.project_title: Immune biomarkers to predict outcomes in solid organ transplant patients with bloodstream infections
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Bacterial bloodstream infections (BSI) are among the most common and serious infections in solid organ
transplant (SOT) recipients. Optimal immunosuppression management in SOT recipients with BSI is unknown
but critical to improving outcomes. The proposed studies will identify cytokine, chemokine, immunoglobulin, and
gene expression biomarkers of 30-day mortality and septic shock among SOT patients with BSI, enabling the
development of an immunologic prognostic model.

organization.org_name: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

results.project_title: Biologic Encapsulation by Tuning their Organic Solubility with Amphiphilic Polymers
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Bone regeneration can be facilitated with growth factor BMP-2 if provided at consistent optimal dosing.
Unfortunately, current drug release approaches result in supraphysiological dosing of BMP-2 which leads to
negative side effects. Here, we plan to fine tune BMP-2 solubility in polymer matrices using complex copolymers,
robotics, and artificial intelligence.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Allergy, Immunology, and Transplantation Research Committee[AITC]

results.project_title: Targetable pathways driving sub-optimal early-life CD8 T cell responses
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Viral infections are a leading cause of early-life morbidity and mortality, and CD8 T cells are a crucial component
of adaptive immunity responsible for combating viruses and conferring immunological memory. This project aims
to understand the role of intrinsically high PI3K/mTOR signaling in early-life CD8 T cells and how this pathway
contributes to metabolic and functional peculiarities of early-life T-cell responses in health and severe viral
illness. This research will lead to further insights into how early-life CD8 T cells differ functionally from young
adults and what pathways could serve as targets for therapies to improve early-life immune responses to
infection and vaccination.

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

full_study_section.name: Neurodifferentiation, Plasticity, Regeneration and Rhythmicity Study Section[NDPR]

results.project_title: The Role of Dystrophin in Synapse Development
results.phr_text:
Narrative:
Duchene muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the gene for dystrophin, which is highly expressed in
muscle tissue, but also found at inhibitory synapses in the brain. The function of dystrophin in the brain is still
unclear. This project will demonstrate that dystrophin, and the protein complex it belongs to, are necessary for
maturation of inhibitory synapses. Understanding the function of dystrophin in synaptic function is critical to
developing future therapies for cognitive deficits associated with muscular dystrophy and other
neurodevelopmental disorders.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Salmonella type III secretion: substrate targeting and injectisome assembly
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Type III secretion (T3S) is arguably the most important route through which gram-negative animal pathogens
cause disease in humans. The characterization of secretion-substrate recognition and the T3S-specificity switch
for the Salmonella injectisome systems will further our understanding of host-pathogen interactions, protein-
secretion specificity, nanomachine self-assembly and coupled gene regulatory mechanisms. These complex
mechanisms provide a wealth of potential therapeutic targets to inhibit T3S-associated pathogenesis.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

results.project_title: Translational regulation of PGC1alpha and oxidative metabolism
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Obesity and its associated metabolic disorders represent a major threat to the American health, as well as a
substantial economic burden. Thermogenic fat is a specialized tissue whose role is to expend excess energy,
and activating this tissue might ameliorate metabolic disease in humans. This proposal aims to understand
how this cell type is naturally regulated in order to identify new ways to therapeutically activate it.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

results.project_title: Engineering ferritin degrader-encapsulated platelets for post-surgical TNBC treatment
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Post-surgical TNBC recurrence is the major cause of the poor prognosis of TNBC patients. This proposal aims
to identify intracellular ferritin as a new TNBC therapeutic target and develop a ferritin-degrading proteolysis
targeting chimeras (PROTACs) molecule to leverage the intracellular ubiquitin-proteasome system to degrade
ferritin to induce the TNBC cell pyroptosis. The endogenous platelets will be applied to encapsulate developed
ferritin degraders for enhanced in vivo pharmacokinetics and anti-TNBC recurrence efficacy, which can serve as
monotherapy or synergize with current immunotherapeutics to prevent post-surgical TNBC recurrence.

organization.org_name: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

full_study_section.name: NHLBI Mentored Transition to Independence Study Section[MTI (MA)]

results.project_title: Post-transcriptional mechanisms of direct cardiac reprogramming
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Heart failure affects about 5.7 million adults in the United States and continues to be the leading cause of death
globally, partly due to the limited therapeutic options. Direct cardiac reprogramming, which converts non-
myocytes in the heart to induced cardiomyocytes, offers a promising alternative strategy for repairing the heart.
This proposal will use state-of-art approaches to delineate the post-transcriptional mechanisms of this process
for its future clinical implementation.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

results.project_title: Alcohol Tolerance as a Driver of Self-Administration
results.phr_text:
––– PROJECT NARRATIVE ––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Alcohol use disorders are a chronic human condition driven by numerous factors, including one’s initial
sensitivity to ethanol intoxication, how easily one develops tolerance to these intoxicating effects with
continued alcohol experience, or how one becomes insensitive to the pleasant, rewarding effects of alcohol
over time. How exactly these different alcohol responses depend on each other has not been systematically
analyzed. The results from this proposal will examine how these different alcohol responses depend on each
other, thereby illuminating critical mechanisms driving addiction and substance use.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: Multiscale genomic decryption of regulatory DNA
results.phr_text:
Narrative:
This proposal uses advanced sequencing technologies and molecular perturbations to investigate how genes
are regulated in human cells. The data generated by these approaches will be analyzed to reveal how regions
of regulatory DNA are spatially and functionally organized at both the level of individual nucleotides and their
distribution across the genome. This information will help interpret how mutations in human DNA may lead to
developmental defects or increased susceptibility to disease.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Drug Abuse
National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Biobehavioral Regulation, Learning and Ethology Study Section[BRLE]

results.project_title: The Developmental Effects of Environmental Enrichment on the Minor Cannabinoid Drug Reward and Cannabinoid Receptor Levels
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
While the rodent environmental enrichment model has been shown to be protective against various drugs of
abuse, the developmental onset of this enrichment has not been elucidated nor have the effects of enrichment
on cannabinoid drugs been investigated. The purpose of this study is to determine if the length of exposure to
environmental enrichment during adolescence differentially alters brain density of the cannabinoid receptors
(CB1R) or the rewarding effects of vaped delta-8 tetrahydrocannabinol, cannabidiol, and mixtures of these
compounds. The results of the current proposal will be important in determining whether enrichment during
development protects against the rewarding effects of popular vaped cannabinoids.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Maximizing Investigators' Research Award - E Study Section[MRAE]

results.project_title: Structure and function of staphylococcal surface proteins involved in biofilm growth and virulence
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Biofilms are communities of bacteria that adhere to one together and attach to surfaces; by virtue of growing in
a biofilm, bacteria become highly resistant to antibiotics or immune responses and cause recurrent, hard-to-
treat infections. In this project we will investigate the structure of key staphylococcal surface proteins and their
interactions that hold bacterial cells together in the biofilm. The results from this research will provide new
insights into controlling bacterial biofilm formation and reducing the risk of recurrent infections.

results.project_title: CE24-001, Grants for Injury Control Research Centers (ICRC) - 2024
results.phr_text:
UNIVERSITY OF IOWA INJURY PREVENTION RESEARCH CENTER
 PROJECT NARRATIVE
The University of Iowa (UI) Injury Prevention Research Center (IPRC) aims to prevent, control, and optimize
recovery from injuries and violence, especially in rural communities. The UI IPRC works toward this goal
through research, training and education, and outreach, focusing on rural populations and multiple types of
injury and violence. The UI IPRC will continue its strong tradition of multidisciplinary, collaborative, and
integrated activities that engage diverse areas of expertise and multiple local, state, and national partners.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award B Study Section[MRAB]

results.project_title: Deciphering protein ubiquitination with chemical biology tools
results.phr_text:
Narrative
The ubiquitin proteasome system is currently underexploited for therapeutic interventions despite a vast number
of proteins and complexes associated with this vital system. Our understanding of ubiquitin signaling
mechanisms as mediated by the many forms of ubiquitin modifications is still lacking. Chemical tools are central
to the efforts in unraveling the complex pathways and mechanisms in ubiquitin signaling and they also provide
new ways of exploiting the ubiquitin pathway enzymes for drug development, thus achieving therapeutic benefit
in treating human diseases such as neurodegeneration and cancer.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award A Study Section[MRAA]

results.project_title: Molecular mechanisms of chromatin signaling and epigenetic regulation
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
DNA methylation is a key epigenetic regulator of genome-templated processes, and dysregulated DNA
methylation signaling is a defining molecular feature of human cancer and other diseases. This proposal seeks
to understand how DNA methylation is inherited through cell divisions, why DNA methylation patterns change in
cancer and aging cells, and how these changes contribute to disease states. As DNA methylation antagonism
is a major clinical strategy for epigenetic therapy, these studies also have the potential to identify biomarkers
and next-generation therapeutic targets for the management of cancer and other diseases.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

agency_ic_fundings.name: NIH Office of the Director

results.project_title: A multi-level framework for characterizing task-efficient coding geometry of neural population activities
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Rapid progress in experimental neuroscience techniques and machine learning-based models for the brain
presents a common challenge in understanding high-dimensional (many neurons) neural representations in an
interpretable and quantifiable way. This proposal represents a path to a multi-level framework for connecting
neural representational geometry to multiple scales (neurons to regions) and levels of computational abstraction,
such as (i) the effect of single neuron tuning properties on neural representations, (ii) the role of region-to-region
transformations and task-learning, and (iii) new algorithms for training neural network models of the brain via
geometry and machine learning. The synergy between two modern approaches – task-efficient representational
geometry and machine learning – will lead to new fundamental principles and methods in computational
neuroscience and enable multi-level, multi-scale theory of neural representations and discover common
principles of neural computation across different brain regions and multiple modalities.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

full_study_section.name: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award B Study Section[MRAB]

results.project_title: Structural requirements for sterol 14α-demethylases
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
Integrating cryo-EM techniques into the P450 field will open new horizons in understanding
molecular dynamics and evolution (with the prospect of rational reprogramming) of this catalyst,
including its interactions with the electron donor partner proteins and biological membranes. For
CYP51 in particular, such knowledge is essential in developing new therapeutics that benefit human
health, in addressing the escalating problem of drug resistance in the clinic and will help validate the
proximal P450 surface as a new target for inhibition.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

results.project_title: Project 1 - Examining the impact of microbial dynamics on B cells responsible for anti-blood group antibody formation
results.phr_text:
Narrative: ABO(H) blood group antigens were the first human polymorphisms described and corresponding
anti-ABO(H) antibodies continue to be the most common immunological barrier to transfusion and
transplantation. However, despite their discovery over a century ago, the factors responsible for anti-ABO(H)
antibody development remain relatively unknown. Using a series translational studies coupled with a new
preclinical model of anti-blood group antibody formation, we will define key factors that influence the development
of anti-ABO(H) antibodies.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Aging

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Aging

full_study_section.name: Career Development Facilitating The Transition to Independence Study Section[AGCD-1]

results.project_title: Establishing reactive astrocyte memory as a risk factor for aging-related neurodegenerative disease
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Viral and bacterial infections result in transient neuroinflammation and are a common occurrence throughout life,
yet how or why temporary inflammation increases the risk of developing neurodegenerative disease (ND) remains
elusive. Similarly, despite the key role of astrocytes in neuron function and modulating the immune response, they
are often overlooked in the study of ND. The proposed research will address these outstanding questions and
provide fundamental insight into how transient astrocyte reactivity affects future insults and how this impacts on
ND.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Ankle contractures in muscular dystrophy: mechanisms and tissue adaptations
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Ankle contracture, or loss of full ankle joint motion, commonly occurs alongside progression of muscle
degeneration and weakness in ambulatory children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). A lack of
understanding of the pathophysiology of contracture development has limited the impact of rehabilitation
interventions used to prevent contractures and maximize functional ability in DMD. This study will evaluate the
potential mechanisms leading to loss of ankle range of motion and the muscle and tendon tissue adaptations
associated with ankle contractures in ambulatory children with DMD, which will give rehabilitation professionals
the ability to make more evidence-based decisions and provide more targeted interventions.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

results.project_title: Development of a Novel AAV9 Gene Replacement Therapy for Neurofibromatosis Type 2
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Patients suffering from the progressive, currently incurable genetic disorder Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2),
which causes tumor growth throughout the nervous system, face a shortened lifespan and a lifetime of
devastating neurological symptoms that remain unaddressed by current treatment technologies. Merlin
Therapeutics is developing a unique gene therapy allowing NF2 deficient cells to produce a healthy version of
the lacking NF2 protein in all cell types affected by the disease, thereby addressing the underlying disease
cause. The proposed project will confirm existing preliminary data and establish dose-response, safety, and
biodistribution data for our lead gene therapy candidate to bridge the gap to the next steps to a future clinical
trial and position this vector as a potential preventive and/or treatment for NF2.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Androgen Enhancement of E. coli Hemolysin Toxicity during Pyelonephritis.
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Kidney infection caused by Escherichia coli can lead to systemic infection, impaired renal function, or renal
scarring. Recent work in mouse models shows that androgen exposure worsens pyelonephritis, often leading
to abscess formation in the kidney. This project will define how an E. coli toxin called alpha-hemolysin (HlyA)
promotes renal damage and how its toxic activity in the kidney is amplified by testosterone.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

results.project_title: CONTROL OF RB TUMOR SUPPRESSOR FUNCTIONS THROUGH POST-TRANSLATIONAL MODIFICATIONS
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Covalent protein modifications are critical regulatory signals that enable cells to adapt to changing conditions,
but they are often dysregulated in diseases, such as cancer. In the interest of improving public health, we must
understand–at the molecular level–how such modifications affect protein function and dysfunction. To this end,
the proposed work will establish a causative link between protein modification, structure, and function, which
may ultimately translate to new treatment strategies for human diseases.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Investigating the potential of wastewater surveillance data to improve SARS-CoV-2 dynamical modeling and forecasting
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Mathematical models that help predict cases and hospitalizations of COVID-19 are essential for policy makers
and the public to plan public health interventions and prepare for outbreaks and typically rely on data about
cases. As data on cases has become less reliable and sparser, wastewater surveillance has emerged as a new
source of data for tracking infections; however, it is not clear yet how wastewater surveillance can be used to
improve modeling of transmission. This project will take advantage of a unique collaboration with the New York
State Wastewater Surveillance Network to find out how wastewater surveillance data may be used to improve
SARS-CoV-2 forecasting and protect the public health.

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Deciphering the mechanisms of nucleolar stress response during MCPyV infection
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The nucleolar stress response (NSR) functions to maintain cellular homeostasis when the cell is faced with
stress or suboptimal growth conditions. This research proposal will investigate how this stress response is
regulated by and how it might impact viral replication of Merkel Cell Polyomavirus, a human tumor virus that
causes a highly fatal skin cancer called Merkel Cell Carcinoma (MCC). Such work will advance our
understanding of the role of the NSR during viral infections, an area which has not been well described, and
identify potential therapeutic targets to prevent the onset of MCC.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

results.project_title: Defining the role of platelet-mediated glycocalyx breakdown in driving pathogenic CD8 activity during severe malaria.
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
While vascular leak is a deadly complication of malaria, the mechanism underlying its development is poorly
understood. The goal of this proposed study is to identify how platelet degranulation promotes vascular leak by
driving endothelial glycocalyx breakdown and CD8 T cell activation/recruitment to the lung during severe malaria.
This work is relevant to the NIH mission to develop fundamental knowledge that reduces human disease burden
by defining a mechanistic pathway that could be targeted by novel adjunct therapies to disrupt the development
of vascular leak in malaria.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Development of novel bacteriophage-based therapies to combat Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Candida spp. dual-species biofilms.
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The opportunistic pathogens, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Candida spp., are growing concerns in healthcare
settings due to their increasing rates of antimicrobial resistance, and are commonly co-isolated from infections.
The present study aims to develop two novel treatment strategies against such coinfections, ones using
antimicrobial peptides and bacteriophages, viruses that selectively infect bacteria. Not only would such
treatments provide alternative approaches to combating bacterial and fungal coinfections, but their development
would provide a new pipeline for treatment of additional polymicrobial infections and site-specific delivery of drug
compounds.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.project_title: Determining the mechanism of cell death of small molecules produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa against Acanthamoeba castellanii
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Acanthamoeba castellanii is a pathogenic free-living amoeba responsible for central nervous system human
infections that are almost always fatal. The proposed research will aim to identify potent amoebicidal compounds
produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an environmental bacteria that co-exists with A. castellanii, and
determine how these are inducing cell death. This work will therefore identify novel natural products that will
bring us closer to treating devastating human infections caused by A. castellanii and other free-living amoebae.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

results.project_title: Development of an intravenous CB1 antagonist for acute cannabinoid intoxication and cannabis hyperemesis syndrome
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Recent legalization of cannabis in a growing number of States across the U.S. has led to a
rapid increase in availability and use of cannabis and cannabis products, in a wide range of
inhaled and edible forms that are potent and inexpensive, and this in turn has led to an
exponential surge in emergency department (ED) visits for acute cannabinoid intoxication
(ACI). This project aims to further advance Anebulo Pharmaceutical’s clinical development of
an emergency treatment for ACI: ANEB-001, a CB1 antagonist shown to rapidly reverse the
key symptoms of ACI after single oral doses in a Phase 2 THC challenge study in healthy
subjects. Ultimately, providing ANEB-001 as an intravenous antidote for ACI and potentially
cannabis hyperemesis syndrome (CHS) in the ED could address this rapidly growing unmet
need, particularly for children and vulnerable patients at greatest risk of potentially life-
threating adverse events, while also reducing the burden on the US healthcare system.

agency_ic_admin.name: Veterans Affairs

full_study_section.name: Rehabilitation Research and Development SPiRE Program[RRDS]

results.project_title: Evaluation of Anti-Inflammatory Delivery from Mechanically-Activated Microspheres in the Context of Cruciate Ligament Injury
results.phr_text:
From mouse to man, traumatic injuries to the joint cause inflammation and, when the instigating injury remains
uncorrected, persistent inflammation culminates in irreversible degradation of all joint structures. This project
develops and validates a novel joint injectable anti-inflammatory sustained drug delivery system in client owned
canines presenting with knee injury (cruciate ligament disease). Successful completion of this study will advance
this new technology towards human clinical implementation and validate, for the first time, the safety and
therapeutic efficacy of IL-1Ra delivered from mechanically activated microcapsules (MAMCs) compared to
systemic and soluble IL-1Ra joint injections in a pilot clinical trial (executed through the PennVet Veterinary
Clinical Investigation Center).

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Central & Peripheral Mechanisms of Respiratory & Autonomic Control Dysfunction in a Novel Model of SIDS: Predictive Biomarkers and the Role of the Extracellular Matrix
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative:
Sudden Unexpected Infant Death (SUID) is the leading cause of infant mortality up to one year of age. A
significant proportion of the ~3,500 SUIDS per year in the US are classified as Sudden Infant Death Syndrome
(SIDS). The cause of SIDS is complex, multifactorial, and remains largely unknown. Here we implement an
animal model of SIDS to: 1) investigate new (and existing) central and peripheral neural mechanisms
associated with mortality; 2) perform screening of blood and urine to discover several new biomarkers as
potential predictors of infants at increased risk of SIDS; and 3) test a clinically approved drug that may be a
novel prophylactic measure to prevent SIDS.

organization.org_name: SOUTHERN ARIZONA VA HEALTH CARE SYSTEM

agency_ic_admin.name: Veterans Affairs

results.project_title: Validation of Patient-Specific, iPSC-based In Vitro Liver System
results.phr_text:
NARRATIVE
 The number of patients with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in the United States will continue to
escalate due to the high prevalence of the two main risk factors for the disease—obesity and diabetes that are
both higher within the Veteran community compared to the general public. From a public health standpoint, there
are no effective medications to treat NASH, no biomarkers for disease progression, and no effective high-
throughput screening technologies. The goal of the project is to benchmark the in vitro microfluidic system
against two animal models of NASH. The technology has unique advantages afforded by its ability to be a high-
throughput system that utilizes patient-specific cells that can be obtained with minimal intervention. Once
validated here, the microfluidic system will enable improved diagnostics, uncover molecular pathways and
identify new treatments for a disease that leads to liver cancer, need for transplantation, and oftentimes death.

full_study_section.name: Addiction Risks and Mechanisms Study Section[ARM]

results.project_title: Exploring the antecendents and consequences of cannabis use in the context of coping: An experimental study
results.phr_text:
Project Narrative
Using cannabis for coping purposes is a problematic use pattern with negative health implications (e.g., greater
quantity/frequency of cannabis use), and this behavior has potential for increase due to spreading cannabis
legalization. The current project proposes to test several relationships relevant to this use pattern including
causal factors, potential outcomes, and what variables may moderate/mediate the relationship between
cannabis use and stress. Knowledge from this research can have significant impact on public health via aiding
in intervention and prevention efforts as well as gaining information on the harm reduction potential of specific
cannabinoid content.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute on Drug Abuse

results.project_title: Development of NLRP3 inhibitors for HIV-associated neuroinflammation in cocaine use.
results.phr_text:
Narrative
Inflammation plays a pivotal role in the development of HIV-associated comorbidities, including HIV-associated
neurocognitive disorders (HAND). The use of substances of abuse, such as cocaine, worsen the neurological
outcomes in HIV patients. We propose to develop novel NLRP3 inhibitors that will minimize the
neuroinflammation in HIV patients abusing cocaine.

agency_ic_admin.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

agency_ic_fundings.name: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

results.project_title: Early Life Phenotyping of Very Preterm Infants
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Among very preterm infants, variation in health outcomes within gestational age categories may be explained
by perinatal factors. We propose to define a perinatal phenotype for very preterm infants that integrates
maternal characteristics and care with infant presentation at birth to predict meaningful outcomes.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Nursing Research

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Nursing Research

full_study_section.name: Biobehavioral Medicine and Health Outcomes Study Section[BMHO]

results.project_title: Patient activation, cognition, and self-management for LVADs
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Patient activation, cognition, and self-management for LVADs
Left-ventricular assist devices (LVADs) are the most complex machines ever designed for home use with
difficult self-management (SM) and high health care use (HCU) but little is known about the factors influencing
patient outcomes. Patient activation (PA) is the willingness and ability to manage a health condition and may
offer unique opportunities for improving LVAD SM and HCU. We seek to understand the relationships
between cognition, PA, LVAD SM, and HCU, and to explore PA as a mediator of the influence of cognition on
outcomes, by studying patients prior to and within 12-months after LVAD surgery.

results.project_title: Acute effects of THC in older adults
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Cannabis use is rapidly growing in older adults, but there is no reliable experimental data about the acute effects
of cannabinoids in healthy older adults. In this double-blind, placebo-controlled study, the impact of age on THC
effects will be investigated.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Eye Institute

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Eye Institute

results.project_title: Curved Implantation of Flexible Microelectrode Arrays for High-Density Mapping of Nonlinear Brain Structures and Circuits
results.phr_text:
Project Narratives
The brain consists of structures and neural circuits that are nonlinearly organized in nature. Electrophysiological
mapping of complete structures or circuits is critical to understand their functional organization, synaptic
connectivity, and signal processing. This project explores a new modality that allows the nonlinear implantation
of flexible neural probes to conformally cover designated structures or circuits at minimal surgical lesions and
thus enables mapping nonlinear brain trajectories at unprecedented spatial resolution.

agency_ic_admin.name: National Institute of Mental Health

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

full_study_section.name: Population and Public Health Approaches to HIV/AIDS Study Section[PPAH]

results.project_title: Improving HIV testing among Children under five in Rural Uganda
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The proposed research is relevant to public health because it can potentially address gaps in current
prevention of maternal-to-child transmission programs in sub-Saharan Africa, where nearly 140,000 infants are
perinatally infected with HIV each year. We hypothesize that the innovative strategy of training traditional
healers to deliver HIV counseling and rapid HIV testing in their communities can increase testing among
children who have not received the World Health Organization recommended HIV testing. We propose
formative qualitative work to guide adaptation of an evidence-based HIV testing intervention that will meet the
unique needs of children and their caregivers (Aim 1), and then to pilot test this intervention at five traditional
healer practices among 200 children aged between 18 months to 5 years old (Aim 2).

organization.org_name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON

agency_ic_admin.name: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences

agency_ic_fundings.name: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences

results.project_title: CTSA Predoctoral T32 at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This predoctoral T32 application is seeking to train six translational science researchers at the predoctoral level
who will build a community of clinical and translational scientists by leveraging the trans-institutional multi-
disciplinary strengths of our Center for Clinical and Translational Sciences (CCTS) based at the University of
Texas Health Science Center at Houston (UTH-H). Through a TL1 grant which preceded this application,
awarded as the training core of the CCTS, we have trained 94 diverse and productive translational researchers,
57% of whom are female, 16% of whom are underrepresented and 31% of whom are faculty at domestic
academic institutions. In the proposed training program, we will continue to train leaders in translation science
while integrating trainees from CCTS partner institutions in south and east Texas, thereby bringing additional
diversity to the T32 since these trainees will draw upon the broad racial, ethnic, gender, economic and social
backgrounds represented in Texas.

full_study_section.name: Skeletal Biology Development and Disease Study Section[SBDD]

results.project_title: Characterization of senescent cell populations in skeletal aging
results.phr_text:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Cellular senescence is a key mechanism driving age-related bone loss and other aging co-morbidities. The
overall goal of this application is to leverage our novel tools and mouse models in order to better define the
mechanisms driving cellular senescence in the bone microenvironment and to characterize the key senescent
cell populations that contribute to skeletal aging.
